original: prāṇapuryaṣṭakakrameṇa śarīramapi saṃcaramāṇā spandanarūpā satī vyāpārātmikā māthāpade 'pi pramāṇasya pratyakṣāderviṣayaḥ /
analyzed: prāṇa puryaṣṭaka krameṇa śarīram api saṃcaramāṇā spandana rūpā satī vyāpāra ātmikā māthā pade pi pramāṇasya pratyakṣa ādeḥ viṣayaḥ
translated: moving through the body in the sequence of the vital breath and the eight [constituents of the individual], being in the form of vibration, being of the nature of activity, is the object of perception etc., the means of knowledge, even in the state of deep sleep.

original: sā ca paraśarīrādisāhityena avagatā svaṃ svabhāvaṃ jñātmakamavagamayati /
analyzed: sā ca para śarīra ādi sāhityena avagatā svam svabhāvam jña ātmakam avagamayati
translated: And that, being understood through association with another's body etc., makes one understand one's own nature, which is known.

analyzed: na ca jñānam idam tathā bhāti
translated: And knowledge does not appear thus as this.

analyzed: hi
translated: For thisness is ignorance.

original: na ca anyadvastu anyena vapuṣā bhātaṃ bhātaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: na ca anyat vastu anyena vapuṣā bhātam bhātam bhavet
translated: And an object cannot appear with another form.

analyzed: tat jñānam bhāti eva param
translated: That knowledge appears as supreme.

original: bhāti ca yat tadeva ahamityasya vapuḥ iti parajñānamapi svātmaivaḥ /
analyzed: bhāti ca yat tat eva aham iti asya vapuḥ iti para jñānam api
translated: And what appears is the very form of I. Thus, even another's knowledge is one's own self.

analyzed: paratvam kevalam upādheḥ deha ādeḥ
translated: The otherness is only due to the limiting adjunct like the body etc.

original: sa cāpi vicārito yāvat na anya iti viśvaḥ pramātṛvargaḥ paramārthata ekaḥ pramātā sa eva ca asti / taduktam
analyzed: sa ca api vicāritaḥ yāvat na anyaḥ iti viśvaḥ pramātṛ vargaḥ paramārthataḥ ekaḥ pramātā saḥ eva ca asti tat uktam
translated: And that also is considered thus far as it is not different. The entire group of knowers of the self is ultimately one knower, and He alone exists. That is said:

analyzed: prakāśaḥ eva asti sva ātmanaḥ sva para ātmabhiḥ
translated: Light alone exists by one's own nature, by one's own and others' selves.

original: iti / tataśca bhagavān sadāśivo jānāti ityataḥ prabhṛti krimirapi jānāti ityantam eka eva pramātā iti phalataḥ sarvajñatvaṃ pramātuḥ /
analyzed: iti tatas ca bhagavān sadāśivaḥ jānāti iti atas prabhṛti krimiḥ api jānāti ityantam ekaḥ eva pramātā iti phalataḥ sarvajña tvam pramātuḥ
translated: Thus, therefore, Lord Sadashiva knows, and so on up to even a worm knows. Thus, in effect, the knower is omniscient.

analyzed: evam kartṛ tve vācyam
translated: Similarly, it should be said in the case of being the agent.
As it was said by our supreme sages in the Shivadarshana:

original: ghaṭo madātmanā vetti vedmyahaṃ ca ghaṭātmanā /
analyzed: ghaṭaḥ mad ātmanā vetti vedmi aham ca ghaṭa ātmanā
translated: The pot knows by my nature, and I know by the nature of the pot.

original: sadāśivātmanā vedmi sa vā vetti madātmanā //
analyzed: sadāśiva ātmanā vedmi sa vā vetti mad ātmanā
translated: I always know by the nature of Sadashiva, and He knows by my nature.

analyzed: nānā bhāvaiḥ svam ātmānam jānan āste svayam śivaḥ
translated: Shiva Himself remains knowing His own Self by various states.

original: ityādi / ūhyate ityanena jñānena jñānasya prameyatvaṃ na nirvahati iti darśayati /
analyzed: ityādi ūhyate iti anena jñānena jñānasya prameya tvam na nirvahati iti darśayati
translated: Thus, and so on. By is inferred, he shows that the knowability of knowledge is not established by this knowledge.

analyzed: anyathā hi anumīyate iti brūyāt
translated: Otherwise, he would say is inferred.

original: tadevaṃ yeṣāṃ tārkikapravādapāṃsupātadhūsarībhāvo na vṛtto 'smin saṃvedanapathe /
analyzed: tat evam yeṣām tārkika pravāda pāṃsu pāta dhūsarībhāvaḥ na smin saṃvedana pathe
translated: Thus, those for whom this dust of the talk of logicians has not caused a boil in the path of consciousness,

original: te iyataiva ātmānamīśvaraṃ vidvāṃso ghaṭaśarīraprāṇasukhatadabhāvān tatraiva nimajjayanta īśvarasamāviṣṭā eva bhavanti /
analyzed: te iyatā eva ātmānam īśvaram vidvāṃsaḥ ghaṭa śarīra prāṇa sukha tad abhāvān tatra eva nimajjayantaḥ īśvara samāviṣṭāḥ eva bhavanti
translated: Those who know the Self as the Lord in this way alone, merge the pot, body, life, happiness, and their absence right there, and become completely absorbed in the Lord.

analyzed: tatas yam upoddhātaḥ
translated: Therefore, this is the introduction.

original: upa iti ātmanaḥ samīpe ṭaṅkavat īśvarapratyabhijñānalakṣaṇa utkarṣo hanyate viśrāmyate yena /
analyzed: upa iti ātmanaḥ samīpe ṭaṅka vat īśvara pratyabhijñāna lakṣaṇaḥ utkarṣaḥ hanyate viśrāmyate yena
translated: Up means the elevation characterized by the recognition of the Lord near the Self like a hammer, which is struck, i.e., rested upon.

original: etāvadeva ca asya granthasya tātparyam iti /
analyzed: etāvat eva ca asya granthasya tātparyam iti
translated: And this much alone is the purport of this treatise.

analyzed: tatas pi ayam upoddhātaḥ
translated: Therefore, this is also the introduction.

original: upāṃśu avitataṃ kṛtvā uditi śāstrasya ūrdhva eva hanyate apasāryate prameyaviṣayo vyāmoho yena iti /
analyzed: upāṃśu avitatam kṛtvā ud iti śāstrasya ūrdhve eva hanyate apasāryate prameya viṣayaḥ vyāmohaḥ yena iti
translated: Having made it inaudible, the delusion regarding the object of knowledge is struck, i.e., removed, above, i.e., beyond, the scripture, by which.

analyzed: gati artha tvāt vā hanteḥ jñānam arthaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning is knowledge, because of the sense of going in the word hanta.

analyzed: jñāyate prameyam yena iti
translated: By which the object of knowledge is known.

original: kecittu gatiṃ striyaṃ gacchati ityetadviṣayameva hantyarthamāhuḥ /
analyzed: kecid tu gatim striyam gacchati iti etad viṣayam eva hanti artham āhuḥ
translated: But some say that the meaning of hanta is only in the sense of she goes to the woman.

analyzed: evam śloka catuṣṭaya artha bhāvanā dārḍhy
translated: Thus, by the firmness of meditation on the meaning of the four verses,

analyzed: labhyate paramaśivaḥ iti śivam
translated: the supreme Shiva is attained. Thus is auspiciousness.

original: iti śrīmadācāryotpaladevaśiṣya śrīmadācāryalakṣmaṇaguptadattopadeśa śrīmadācāryābhinavaguptaviracitāyāṃ śrīpratyabhijñāvimarśinyāṃ 🔽jñānādhikāre upoddhātaḥ /
analyzed: iti śrīmat ācārya utpaladeva śiṣya śrīmat ācārya lakṣmaṇagupta datta upadeśa                             jñāna adhikāre upoddhātaḥ
translated: Thus ends the introduction in the chapter on knowledge in the venerable work called The Mirror of Recognition composed by the venerable teacher Abhinavagupta, given by the venerable teacher Lakshmanagupta, the disciple of the venerable teacher Utpaldeva.

analyzed: iti prathama āhnikam
translated: The first chapter.

analyzed: atha dvitīyam āhnikam  pūrvapakṣa tayā yena viśvam ābhāsya bhedataḥ
translated: Now, the second chapter.

analyzed: abheda uttarapakṣa antam nīyate tam stumaḥ śivaḥ
translated: We praise Shiva, by whom the universe is manifested as differentiated in the prima facie view,🔽and is led to the ultimate conclusion of non-differentiation.

original: iha yat paramārtharūpaṃ āśaṅkyamānapratipakṣapratikṣepeṇa nirūpayiṣyamāṇaṃ suṣṭhutamāṃ spaṣṭokṛtaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: iha yat paramārtha rūpam āśaṅkyamāna pratipakṣa pratikṣepeṇa nirūpayiṣyamāṇam suṣṭhutamām spaṣṭokṛtam bhavati
translated: Here, what is to be described as the nature of the ultimate truth by rejecting the suspected counter-arguments becomes very clearly illuminated.

analyzed: yat āha bhaṭṭanārāyaṇaḥ  namaḥ te bhava saṃbhrānta bhrāntim udbhāvya bhindate
translated: As Bhatta Narayana says:🔽Salutations to you, O God, who, having manifested the error of delusion due to worldly existence, destroy it,

original: jñānānandaṃ ca nirdvandvaṃ deva vṛtvā vivṛṇvate //
analyzed: jñāna ānandam ca nirdvandvam deva vṛtvā vivṛṇvate
translated: and having taken up the knowledge-bliss free from duality, explain it.

original: tatreha anātmānīśvaravādināṃ bhrāntibhedanapūrvakaṃ paramārthaṃ vivarīṣyan tadudbhāvanaṃ tāvat ekādaśabhiḥ ślokaiḥ karoti
analyzed: tatra iha anātma anīśvara vādinām bhrānti bhedana pūrvakam paramārtham tad udbhāvanam tāvat ekādaśabhiḥ ślokaiḥ karoti
translated: There, here, in order to explain the ultimate truth by first destroying the errors of those who propound the non-self and God, he first presents them in eleven verses.

analyzed: nanu sva lakṣaṇa ābhāsam
translated: But it appears as having its own characteristic...

analyzed: ityādibhiḥ
translated: and so on, up to

analyzed: tena kartā api kalpitaḥ
translated: ...therefore the agent is also imagined.

original: ityantaiḥ / tatra ślokadvayena ātmano dhruvasya dṛśyānupalabdhyā abhāva uktaḥ pratyakṣātmavādinaḥ prati /
analyzed: ityantaiḥ tatra śloka dvayena ātmanaḥ dhruvasya dṛśya anupalabdhyāḥ abhāvaḥ uktaḥ pratyakṣa ātma vādinaḥ prati
translated: This is said in two verses, where the non-perception of the visible of the eternal self is stated by one who maintains the nature of perception.

original: tatra ślokatrayeṇa smṛtyanusaṃdhānaṃ saṃskārāt siddham iti anyabāsiddhatvāt ātmānumānāya na paryāptam iti proktam anumeyātmavādinaḥ prati
analyzed: tatra śloka trayeṇa smṛti anusaṃdhānam saṃskārāt siddham iti ātma anumānāya na paryāptam iti proktam anumeya ātma vādinaḥ prati
translated: There, in three verses, it is said that the remembrance-connection is established from the impression, and that it is not sufficient for inferring the self because it is not established for others, to one who maintains the inferable self.

original: tatra ślokena jñānādi guṇairguṇini pratipattiḥ iti anumānaṃ nirastam /
analyzed: tatra ślokena jñāna ādi guṇaiḥ guṇini pratipattiḥ iti anumānam nirastam
translated: There, in one verse, the inference that the possessor of qualities is understood from the qualities such as knowledge is refuted.

analyzed: evam ātmānam nirākṛtya
translated: Having thus refuted the self,

original: tato jñānakriyāśaktisaṃbandharūpamaiśvarya nirākartuṃ jñānasya svarūpameva vyatiriktaṃ vādyantaramate /
analyzed: tatas jñāna kriyā śakti saṃbandha rūpam aiśvarya nirākartum jñānasya svarūpam eva vyatiriktam vādi antara mate
translated: in order to refute the lordship which is the connection with the power of knowledge and action, the nature of knowledge itself, which is separate according to the opinion of other schools,

original: sāṃkhyamate ca ayujyamānam iti nirūpitaṃ ślokadvayena /
analyzed: sāṃkhya mate ca ayujyamānam iti nirūpitam śloka dvayena
translated: and which is not appropriate according to the Sāṃkhya opinion, is examined in two verses.

original: tata ekena kriyā nāma na kācit kvacidapi asti iti kathitam /
analyzed: tatas ekena kriyā nāma na kācid kvacid api asti iti kathitam
translated: Then it is said that there is no such thing as an action anywhere at all.

original: tatra sādhakaṃ pratikṣipya bādhakaṃ ca upanyasyati /
analyzed: tatra sādhakam pratikṣipya bādhakam ca upanyasyati
translated: There, having refuted the proof, he presents the refutation.

original: tataḥ saṃbandhasya ślokena nāstitvaṃ pratipāditaṃ pramāṇābhāvaṃ vadatā /
analyzed: tatas saṃbandhasya ślokena nāstitvam pratipāditam pramāṇa abhāvam vadatā
translated: Then, by a verse, the non-existence of the relation is taught by one who speaks of the absence of a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: ślokena eva tatra bādhakam pramāṇam uktvā
translated: Having stated the refuting means of valid knowledge by a verse alone,

original: na ātmā sthiro nāpi jñātṛtvakartṛtvalakṣaṇam asya aiśvaryam iti svapakṣa upasaṃhṛtaḥ iti pūrvapakṣasya piṇḍārthaḥ /
analyzed: na ātmā sthiraḥ na api jñātṛ tva kartṛ tva lakṣaṇam asya aiśvaryam iti svapakṣaḥ upasaṃhṛtaḥ iti pūrvapakṣasya piṇḍa arthaḥ
translated: it is concluded that the self is not permanent, nor does it have lordship characterized by being the knower and the doer. This is the summary meaning of the prima facie view.

analyzed: atha grantha arthaḥ vyākhyāyate
translated: Now, the meaning of the text is explained.

analyzed: nanu sva lakṣaṇa ābhāsam jñānam ekam param punar
translated: But the cognition that appears as the specific characteristic is one, and again,

original: sābhilāpaṃ vikalpākhyaṃ bahudhā nāpi tad dvayam // / / //
analyzed: sa abhilāpam vikalpa ākhyam bahudhā nā api tat dvayam
translated: the one called conceptual, which is associated with verbal expression, is manifold, and that pair is not [the self].

analyzed: nityasya kasyacid draṣṭuḥ tasya atra anavabhāsataḥ
translated: Because no permanent seer is manifested here,

analyzed: ahaṃpratītiḥ api eṣā śarīra ādi avasāyinī
translated: this notion of I also ascertains the body and so on.

analyzed: nanu iti ākṣepe
translated: But is used for objection.

original: iha ātmā saṃvitsvabhāvaḥ sthiraḥ iti tāvadayuktam /
analyzed: iha ātmā saṃvid svabhāvaḥ sthiraḥ iti tāvat ayuktam
translated: Here, it is not proper to say that the self is permanent and has the nature of consciousness.

analyzed: sthirasya api sva prakāśasya aprakāśanāt
translated: Because even a permanent [self] does not illuminate itself.

original: tathā hi ghaṭaprakāśo ghaṭavikalpo ghaṭapratyabhijñā ghaṭasmṛtiḥ ghaṭotprekṣā ityādirūpeṇa jñānānyeva prakāśante bhinnakāntāni bhinnaviṣayāṇi
analyzed: tathā hi ghaṭa prakāśaḥ ghaṭa vikalpaḥ ghaṭa pratyabhijñā ghaṭa smṛtiḥ ghaṭa utprekṣā ityādi rūpeṇa jñānāni eva prakāśante bhinna kāntāni bhinna viṣayāṇi
translated: For thus, in the form of the cognition of the pot, the conception of the pot, the recognition of the pot, the memory of the pot, the imagination of the pot, and so on, the cognitions themselves appear as having different aspects, different objects,

analyzed: bhinna kārāṇi ca
translated: and different modes.

original: tatra nīlasya prakāśaḥ svalakṣaṇābhāsaṃ jñānam svam anyānanuyāyi svarūpasaṃkocabhāji /
analyzed: tatra nīlasya prakāśaḥ sva lakṣaṇa ābhāsam jñānam svam anya an anuyāyi svarūpa saṃkoca bhāji
translated: Among them, the manifestation of the blue is the cognition that appears as its own particular characteristic, which has its own contracted form not shared by others.

original: lakṣaṇam deśakālākārarūpaṃ yasya ābhāsaḥ prakāśanam antarmukhaṃ yasmin bahirmukhīnasvarūpadhāriṇi jñāne tat avikalpakam viṣayabhede 'pi ekajātīyam
analyzed: lakṣaṇam deśa kāla ākāra rūpam yasya ābhāsaḥ prakāśanam antarmukham yasmin bahis mukhīna sva rūpa dhāriṇi jñāne tat avikalpakam viṣaya bhede pi eka jātīyam
translated: That which has a characteristic in the form of space, time, and shape, whose appearance is the manifestation, which is turned inward, in the cognition that bears an outward form, that is non-conceptual. Even when the objects are different, it belongs to the same class.

analyzed: svarūpa vaicitrye pi kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no cause for diversity in form.

analyzed: vikalpe hi vaicitrya kāraṇam abhilāpaḥ
translated: For in conception, the cause of diversity is verbal expression.

analyzed: sa ca ata na asti
translated: And that does not exist here.

analyzed: na hi abhilāpaḥ nīlasya dharmaḥ
translated: For verbal expression is not a property of the blue.

analyzed: na ca cakṣuḥ grāhyaḥ
translated: Nor is it perceptible by the eye.

analyzed: tatas u sau prācyaḥ smartavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, it must be remembered from before.

analyzed: aprabuddhe ca saṃskāre na smṛtiḥ
translated: And when the impression is not awakened, there is no memory.

analyzed: tad prabodhaḥ ca vastu darśana utthitaḥ iti vastu darśana samaye bhilāpa smṛtiḥ na asti
translated: And the awakening of that arises from seeing the object. Thus, at the time of seeing the object, there is no memory of verbal expression.

analyzed: tatas param vikalpakam jñānam
translated: After that, there is the conceptual cognition.

original: sarvasya vikalpasya sākṣāt pāramparyeṇa vā nirvikalpakamūlatvāt /🔽param iti ca anyarūpaṃ sāmānyalakṣaṇaṃ tasya viṣayaḥ /
analyzed: sarvasya vikalpasya sākṣāt pāramparyeṇa vā nirvikalpaka mūla tvāt  param iti ca anya rūpam sāmānya lakṣaṇam tasya viṣayaḥ
translated: Because all conceptual cognition, directly or indirectly, has non-conceptual cognition as its root.🔽And 'after that' means the other form, the universal characteristic, is its object.

original: svalakṣaṇe 'tisaṃkocini vitatavikalpasādhyasya vrḍdhavyāvahārikasya /🔽aupadeśikasya vā saṃketasya kartum aśakyatvāt /
analyzed: sva lakṣaṇe ti saṃkocini vitata vikalpa sādhyasya vrḍdha vyāvahārikasya  aupadeśikasya vā saṃketasya kartum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because it is impossible to make the extensive conventional usage, which is accomplished by the extensive conceptual cognition, in the extremely restricted particular characteristic.

analyzed: kṛtasya api vaiyarthyāt
translated: Or to make the conventional usage taught by others, because even if made, it would be useless.

analyzed: tena hi an anuyāyinā na punar vyavahāraḥ
translated: Because the conventional usage is not again with that which does not follow.

analyzed: tat ca bahu bhedam
translated: And that is of many kinds.

original: yatastat abhilāpena saṃjalpātmanā śabdarūpeṇa saha vartate /
analyzed: yatas tat abhilāpena saṃjalpa ātmanā śabda rūpeṇa saha vartate
translated: Because it exists together with verbal expression, which has the nature of conversation and the form of sound.

analyzed: śabdanam ca idam iti  tat iti
translated: And this is the verbalization 'this'.🔽'That' means that.

analyzed: tat idam iti
translated: 'This is that' means that.

analyzed: bhavet idam iti
translated: 'This may be' means this.

original: idaṃ vā idam ityādi bahudhā bhidyate /
analyzed: idam vai idam ityādi bahudhā bhidyate
translated: 'This is this' and so on are divided in many ways.

original: tacca na viṣayapakṣo vartate /🔽api tu tasya vikalpasya svarūpameva vicitrokurvat pratibhāti iti vikalpo bahubhedaḥ /
analyzed: tat ca na viṣaya pakṣaḥ vartate  api tu tasya vikalpasya svarūpam eva vicitrokurvat pratibhāti iti vikalpaḥ bahu bhedaḥ
translated: And that does not exist on the side of the object.🔽But rather the form of that conceptual cognition itself appears as variegated. Thus conceptual cognition is of many kinds.

analyzed: evam anubhava vikalpa paramparā tāvat sva prakāśa tvena bhāti
translated: Thus the series of experience and conceptual cognition appears as self-luminous.

original: syādetat / yallagnāsau paramparā so'pi ābhāti iti / tatra /
analyzed: syāt etat yat lagnā asau paramparā sā upi ābhāti iti tatra
translated: It may be said: That which is this series, it also appears. Regarding that,

original: yato dvayamapi etad avikalpetararūpaṃ na anyasya kasyacit etadatiriktasya draṣṭuḥ anubhavituḥ saṃbandhi /
analyzed: yatas dvayam api etat avikalpa itara rūpam na anyasya kasyacid etad atiriktasya draṣṭuḥ anubhavituḥ saṃbandhi
translated: because both of these are not of the nature of conceptualization, they are not related to any other observer or experiencer apart from this.

analyzed: dṛśyasya tu bhavatu bāhya artha vāde
translated: But let it be for the doctrine of external objects.

analyzed: atra hetuḥ yatas tasya draṣṭuḥ
translated: Here the reason is: because of that observer.

analyzed: atas eva saṃvid svabhāva tā upagamāt sva prakāśa tā yogya tvāt āpanna upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāpteḥ
translated: For this very reason, because of accepting the nature of consciousness, because of being fit for the property of self-illumination, because of attaining the characteristic of being perceptible,

analyzed: atra etad bodha dvaya madhye na asti avabhāsaḥ
translated: in this pair of cognitions, there is no appearance.

original: nanu astyeva avabhāsaḥ iti asiddhā dṛśyānupalabdhiḥ /
analyzed: nanu asti eva avabhāsaḥ iti asiddhā dṛśya anupalabdhiḥ
translated: But surely, there is appearance. Thus, the non-apprehension of the visible is not established.🔽For thus, I know.

analyzed: tathā hi aham vedmi  niścinomi
translated: I ascertain.

original: smarāmi idam iti vidādiprakṛtyartharūpāt jñānasmṛtyādeḥ idam iti ca karmarūpāt viṣayāt atiriktameva aham iti anuyāyini prakāśe
analyzed: smarāmi idam iti vid ādi prakṛti artha rūpāt jñāna smṛti ādeḥ idam iti ca karma rūpāt viṣayāt atiriktam eva aham iti anuyāyini prakāśe
translated: I remember this. From the meaning of the root vid (to know) etc. in the form of knowledge, memory etc., and from the object in the form of this, the continuing light in the form of I appears.

analyzed: anuyāyi rūpam bhāti
translated: It shines in the form of a continuum.

analyzed: kaḥ evam āha bhāti iti
translated: Who says it shines?

analyzed: bhānam hi avikalpakam
translated: For shining is non-conceptual.

analyzed: aham iti śabda anuviddhaḥ vikalpa pratyayaḥ
translated: The conceptual cognition connected with the word I.

analyzed: nanu tathā api kim anena vikalpyate
translated: But even so, what is this [self] imagined to be?

analyzed: śarīra santānaḥ vā kṛśaḥ ūham ityādi pratyayāt
translated: Either the continuum of the body, because of the notion I am thin, etc.

analyzed: jñāna santānaḥ vā sukhī aham iti pratīteḥ
translated: Or the continuum of cognition, because of the notion I am happy.

analyzed: matvarthīyaḥ ca santānam eva spṛśati na atiriktam
translated: And the suffix matup touches the continuum itself, not something additional.

analyzed: tat etat uktam ahaṃpratītiḥ api śarīram
translated: This has been said: The notion of I also [touches] the body.

analyzed: ādi grahaṇāt jñānam
translated: By the word etc., [it touches] cognition.

analyzed: avasyati
translated: It necessarily [touches the continuum].

analyzed: saṃtāna rūpa tayā vikalpayati avaśyam
translated: It necessarily imagines [the self] in the form of a continuum.

analyzed: sadṛśa apara bhāva bheda grahaṇa sāmarthya vāsanā āviṣṭa tvāt iti
translated: Because it is imbued with the latent impressions capable of grasping the difference in the appearance of similar [moments].

analyzed: eṣā iti na asmābhiḥ nihnutā
translated: This [notion of I] is not denied by us.

analyzed: sa abhilāpam vikalpa ākhyam iti anena saṃgṛhīta tvāt
translated: Because it is included by [the statement] with verbal expression, called imagination.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati ahaṃpratītireva tāvat na ātmā /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati ahaṃpratītiḥ eva tāvat na ātmā
translated: This is what is meant: The notion of I is not the self.

analyzed: tasyāḥ api vikalpa rūpa tvāt asthairyāt ca
translated: Because that [notion] also has the form of imagination and is unstable.

analyzed: etad pratīti pratyayaḥ pi na asti anyaḥ śarīra ādeḥ
translated: And there is no other basis for that notion than the body, etc.

analyzed: bhavan api vā vedya pakṣa patitaḥ syāt iti
translated: Or even if it exists, it would fall to the side of the knowable.

original: tathāpi saṃvitsaṃvedyavyatiriktasya ātmano na siddhiḥ ityetat apiśabdena dyotitam /
analyzed: tathā api saṃvid saṃvedya vyatiriktasya ātmanaḥ na siddhiḥ iti etat apiśabdena dyotitam
translated: Nevertheless, by the word also, it is indicated that there is no establishment of a self separate from consciousness and the knowable.

original: evaṃ nāsti ātmā saṃvitsaṃvedyatryatirikto dṛśyasya tasyānupalabdheḥ iti // ////
analyzed: evam na asti ātmā saṃvid saṃvedya tri atiriktaḥ dṛśyasya tasya anupalabdheḥ iti
translated: Thus, there is no self apart from consciousness and the object of consciousness, because that [self] is not perceived.

analyzed: atra ātma vādi anumānam utthāpayati  atha anubhava vidhvaṃse smṛtiḥ tad anurodhinī
translated: Here, the proponent of the self presents an inference:🔽If there were no destruction of experience, how could memory conform to it?

analyzed: katham bhavet na nityaḥ syāt ātmā yadi anubhāvakaḥ
translated: The self would be permanent if it were the experiencer.

original: iha smṛtikāle susmūrṣito 'rtho bhavatu /🔽dhvaṃsatāṃ vā iti kintenaKSS / kimanena
analyzed: iha smṛti kāle susmūrṣitaḥ rthaḥ bhavatu  dhvaṃsatām vai iti kintenaks kim anena
translated: Here, let the object to be remembered exist at the time of memory.🔽Whether it is destroyed or not, what does that matter? What is the use of this?

analyzed: anubhavaḥ tāvat dhvastaḥ iti atra sarvasya avivādaḥ
translated: All agree that the experience is indeed destroyed.

analyzed: tam eva ca anurundhānā smṛtiḥ jāyate
translated: And memory arises conforming to that very [experience].

original: tathā hi smṛtau na arthasya prakāśaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi smṛtau na arthasya prakāśaḥ
translated: For in memory, there is no manifestation of the object.

original: na adhyavasāyaḥ /🔽nāpi anubhavasya arthasya ca aṅgulidvayavat /
analyzed: na adhyavasāyaḥ  na api anubhavasya arthasya ca aṅguli dvaya vat
translated: There is no ascertainment.🔽Nor is there [the manifestation] of the experience and the object, like two fingers [placed side by side].

analyzed: na api anubhava viśiṣṭasya arthasya daṇḍi vat
translated: Nor is there [the manifestation] of the object qualified by the experience, like a man with a stick.

analyzed: sarvatra ayam iti pratyaya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because in all cases, there would be the cognition this is that.

analyzed: kiṃtu anubhava prakāśaḥ eva smṛtau pradhānam
translated: But in memory, the manifestation of the experience itself is primary.

analyzed: anubhavasya tu artha prakāśa ātmaka tvāt anubhava prakāśa nāntarīyakaḥ rtha avabhāsaḥ iti
translated: And because the experience has the nature of manifesting the object, the appearance of the object is inseparable from the manifestation of the experience.

analyzed: sarvathā yadi anubhavaḥ dhvastaḥ
translated: If, in every way, experience is destroyed,

original: tadā tatprakāśarūpā kathaṃ smṛtistaddvāreṇa arthaviṣayā syāt /
analyzed: tadā tad prakāśa rūpā katham smṛtiḥ tad dvāreṇa artha viṣayā syāt
translated: then how can memory, which has the form of its manifestation, be about the object through that [experience]?

original: tayā ca sarvo vyavahāraḥ kriyamāṇo dṛṣṭaḥ ityasau svarūpeṇa anapahnavanīyā satī anubhavasya nāśe kiṃcit avinaṣṭam āvedayati /
analyzed: tayā ca sarvaḥ vyavahāraḥ kriyamāṇaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti asau sva rūpeṇa anapahnavanīyā satī anubhavasya nāśe kiṃcid avinaṣṭam āvedayati
translated: And it is seen that all activity is done by that [memory]. Thus, it must be accepted in its own form. When [experience] is destroyed, it conveys something that is not destroyed.

analyzed: tat eva ca anubhava kartṛ anubhavitṛ rūpam
translated: And that itself is the experiencer of experience, which has the form of the experiencer.

analyzed: ātmā anubhāvakaḥ nityaḥ iti
translated: The self, which is the experiencer, is eternal.

original: iyadeva ca ātmasiddherjīvitam /🔽tattu na adhikam ihaiva unmīlitam ācāryeṇa /
analyzed: iyat eva ca ātma siddheḥ jīvitam  tat tu na adhikam iha eva unmīlitam ācāryeṇa
translated: And this alone is the life of the proof of the existence of the self.🔽But that is not elaborated here by the teacher.

original: vaktavyaśeṣavivakṣayā pūrvapakṣo mā tāvat samāpat ityāśayena /
analyzed: vaktavya śeṣa vivakṣayā pūrvapakṣaḥ mā tāvat samāpad iti āśayena
translated: With the intention that the prima facie view should not be completed for the time being due to the desire to state what remains to be said.

analyzed: katham bhavet iti
translated: How could it be?

original: arhtastāvat tasyām akiṃcitkaraḥ /🔽anubhavaśca dhvastaḥ iti na kenacitprakāreṇa smṛtiḥ syāt /
analyzed: arhtaḥ tāvat tasyām a kiṃcitkaraḥ  anubhavaḥ ca dhvastaḥ iti na kenacid prakāreṇa smṛtiḥ syāt
translated: The object is of no use in that [memory].🔽And experience is destroyed. Thus, memory would not exist in any way.

original: tadabhāve ca saṃketaśabdasmṛtyāyattā api astaṅgatāḥ sarve vikalpāḥ /
analyzed: tad abhāve ca saṃketa śabda smṛti āyattāḥ api a staṅga tāḥ sarve vikalpāḥ
translated: And in the absence of that [experience], all conceptual thoughts, which depend on the memory of the convention and word, would also disappear.

original: nirvikalpaṃ ca andhabadhiramūkaprāyam iti hanta nirākrandam avasīdet viśvam iti ////
analyzed: nirvikalpam ca andha badhira mūka prāyam iti hanta nirākrandam avasīdet viśvam iti
translated: And [memory] would be without conceptual thought, like the blind, the deaf, and the mute. Alas! The world would be helpless and fall into despair.

original: iha kāryātirekeṇa tādṛk kalpanīyaṃ yat kāryasiddhaye paryāpnoti /
analyzed: iha kārya atirekeṇa tādṛś kalpanīyam yat kārya siddhaye paryāpnoti
translated: Here, something that is more than the effect should be imagined, which is sufficient for the accomplishment of the effect.

analyzed: na ca evam ātmā
translated: But the self is not like that.

analyzed: arthaḥ hi tāvat smaryate
translated: For an object is indeed remembered.

analyzed: sa ca anubhava prakāśa mukhena
translated: And that [object] through the medium of the experience-illumination.

analyzed: anubhavaḥ ca dhvastaḥ iti uktam
translated: And experience has ceased, it has been said.

analyzed: yadi ātmā kaścid asti kim tena
translated: If there is some self, what is the use of it?

original: etadapi hi vaktavyam ākāśamapi asti iti /
analyzed: etat api hi vaktavyam ākāśam api asti iti
translated: This too should be said: Space also exists.

original: atha ucyate na kevalena ātmanā etat siddhyati /
analyzed: atha ucyate na kevalena ātmanā etat siddhyati
translated: But if it is said that this is not accomplished by the self alone,

original: api tu anubhavasaṃskāro 'pi atra upayogī iti /
analyzed: api tu anubhava saṃskāraḥ api atra upayogī iti
translated: but that the impression of experience is also useful here,

analyzed: tarhi saḥ eva astu kim anena
translated: then let that alone be. What is the use of this [self]?

analyzed: tat etat darśayati
translated: This is shown by him [Dignāga]:

analyzed: satyā api ātmani dṛś nāśāt tad dvārā dṛṣṭa vastuṣu
translated: Even if the self exists, due to the destruction of the seer, in the objects seen through that [self],

analyzed: smṛtiḥ kena atha yatra evā anubhavaḥ tad padā eva sā
translated: memory is by what? Where there is experience, there is memory by that [self].

original: dṛṣṭeṣu anubhūteṣu vastuṣu yā smṛtiḥ tasyām anubhavo dṛgātmā dvāram arthāśasparśe /
analyzed: dṛṣṭeṣu anubhūteṣu vastuṣu yā smṛtiḥ tasyām anubhavaḥ dṛś ātmā dvāram artha āśa sparśe
translated: In the objects seen or experienced, the memory has as its medium the experience-self, the seer, in the contact with the object-taste.

analyzed: sa ca sati api ātmani naṣṭaḥ anubhavaḥ
translated: And that experience, even if the self exists, has ceased.

original: tasya hi anāśe idam ityeṣa eva atruṭitaḥ prakāśaḥ iti kā smṛtiḥ /
analyzed: tasya hi anāśe idam ityeṣa eva atruṭitaḥ prakāśaḥ iti kā smṛtiḥ
translated: For if that [experience] has not ceased, this very unbroken illumination of 'this' [object] would be here. What memory is there?

analyzed: tad anubhavitā kim smṛteḥ kuryāt iti
translated: What would the experiencer of that do for memory?

original: yatraiva viṣaye anubhavo vṛttaḥ tadeva tasyāḥ smṛteḥ padaṃ smaryamāṇam /
analyzed: yatra eva viṣaye anubhavaḥ vṛttaḥ tat eva tasyāḥ smṛteḥ padam smaryamāṇam
translated: The object on which the experience occurred is the basis of the memory that is remembered.

analyzed: tad padā iti bahuvrīhiḥ
translated: The bahuvrihi compound tatpadāḥ (having that as their basis).

analyzed: sā iti smṛtiḥ
translated: Sā refers to memory.

original: nanu jñānāntarasya viṣayeṇa kathaṃ tasyāḥ viṣayitvābhimānaḥ ityāśaṅkyāha
analyzed: nanu jñāna antarasya viṣayeṇa katham tasyāḥ viṣayi tva abhimānaḥ iti āśaṅkya āha
translated: How can the object of another cognition be regarded as the object of memory?

analyzed: yatas hi pūrva anubhava saṃskārāt smṛti saṃbhavaḥ
translated: Because memory arises from the impression of a previous experience.

analyzed: yadi evam antargaḍunā kaḥ ṛthaḥ syāt sthāyinā ātmanā
translated: If that is so, what is the use of an enduring self?

analyzed: anubhavena hi saṃskāraḥ janyate sva ucitaḥ
translated: For an impression is produced by an experience in accordance with itself.

analyzed: saṃskāraḥ ca prātana rūpām sthitim sthāpayati
translated: And the impression establishes the existence of the form of the past.

analyzed: ākṛṣṭa śākhā ādeḥ cira saṃvartitasya vivartyamānasya bhūrja ādeḥ
translated: Like a birch bark that has been rolled up for a long time and is being unrolled, with its branches and so on being drawn out.

original: tena atrāpi saṃskāraḥ tāṃ smṛtiṃ pūrvānubhavānukāriṇīṃ karoti iti tadviṣaya eva smṛterviṣayaḥ /
analyzed: tena atra api saṃskāraḥ tām smṛtim pūrva anubhava anukāriṇīm karoti iti tad viṣayaḥ eva smṛteḥ viṣayaḥ
translated: Therefore, here also the impression makes that memory resemble the previous experience. Thus the object of memory is only the object of the experience.

original: evaṃ tarhi antargaḍuḥ yathā āyāsāya param /
analyzed: evam tarhi antargaḍuḥ yathā āyāsāya param
translated: If that is so, then an enduring self is as useless as an internal organ.

original: tadvat ātmā sthiraḥ kalpanāyāsamātraphalaḥ iti kiṃ tena /
analyzed: tadvat ātmā sthiraḥ kalpanā āyāsa mātra phalaḥ iti kim tena
translated: Similarly, a permanent self is the fruit of mere conceptual effort. What is the use of it?

original: sarvaṃ hi saṃskāreṇa jagadvyavahārakuṭumbakaṃ kṛtakarāvalambam iti ////
analyzed: sarvam hi saṃskāreṇa jagat vyavahāra kuṭumbakam kṛta kara avalambam iti
translated: For the entire world of practical usage is supported by impressions.

analyzed: nanu tasmai eva saṃskārasya āśrayaḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: But the substratum of that impression should be stated.

analyzed: sa hi guṇa tvāt āśrayam apekṣate
translated: That, being a quality, requires a substratum.

original: ya āśrayaḥ sa ātmā syāt ityāśaṅkyāha
analyzed: yaḥ āśrayaḥ saḥ ātmā syāt iti āśaṅkya āha
translated: Fearing that the substratum would be the self, he says:

analyzed: tatas bhinneṣu dharmeṣu tad svarūpa aviśeṣataḥ
translated: From that, in the distinct dharmas, due to the non-distinction of its nature,

analyzed: saṃskārāt smṛiti siddhau syāt smartā draṣṭā iva kalpitaḥ
translated: If memory is established from impression, the experiencer would be imagined like the seer.

analyzed: iha saṃskāre jāyamāne
translated: Here, when the impression is produced,

analyzed: yadi ātmanaḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: if there is a distinction of the self,

original: sa tarhi avyatiriktaḥ iti na nityaḥ syāt /
analyzed: sa tarhi avyatiriktaḥ iti na nityaḥ syāt
translated: then it is not separate, so it would not be eternal.

analyzed: atha na kaścid asya viśeṣaḥ
translated: But if there is no distinction of it at all,

analyzed: tena tarhi kim
translated: then what is it?

analyzed: atha saṃskāra eva asya viśeṣaḥ
translated: But if the distinction of it is just the impression,

original: tarhi na vyatirikto 'sau iti punarapi anitye jñāne saṃskāraḥ ityāyātam /
analyzed: tarhi na sau iti punar api anitye jñāne saṃskāraḥ iti āyātam
translated: then it is not separate, so again it comes to the impression being in the non-eternal cognition.

original: anubhavādviśiṣṭaṃ viśiṣṭasmrṭyākhyakāryakāri jñānaṃ paramparayā jāyate iti iyāneva saṃskārārthaḥ /
analyzed: anubhavāt viśiṣṭam viśiṣṭa smrṭi ākhya kārya kāri jñānam paramparayā jāyate iti iyān eva saṃskāra arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of impression is just this: a cognition distinguished from experience, producing the effect called distinguished memory, is produced indirectly.

analyzed: atha saṃskāra ātmā vyatiriktaḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: But if the distinct distinction is the nature of the impression,

analyzed: tasya tarhi kim asau
translated: then what is that of it?

analyzed: saṃbandhaḥ ca vyatiriktaḥ nirākariṣyate
translated: And the distinct relation will be denied.

analyzed: evam jñāna sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatna dharma adharmāḥ api vikalpanīyāḥ
translated: Thus, knowledge, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, virtue, and vice should also be distinguished.

original: etadāha tataḥ iti ātmano bhinneṣu dharmeṣu aṅgīkriyamāṇeṣu teṣu satsvapi /
analyzed: etat āha tatas iti ātmanaḥ bhinneṣu dharmeṣu aṅgīkriyamāṇeṣu teṣu satsu api
translated: This is stated by the word tataḥ (from that). When the attributes are accepted as different from the self, even though they exist,

original: ātmanaḥ svarūpe viśeṣābhāvāt sa tāvat ātmā smrṭau na vyāpriyeta /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ svarūpe viśeṣa abhāvāt sa tāvat ātmā smrṭau na vyāpriyeta
translated: since there is no difference in the nature of the self, that self would not operate in memory.

analyzed: asmatṛ rūpa a saṃskṛta rūpa ādi prācya rūp
translated: Because of the non-deviation from the previous nature, such as the nature not modified by the form of the I and the mine.

original: anapāyāt / iti saṃskārādeva smṛteḥ siddhiḥ iti /
analyzed: anapāyāt iti saṃskārāt eva smṛteḥ siddhiḥ iti
translated: Thus, memory is established only through modification.

original: ahaṃ smarāmi iti yaḥ smartā so'pi śarīrasaṃtāno jñānasaṃtānaśca adhyāvasīyate /
analyzed: aham smarāmi iti yaḥ smartā saḥ api śarīra saṃtānaḥ jñāna saṃtānaḥ ca adhyāvasīyate
translated: The one who remembers, thinking I remember, is also understood to be the continuum of the body and the continuum of consciousness.

analyzed: yathā draṣṭā
translated: Just like the seer.

analyzed: pūrvam hi uktam
translated: For it was said earlier:

analyzed: ahaṃpratītiḥ api eṣā śarīra ādi avasāyinī
translated: This notion of 'I' is also based on the body and so on.

original: iti / evam ātmani sādhakaṃ pramāṇaṃ pratyakṣamanumānaṃ ca parākṛtam /
analyzed: iti evam ātmani sādhakam pramāṇam pratyakṣam anumānam ca parākṛtam
translated: Thus, perception and inference, which are the means of valid knowledge establishing the self, have been refuted.

analyzed: bādhakam ca sūcitam dharmayoge nityatā hāni
translated: And the refuting [argument] has been indicated: if the self were connected with attributes, its eternality would be lost.

analyzed: anyathā kim tena tat uktam
translated: Otherwise, what is the use of it? That has been stated:

analyzed: carma upamaḥ ced saḥ nityaḥ svatukyaḥ ced asat samaḥ
translated: If it is like skin, it is non-eternal. If it is the possessor of its own, it is like a non-existent.

analyzed: varṣa ātapābhyām kim vyomnaḥ carmaṇi asti hi tat phalam
translated: What is the effect of rain and heat on the sky? It is present in the skin.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: ittham ātmānam nirākṛtya
translated: Having thus refuted the self,

analyzed: tasya aiśvaryam api nirākartum jñānaśaktim eva parīkṣitum āha
translated: in order to refute its lordship, he says this to examine the power of knowledge itself:

original: jñānaṃ ca citsvarūpaṃ cet tad anityaṃ kimātmavat /
analyzed: jñānam ca cit svarūpam ced tat anityam kim ātma vat
translated: And if knowledge is of the nature of consciousness, is it impermanent like the self?

analyzed: athā api jaḍam etasya katham artha prakāśa tā
translated: Or even if it is inert, how can it illuminate objects?

original: parābhyupagamena prasaṅgāpādanam etat pūrvapakṣavādī karoti prasaṅgaviparyayalābho me bhaviṣyati iti /
analyzed: para abhyupagamena prasaṅga āpādanam etat pūrvapakṣa vādī karoti prasaṅga viparyaya lābhaḥ me bhaviṣyati iti
translated: The proponent of the prima facie view raises this reductio argument by accepting the opponent's position, thinking that he will gain the opposite of the reductio.

original: tatra ātmavādī nityatvam ātmana itthaṃ brūte iha kālo nāma idaṃbhāvaviśiṣṭasya viśeṣaṇatām avalambamānaḥ taṃ viśiṣṭīkurvan tatsaṃkocāt 🔽anityaṃ saṃpādayati /
analyzed: tatra ātma vādī nitya tvam ātmanaḥ ittham brūte iha kālaḥ nāma idaṃbhāva viśiṣṭasya viśeṣaṇa tām avalambamānaḥ tam viśiṣṭīkurvan tad saṃkocāt  / anityam saṃpādayati
translated: There, the proponent of the self states the permanence of the self in this way: Here, time, relying on the relation of qualifier and qualified of the state of being this, qualifying it, makes it impermanent by its own contraction.

original: ātmanaśca citsvabhāvatvāt idam iti prathanābhāvena viśeṣyatvaṃ nāsti /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ ca cit svabhāva tvāt idam iti prathana abhāvena viśeṣya tvam na asti
translated: And the self, being of the nature of consciousness, does not have the relation of qualified and qualifier due to the absence of the manifestation as this.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ hi yojaka āyattaḥ
translated: For the relation of qualifier and qualified depends on the connector.

analyzed: na ca sva prakāśe yojaka antaram asti
translated: And there is no other connector in self-luminous consciousness.

original: sa itthaṃ bruvāṇaḥ paryanuyujyate jñānamapi tarhi svaprakāśam iti tatrāpi eṣaiva vārtā iti tadapi kasmāt na nityam /
analyzed: saḥ ittham bruvāṇaḥ paryanuyujyate  jñānam api tarhi sva prakāśam iti tatra api eṣā eva vārtā iti tat api kasmāt na nityam
translated: When he says this, he is questioned: But then knowledge also is self-luminous. There too, this is the same story. So why is that also not eternal?

analyzed: na ca dvayoḥ nityayoḥ kaścid saṃbandhaḥ
translated: And there is no connection between two eternal things.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ hi asau na anyaḥ
translated: For that is either the relation of cause and effect or something else.

original: tata ātmano jñānaṃ śaktiḥ iti avasannam adaḥ /
analyzed: tatas ātmanaḥ jñānam śaktiḥ iti avasannam adaḥ
translated: Therefore, the idea that knowledge is the power of the self is defeated.

original: atha na svaprakāśaṃ jñānaṃ tarhi parasyāpi ado na prakāśaḥ /
analyzed: atha na sva prakāśam jñānam tarhi parasya api adaḥ na prakāśaḥ
translated: But if knowledge is not self-luminous, then the object is not illuminated even by another.

original: svaprakāśarūpāveśanaṃ hi asau parasya vidadhat bodhaḥ prakāśo bhavati parasyāpi /🔽tataḥ svaprakāśatāśūnyo na asau arthasya prakāśaḥ syāt /
analyzed: sva prakāśa rūpa āveśanam hi asau parasya vidadhat bodhaḥ prakāśaḥ bhavati parasya api  tatas sva prakāśa tā śūnyaḥ na asau arthasya prakāśaḥ syāt
translated: For that which, illuminating the form of another as self-luminous, becomes the illumination of the object,

analyzed: bhāva antara vat
translated: therefore, that illumination of the object would be devoid of self-luminosity, like another entity.

original: jaḍo'pyasau ittham arthasya prakāśo bhaviṣyati iti sāṃkhyamatam āśaṅkate
analyzed: jaḍaḥ api asau ittham arthasya prakāśaḥ bhaviṣyati iti sāṃkhya matam āśaṅkate
translated: The Sāṃkhya view is suspected that even this inert one will become the illumination of the object in this way:

analyzed: atha arthasya yathā rūpam dhatte buddhiḥ tathā ātmanaḥ
translated: Or just as the intellect assumes the form of the object, so does the self.

analyzed: caitanyam  iha tāvat artham jānāmi iti asti vyavahāraḥ

original: tatra arthasya prakāśaḥ ityetāvāneva paramārthaḥ /🔽tat na arthasya svaṃ rūpam /🔽sarvaṃ prati tathātvaprasaṅgāt /🔽na kaṃcitprati vā iti sarvajñam ajñaṃ vā jagat syāt /🔽nāpi arthe anyata etadrūpam upanipatitam /🔽eṣa eva hi doṣaḥ syāt /🔽tat nūnam anyatraiva ayaṃ dharmaḥ tattvāntare /🔽tatrāpi katham arthasya prakāśaḥ syāt iti nūnaṃ tatra tattvāntare so'rthaḥ pratibimbatvena upasaṃkrāmati /🔽tat tattvāntaraṃ sattvaprādhānyāt pratibimbagrahayogyaṃ tamasā''cchāditatvāt sakalapratibimbanato vyāvartitam /
analyzed: tatra arthasya prakāśaḥ iti etāvān eva paramārthaḥ 🔽tat na arthasya svam rūpam 🔽sarvam prati tathātva prasaṅgāt 🔽na kaṃcid prati vai iti sarva jñam ajñam vā jagat syāt 🔽na api arthe anyatas etad rūpam upanipatitam 🔽eṣaḥ eva hi doṣaḥ syāt 🔽tat nūnam anyatra eva ayam dharmaḥ tattva antare 🔽tatra api katham arthasya prakāśaḥ syāt iti nūnam tatra tattva antare saḥ ṛthaḥ pratibimba tvena upasaṃkrāmati 🔽tat tattva antaram sattva prādhānyāt pratibimba graha yogyam tamasā ācchādita tvāt sakala pratibimbanataḥ vyāvartitam

original: bhāge rajasā tamaso'pasāraṇāt kiṃcideva pratibimbakaṃ gṛhyāti /
analyzed: bhāge rajasā tamasā upasāraṇāt kiṃcid eva pratibimbakam
translated: In the part of rajas, by removing tamas, it grasps only a slight reflection.

analyzed: tat eva buddhi tattvam ucyate
translated: That itself is called the principle of intellect.

analyzed: artha pratibimba grahaḥ ca jñānam asya vṛtti rūpam pūrva vyapadeśa tirodhāyaka dadhi ādi pariṇāma vilakṣaṇa pariṇati viśeṣa ātmakam
translated: And the grasping of the reflection of an object is its function in the form of knowledge, which is of the nature of a special transformation unlike the transformation of curd etc. that obstructs the previous designation.

original: evam arthasya tāvat rūpaṃ buddhiḥ dhārayati /
analyzed: evam arthasya tāvat rūpam buddhiḥ dhārayati
translated: Thus, the intellect holds the form of the object.

original: iyaśca sattvādīnāṃ sukhaduḥkhamoharūpatayāṃ bhogyatvāt jaḍam iti darpakṣavat aprakāśam /
analyzed: iyaḥ ca sattva ādīnām sukha duḥkha moha rūpa tayām bhogya tvāt jaḍam iti darpakṣa vat aprakāśam
translated: And this is inert, like a mirror, because it is to be enjoyed in the form of pleasure, pain, and delusion of beings, and is not luminous.

original: na ca bhogyasya aprakāśasya tadviruddhabhoktṛtārūpaprakāśātmakasvabhāvasaṃbhavo yuktyanupātī iti tadvilakṣaṇena bhoktrā bhavitavyam /
analyzed: na ca bhogyasya aprakāśasya tad viruddha bhoktṛ tā rūpa prakāśa ātmaka svabhāva saṃbhavaḥ yukti anupātī iti tad vilakṣaṇena bhoktrā bhavitavyam
translated: And it is not logical for an object to be enjoyed, which is not luminous, to have a nature that is contradictory to the luminous nature of the enjoyer. Therefore, there must be an enjoyer that is different from that.

analyzed: sa ca prakāśaḥ iti etāvat svabhāvaḥ
translated: And that is of the nature of mere light.

original: svabhāvāntaraṃ hi aprakāśarūpaṃ bhogyaṃ kathaṃ bhoktuḥ svabhāvatayā saṃbhāvyeta /
analyzed: svabhāva antaram hi a prakāśa rūpam bhogyam katham bhoktuḥ svabhāva tayā saṃbhāvyeta
translated: For how can a nature that is not luminous, which is different from the nature of light, be conceived as the nature of the enjoyer?

original: sa ca prakāśamātrasvabhāvatvenaiva yadi viśvasya prakāśaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca prakāśa mātra svabhāva tvena eva yadi viśvasya prakāśaḥ
translated: And if that light is the illumination of the universe merely by being of the nature of light,

analyzed: tarhi yugapad eva prakāśeta
translated: then it would be illuminated simultaneously.

original: ghaṭaprakāśo'pi paṭaprakāśaḥ syāt iti viśvaṃ saṃkīryeta /
analyzed: ghaṭa prakāśaḥ api paṭa prakāśaḥ syāt iti viśvam saṃkīryeta
translated: The light of a pot would also be the light of a cloth, and the entire universe would be mixed up.

original: sa ca arthāt arthapratibimbāt tadādhārācca buddhitattvāt anyaḥ katham arthasya prakāśaḥ syāt /
analyzed: sa ca arthāt artha pratibimbāt tad ādhārāt ca buddhi tattvāt anyaḥ katham arthasya prakāśaḥ syāt
translated: And how could that light of the object be other than the object-reflection and the intellect principle which is its substratum?

analyzed: asaṃbandhāt  tasmāt buddhiḥ eva svaccha tvāt prakāśa pratibimbam api gṛhṇāti
translated: Because of lack of connection.🔽Therefore, the intellect itself, due to its clarity, grasps the reflection of light.

analyzed: tatas prakāśa pratibimba parigraha mahima upanata prakāśa āveśa buddhi tattva āveśita pratibimbaka nīla ādi artha paryanta saṃkrānteḥ prakāśa āveśasya arthaḥ prakāśate  /
translated: Then, due to the greatness of the intellect principle's power to grasp the reflection of light, the light enters the reflection projected into the object such as blue, etc., which is connected to the end of the object. Thus, the light enters. The object appears.

analyzed: iti siddhaḥ vyavahāraḥ
translated: Thus, the conventional usage is established.

original: tadevaṃ jñānaṃ jaḍabuddhitattvāvyatirekāt jaḍamapi citpratibimbayogāt viṣayasya prakāśaḥ iti /
analyzed: tat evam jñānam jaḍa buddhi tattva avyatirekāt jaḍam api cit pratibimba yogāt viṣayasya prakāśaḥ iti
translated: Thus, knowledge, being non-different from the inert intellect principle, is inert. But due to the union with the reflection of consciousness, there is the appearance of the object.

original: etadeva tāvat anucitam yat prakāśātmā pumān buddhau pratibimbam arpayati /
analyzed: etat eva tāvat anucitam yat prakāśa ātmā pumān buddhau pratibimbam arpayati
translated: This much alone is improper - that the person, whose nature is light, projects a reflection into the intellect.

analyzed: samāna guṇe bimbaka apekṣayā ca vimale pratibimba saṃkrānti darśanāt
translated: Because a reflection is seen to be transferred in a clear mirror, in relation to the original object having similar qualities.

analyzed: rūpavati ādarśe ghaṭa rūpa pratibimba vat
translated: Like the reflection of the form of a pot in a reflecting surface having form.

analyzed: ātma buddhyoḥ ca ati vailakṣaṇyam
translated: And there is a great difference between the self and the intellect.

original: ātmāpekṣayā ca na buddhirvimalā tat bahvatu tāvat etat iti atha śabdena sūcayati /
analyzed: ātma apekṣayā ca na buddhiḥ vimalā tat bahu atu tāvat etat iti atha śabdena sūcayati
translated: And in relation to the self, the intellect is not clear. He indicates this with the word 'athā' (now).

original: kiṃtu pratibimbavādenāpi na kiṃcit pratisamāhitaṃ bhavet iti darśayati 🔽ajaḍā saivaṃ jāḍye nārthaprakāsatā // / / //
analyzed: kiṃtu pratibimba vādena api na kiṃcid pratisamāhitam bhavet iti darśayati  ajaḍā sā evam jāḍye na artha prakāsa tā
translated: But he shows that even with the doctrine of reflection, nothing would be accomplished.🔽That [reflection] is not inert, otherwise there would be no manifestation of the object.

original: caitanyapratibimbayoge yadi tāvat tatpratibimbakamapi mukhyaṃ prakāśarūpameva na bhavati /
analyzed: caitanya pratibimba yoge yadi tāvat tat pratibimbakam api mukhyam prakāśa rūpam eva na bhavati
translated: If, in the case of the union of the reflection with consciousness, that reflection also is not primarily of the nature of light,

analyzed: tena api na kiṃcid kṛtam syāt
translated: then nothing would be done by it.

original: na hi pratibimbatavahnipuñja ādarśo dāhyaṃ dahet /🔽atha mukhyaprakāśarūpameva tatpratibimbakam /
analyzed: na hi ādarśaḥ dāhyam dahet  atha mukhya prakāśa rūpam eva tat pratibimbakam
translated: For the mirror, which is a reflection of a mass of fire, would not burn what is to be burned.🔽But if that reflection is of the nature of the primary light,

original: tat tarhi buddheravyatiriktam iti mukhyaprakāśarūpaiva buddhirjātā iti /
analyzed: tat tarhi buddheḥ avyatiriktam iti mukhya prakāśa rūpā eva buddhiḥ jātā iti
translated: then it is not separate from the intellect. Thus the intellect itself becomes of the nature of the primary light.

analyzed: yatas viruddha dharma adhyāsāt bhīrubhiḥ etat kalpitam
translated: Because of the superimposition of contradictory properties, this is imagined by the timid.

original: sa eva punaḥ jājvalyamānaṃ nijam ojo jṛmbhayati /
analyzed: saḥ eva punar jājvalyamānam nijam ojaḥ jṛmbhayati
translated: He again displays his own blazing splendor.

analyzed: tatas ca sā buddhiḥ eva cit mayī syāt
translated: And therefore that intellect itself would be full of consciousness.

analyzed: kim puruṣeṇa
translated: What is the use of the self?

original: evam arthapratibimbakadvāreṇa arthamayī ityapi āyāto vijñānavādaḥ /
analyzed: evam artha pratibimbaka dvāreṇa artha mayī iti api āyātaḥ vijñāna vādaḥ
translated: Thus, through the medium of the reflection of the object, the doctrine of consciousness-only is also established as the doctrine of the cognition of the object.

analyzed: kutas etasyāḥ tad rūpa tvam iti
translated: How is it that this [reflection] has that form?

analyzed: pūrva kāraṇa paramparātaḥ iti vācyam
translated: The answer should be given: From the preceding series of causes.

analyzed: evam sā eva ced cit rūpā
translated: If it is the same [reflection] that has the nature of consciousness,
then the consequence of eternality as before [applies].

analyzed: na ceta cit rūpasya api nitya tā
translated: If it does not have the nature of consciousness, then [consciousness] is not eternal.

analyzed: tarhi ātmā na nityaḥ kaścid asti
translated: Then there is no eternal self at all.

original: yasya jñānaṃ nāma śaktiḥ syāt iti jñānamātrameva asti /
analyzed: yasya jñānam nāma śaktiḥ syāt iti jñāna mātram eva asti
translated: For whom would there be the power called knowledge? Thus there is only knowledge.

original: yo 'rthaprakāśarūpo bodho yaśca vikalpasmṛtyādirūpaḥ tāvatā arthavyavahārasiddheḥ iti prasaṅgaviparyayalābhaḥ jñānaṃ ca citsvarūpaṃ cet
analyzed: yaḥ ṛtha prakāśa rūpaḥ bodhaḥ yaḥ ca vikalpa smṛti ādi rūpaḥ tāvatā artha vyavahāra siddheḥ iti prasaṅga viparyaya lābhaḥ jñānam ca cit svarūpam ced
translated: That cognition which has the form of the manifestation of an object, and that which has the form of conceptual thought, memory, etc., by that alone the functioning of the object is accomplished. Thus the consequence and its reversal are obtained. If knowledge and consciousness have the same nature,

analyzed: ityādeḥ śloka dvayasya tātparyam
translated: this is the purport of the two verses beginning with this [verse].

analyzed: evam jñānam parīkṣya kriyām parīkṣate
translated: Having examined knowledge in this way, he examines action:

analyzed: kriyā api arthasya kāya ādeḥ tad tad deśa ādi jāta tā
translated: Action is also the arising of the body and so on in different places and so forth.

analyzed: na anya adṛṣṭeḥ
translated: It is not different from what is seen.

analyzed: iha parispanda rūpam tāvat
translated: Here, the form of motion is indeed going.

analyzed: calati
translated: It moves.

analyzed: patati ityādi yat pratibhāsa gocaram
translated: What is meant by falls and so on is the domain of appearances.

original: tatra gṛhaseśagatadevadattasvarūpāt anantaraṃ bāhyadeśavartidevadattasvarūpam ityetāvat upalabhyate /
analyzed: tatra gṛhaseśa gata devadatta svarūpāt anantaram bāhya deśa varti devadatta svarūpam iti etāvat upalabhyate
translated: There, only the form of Devadatta in the house and the form of Devadatta in the external place are perceived,

original: na tu tatsvarūpātiriktāṃ kāṃcit anyāṃ kriyāṃ pratīmaḥ /
analyzed: na tu tad svarūpa atiriktām kāṃcid anyām kriyām pratīmaḥ
translated: but we do not perceive any other action apart from that form.

original: devadatto dinaṃ tiṣṭhati ityatra tu prabhātakālāviṣṭadevadattasvarūpaṃ tataḥ praharakālāliṅgitatatsvarūpam ityādi bhāti /
analyzed: devadattaḥ dinam tiṣṭhati iti atra tu prabhāta kāla āviṣṭa devadatta svarūpam tatas prahara kāla āliṅgita tad svarūpam ityādi bhāti
translated: But in Devadatta stands for a day, the form of Devadatta possessed by the morning time and the form of him possessed by the afternoon time, etc. appear.

original: dugdhaṃ pariṇamate ityatra madhuravasturūpam amlavasturūpam dravarūpaṃ kaṭhinarūpam ityādi /
analyzed: dugdham pariṇamate iti atra madhura vastu rūpam amla vastu rūpam drava rūpam kaṭhina rūpam ityādi
translated: In milk turns, the form of a sweet substance, the form of an acidic substance, the liquid form, the solid form, etc. [appear].

original: evaṃ sādṛśyācca tatra pratyabhijñā bhinne'pi kāyakeśanasvādāviva /
analyzed: evam sādṛśyāt ca tatra pratyabhijñā bhinne pi kāya keśana sva ādau iva
translated: Thus, recognition occurs there due to similarity, even in a different body, like in the hair and nails of Devadatta.
But when there is difference in place and form, difference in time is necessarily present. Even when there is difference in place and time,

analyzed: svarūpasya eva deśa tvāt  kāla bhede ca svarūpa bhedāt
translated: because the very form is the place.🔽And when there is difference in time, there is difference in form.

analyzed: deśa kāla ākārāḥ ākāre eva yadi api
translated: Although the forms of place, time, and form are included in the form itself,

original: tathāpi sthūladṛṣṭyā asti bhedaḥ iti te hi bhedena bauddhairucyante iti tātparyam /
analyzed: tathā api sthūla dṛṣṭyāḥ asti bhedaḥ iti te hi bhedena bauddhaiḥ ucyante iti tātparyam
translated: Still, from a gross point of view, there is a difference. The meaning is that they are indeed spoken of as different by the Buddhists.

original: evaṃ pratyakṣeṇa na dṛśyate kacit kriyā /
analyzed: evam pratyakṣeṇa na dṛśyate kacid kriyā
translated: Thus, no action is seen anywhere by perception.

analyzed: tad bhāvāt na tad pūrvakeṇa anumānena
translated: And because of its non-existence, not even by inference based on it.

original: kāryaṃ ca prāmaprāptyādyuttarakṣaṇarūpaṃ taddeśavasturūpādi iti kāryānyathānupapattyāpi na sā kalpyā /
analyzed: kāryam ca tad deśa vastu rūpa ādi iti kārya anyathā anupapattyā api na sā kalpyā
translated: And the effect, in the form of the subsequent moment, such as the attainment of the object, the form of the object in that place, etc., cannot be imagined even by the non-apprehension of the effect.

original: evaṃ pratyakṣānumānābhyāṃ tasyā adṛṣṭiḥ iti sādhakapramāṇābhāva uktaḥ /
analyzed: evam pratyakṣa anumānābhyām tasyāḥ adṛṣṭiḥ iti sādhaka pramāṇa abhāvaḥ uktaḥ
translated: Thus, the non-perception of that by perception and inference is stated as the absence of a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: bādhakam api āha
translated: He also states the refutation:

analyzed: na sā api ekā kramikā ekasya ca ucitā
translated: That is also not one, nor is it proper for a sequential entity.

analyzed: tatra pūrva apara rūpa tā kṣaṇānām vikalpa budvyā anusaṃdhānāt
translated: There, the prior and posterior nature of the moments is due to the connection by the conceptual mind.

original: na tu svātmani kiṃcit pūrvam aparaṃ vā /
analyzed: na tu sva ātmani kiṃcid pūrvam aparam vā
translated: But there is nothing prior or posterior in its own nature.

analyzed: vastu mātram hi tat
translated: For that is merely an entity.

original: ato vikalpaprāṇitaṃ pūrvāparībhūtatvaṃ kramarūpatā kriyāyāḥ kiṃcit kṣaṇaṃ na vastu spṛśati /
analyzed: atas vikalpa prāṇitam pūrvāparībhūta tvam krama rūpa tā kriyāyāḥ kiṃcid kṣaṇam na vastu spṛśati
translated: Therefore, the prior and posterior nature, which is the form of sequence of action, is animated by the conceptual mind. It does not touch any entity in a moment.

original: te hi kṣaṇā na anyonyasvarūpāviṣṭāḥ iti katham ekā kriyā /
analyzed: te hi kṣaṇāḥ na anyonya sva rūpa āviṣṭāḥ iti katham ekā kriyā
translated: For those moments are not mutually pervaded by their own nature. So how can there be one action?

original: kramo hi bhedena vyāptaḥ abhiśne tadabhāvāt /🔽bhedasya viruddham ekyam iti kathaṃ kramikā ekā ca iti syāt /
analyzed: kramaḥ hi bhedena vyāptaḥ abhiśne tad abhāvāt  bhedasya viruddham ekyam iti katham kramikā ekā ca iti syāt
translated: For sequence is pervaded by difference, and that is absent in the non-different.🔽And oneness is contradictory to difference. So how could there be sequence and oneness?

analyzed: atha ekatra āśraya ivasthānāt ekā
translated: If it is said that it is one because it exists in one substratum,

analyzed: tatra api tad kṣaṇa atiriktaḥ na kaścid āśrayaḥ anubhūyate
translated: even there, no substratum other than that moment is experienced.

analyzed: kṣaṇāḥ eva hi prabandha vṛttayaḥ bhānti
translated: For the moments themselves appear as a continuum.

original: kiṃ ca tathābhūtairbhinnadeśakālākāraiḥ kriyākṣaṇairāviṣṭa āśrayaḥ kathamekaḥ syāt /
analyzed: kim ca tathābhūtaiḥ bhinna deśa kāla ākāraiḥ kriyā kṣaṇaiḥ āviṣṭaḥ āśrayaḥ katham ekaḥ syāt
translated: Moreover, how could the substratum pervaded by the moments of action with different places and times be one?

analyzed: atas eva devadatta uyam
translated: For the same reason, this is Devadatta.

original: sa eva grāmaṃ prāptaḥ iti sādṛśyāt bhavantī pratyabhijñā na aikyaṃ vāstavaṃ gamayitumalam ////
analyzed: saḥ eva grāmam prāptaḥ iti sādṛśyāt bhavantī pratyabhijñā na aikyam vāstavam gamayitum alam
translated: He himself reached the village - this recognition arising from similarity is not capable of conveying real oneness.

analyzed: evam jñānam kriyām ca parīkṣya
translated: Having thus examined knowledge and action,

analyzed: yasmin sati te saṃbaddhe sarvajña tva sarva kartṛ tā rūpa aiśvarya prasādhanāya prabhavataḥ
translated: the relation which, when present, can connect them for the purpose of establishing the lordship characterized by omniscience and omnipotence,

original: taṃ saṃbandhaṃ dhvaṃsayituṃ tadviṣayaṃ pramāṇābhāvaṃ tāvadāha
analyzed: tam saṃbandham dhvaṃsayitum tad viṣayam pramāṇa abhāvam tāvat āha
translated: in order to destroy that relation, he first states the absence of any means of valid knowledge regarding it:

analyzed: tatra tatra sthite tat tat bhavati iti eva dṛśyate
translated: It is only seen that when this exists in that place, that exists there.

analyzed: na anyat na anyaḥ asti saṃbandhaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāvataḥ
translated: There is no other relation than that of cause and effect.

analyzed: mṛd piṇḍe sati stūpakaḥ
translated: When there is a lump of clay, there is a pot.

original: tatra sati śiviko yāvat ghaṭaḥ ityevaṃ bhāvakṣaṇā eva upalabhyante /
analyzed: tatra sati śivikaḥ yāvat ghaṭaḥ iti evam bhāva kṣaṇāḥ eva upalabhyante
translated: When that exists, there is a wheel, and so on up to a pot. Thus only momentary entities are perceived.

analyzed: na adhikam kiṃcid pratyakṣeṇa avabhāsate
translated: Nothing more appears to perception.

analyzed: nā api anumānena iti kriyāyām iva vācyam
translated: Nor to inference. Therefore, it should be said that it is like in the case of an action.

original: sarvatra ādhārādheyabhāvādau ayameva panthāḥ pṛthagrūpakuṇḍavadarakṣaṇānantaraṃ nirantarātmakaviśiṣṭakuṇḍavadarodayaḥ iti /
analyzed: sarvatra ādhāra ādheya bhāva ādau ayam eva panthāḥ pṛthak rūpa kuṇḍa vat arakṣaṇa anantaram nirantara ātmaka viśiṣṭa kuṇḍa vat ara udayaḥ iti
translated: In all cases, such as the relation of container and contained, this is the same path: the appearance of a specific pot and fruit with a continuous nature after the momentary appearance of the pot and fruit with separate forms.

original: ayameva ca bhāvo bhāvāntareṇa saha niyatapūrvāparatayā vikalpena vyavahiyamāṇaḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ iti abhidhīyate /
analyzed: ayam eva ca bhāvaḥ bhāva antareṇa saha niyata pūrva apara tayā vikalpena vyavahiyamāṇaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: And this very entity, when designated by the conceptual mind as having a definite sequence of prior and posterior with another entity, is called the relation of cause and effect.

original: na ca jñānakriyābhyāṃ saha ātmanaḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ ātmanastatkāryatvābhāvāt /
analyzed: na ca jñāna kriyābhyām saha ātmanaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ ātmanaḥ tad kārya tva abhāvāt
translated: And the self does not have the relation of cause and effect with the action of cognition, because the self is not the effect of that.

analyzed: jñānasya ca sva sāmagraḥ kārya tvāt
translated: And because cognition is the effect of its own assemblage of causes,

original: kriyāyāśca abhāvāt iti na jñānakriyāsaṃbandho yato jñātṛtvakartṛtve syātām ////
analyzed: kriyāyāḥ ca abhāvāt iti na jñāna kriyā saṃbandhaḥ yatas jñātṛ tva kartṛ tve syātām
translated: and because action does not exist, therefore the self cannot be the knower or the agent, since it does not have the relation of cognition and action.

analyzed: evam pramāṇam parākṛtya
translated: Having thus refuted the means of valid knowledge,

analyzed: saṃbandhe bādhakam sāmānya viśeṣa mukhena nirūpayati
translated: The objection to the relation is stated in general and particular terms:

analyzed: dviṣṭhasya aneka rūpa tvāt siddhasya anya anapekṣaṇāt
translated: Because what is related to two things cannot have many forms, and because what is established does not depend on another,

analyzed: pāratantrya ādi ayogāt ca tena kartā api kalpitaḥ
translated: and because there cannot be dependence, etc., therefore the agent is also imagined.

original: saṃbandhastāvat parasparaprāptirūpo dvayoḥ prāptibhājorekastiṣṭhati iti sāmānyalakṣaṇam /
analyzed: saṃbandhaḥ tāvat paraspara prāpti rūpaḥ dvayoḥ prāpti bhājoḥ ekaḥ tiṣṭhati iti sāmānya lakṣaṇam
translated: The general definition of relation is that it is the mutual attainment of two things that are to be attained, and it exists as one.

analyzed: tat ca katham
translated: And how is that?

original: na hi ekatra viśramitāśeṣaśarīrasāro'nyatra viśramitum alam svarūpabhedaprasaṅgāt /🔽etena saṃyogasamavāyau tanmūlāśca anye'pi saṃbandhā bādhavidhurāṃ dhuram adhyāropitā mantavyāḥ /
analyzed: na hi ekatra viśramita aśeṣa śarīra sāraḥ nyatra viśramitum alam sva rūpa bheda prasaṅgāt  etena saṃyoga samavāyau tad mūlāḥ ca anye api saṃbandhāḥ bādha vidhurām dhuram adhyāropitāḥ mantavyāḥ
translated: For what has exhausted its entire essence in one thing cannot rest in another, because it would lead to the difference of its own nature.🔽By this, conjunction, inherence, and other relations based on them should be understood to have been imposed with the burden of contradiction.

original: yo'pi cetaneṣu tatkalpanayā ca acetaneṣu pāratantryātmā saṃbandho vyavahiyate /
analyzed: yaḥ api cetaneṣu tad kalpanayā ca acetaneṣu pāratantrya ātmā saṃbandhaḥ vyavahiyate
translated: And that relation which is characterized by dependence is also used in the case of conscious beings by imagining it, and in the case of unconscious things by dependence.

original: tatra siddhasya na pāratantryam asti siddhatvādeva /
analyzed: tatra siddhasya na pāratantryam asti siddha tvāt eva
translated: There, what is established does not have dependence, because of being established itself.

analyzed: asiddhasya natarām niḥsvarūpasya tāddharmya ayogāt
translated: What is not established, even less so, because it lacks its own nature, due to the incompatibility of having that property.

original: evamapekṣāyāmapi vācyam /🔽dve ca rūpe kathaṃ śliṣyataḥ /
analyzed: evam apekṣāyām api vācyam  dve ca rūpe katham śliṣyataḥ
translated: The same should be said in the case of expectation.🔽And how can two forms be connected?

analyzed: dvayoḥ eka tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the identity of two things is not possible.

original: ekatve vā kaḥ śleṣaḥ /🔽tasmāt jñānasaṃbandhāt jñātā iti yathā vikalpakalpito 'rtho na vastu tathā kriyāsaṃbandhāt kartā ityapi kalpanāmātram iti pūrvapakṣasya
analyzed: ekatve vā kaḥ śleṣaḥ  tasmāt jñāna saṃbandhāt jñātā iti yathā vikalpa kalpitaḥ rthaḥ na vastu tathā kriyā saṃbandhāt kartā iti api kalpanā mātram iti pūrvapakṣasya
translated: If they are one, then what is the connection?

analyzed: saṃkṣepaḥ
translated: Therefore, from the connection with knowledge, the knower is known. Just as the object imagined by conceptualization is not a real entity, so also the agent from the connection with action is mere imagination. This is the summary of the prima facie view.

analyzed: iti śivam āditas
translated: Thus, auspiciousness... from the beginning.

original: iti śrīmadācāryābhinavaguptaviracitāyāṃ pratyabhijñāsūtravimarśinyāṃ jñānādhikāre pūrvapakṣavivṛtirnāma dvitīyamāhnikam // //
analyzed: iti śrīmat ācārya abhinavagupta viracitāyām pratyabhijñā sūtravimarśinyām jñāna adhikāre pūrvapakṣavivṛtiḥ nāma dvitīyam āhnikam  /
translated: Thus ends the second chapter named Exposition of the Prima Facie View in the Vimarśinī commentary on the Pratyabhijñā-sūtras composed by the illustrious teacher Abhinavagupta.

analyzed: atha tṛtīyam āhnikam
translated: Now, the third chapter.

original: vinā yena na kiṃcitsyātsamastā api dṛṣṭayaḥ /
analyzed: vinā yena na kiṃcid syāt samastāḥ api dṛṣṭayaḥ
translated: Without which nothing would exist, even all the views combined,

analyzed: an astamita saṃbodha svarūpam tam stumaḥ śivam
translated: We praise that Śiva, whose nature is unobstructed consciousness.

original: etasmin pūrvapakṣe yaduktaṃ smṛteḥ saṃskāramātrādeva siddhiḥ iti /
analyzed: etasmin pūrvapakṣe yat uktam smṛteḥ saṃskāra mātrāt eva siddhiḥ iti
translated: In this prima facie view, it was said that the establishment of memory is only from mere impressions.

analyzed: tat eva dūṣayitum
translated: To refute that very [view],

analyzed: satyam
translated: It is true...

analyzed: ityādi
translated: and so on,🔽up to
Possessing the power of knowledge, memory, and suppression.

analyzed: ityantam śloka saptakam
translated: This is the group of seven verses, ending with

original: kriyāyāṃ saṃbandhe ca dūṣaṇoddharaṇaṃ dvitīye kriyādhikāre bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: kriyāyām saṃbandhe ca dūṣaṇa uddharaṇam dvitīye kriyā adhikāre bhaviṣyati
translated: The refutation of the objections regarding the relation of the action will be in the second chapter on action.

original: yattu pareṇa vyatiriktaṃ jñānaṃ kāśādasāṃkhyādidṛṣṭau nirākṛtaṃ tadabhimatameva granthakṛta iti tat dūṣaṇāntarameva /
analyzed: yat tu pareṇa vyatiriktam jñānam kāśāt asāṃkhya ādi dṛṣṭau nirākṛtam tat abhimatam eva granthakṛtaḥ iti tat dūṣaṇa antaram eva
translated: But what has been refuted by the opponent as a separate cognition in the perception of a rope as a snake, etc., is accepted by the author of the treatise itself. Therefore, it is a different objection.

original: tatra ślokadvayena jñānasya svasaṃvedanarūpatayā anubhavasya smṛtau aprakāśatvaṃ darśitaṃ saṃskārajatve 'pi /
analyzed: tatra śloka dvayena jñānasya sva saṃvedana rūpa tayā anubhavasya smṛtau aprakāśa tvam darśitam saṃskāra ja tve pi
translated: There, in the two verses, the non-illumination of experience in memory is shown by the form of self-cognition of knowledge, even in the case of being born from impressions.

original: tataḥ ślokadvayena smṛteḥ bhrāntitvam āśaṅkāpūrvakaṃ parākṛtya tṛtīyena prasaṅgāt sarvādhyavasāyānāmapi bhrāntitvāśaṅkā śamitā /
analyzed: tatas śloka dvayena smṛteḥ bhrānti tvam āśaṅkā pūrvakam parākṛtya tṛtīyena prasaṅgāt sarva adhyavasāyānām api bhrānti tva āśaṅkā śamitā
translated: Then, in the two verses, the falsity of memory is refuted after raising doubts, and by the third, the doubt of the falsity of all determinations is removed by the way.

original: tataḥ satyapi saṃskāre smṛtyanupapattau vyavahārocchedaḥ iti ślokenoktvā svapakṣe tadupapattiḥ iti ślokenoktam iti tātparyam
analyzed: tatas sati api saṃskāre smṛti anupapattau vyavahāra ucchedaḥ iti ślokena uktvā sva pakṣe tad upapattiḥ iti ślokena uktam iti tātparyam
translated: Then, after stating in a verse that there would be a cessation of worldly transactions in the absence of memory even with the existence of impressions, it is stated in a verse that it is possible in one's own view. This is the purport.

analyzed: grantha arthaḥ tu nirūpyate  satyam kiṃtu smṛti jñānam pūrva anubhava saṃskṛteḥ
translated: The meaning of the text is being described.🔽It is true, but the knowledge of memory is born from the impression of previous experience.

analyzed: jātam api ātma niṣṭham tat na adya anubhava vedakam
translated: Even though born, it is related to the self, but it does not experience the present experience.

original: pūrvapakṣamadhyāt mayā tāvat bahu aṅgīkartavyam iti satyam ityanena darśitam /
analyzed: pūrvapakṣa madhyāt mayā tāvat bahu aṅgīkartavyam iti satyam iti anena darśitam
translated: It is true that much has to be accepted by me from the prima facie view, as shown by the word 'satyam'.

original: yattu na aṅgīkartavyaṃ tat dūṣyate ityetaduktaṃ kiṃtu ityanena viśeṣābhidhāyinā /
analyzed: yat tu na aṅgīkartavyam tat dūṣyate iti etat uktam kiṃtu iti anena viśeṣa abhidhāyinā
translated: But what is not to be accepted is refuted, this is stated by the word 'tu', which expresses a distinction.

original: iha smṛtau viṣayamātrasya prakāśo na samarthanīyo vartate yaḥ saṃskārādeva siddhyet /
analyzed: iha smṛtau viṣaya mātrasya prakāśaḥ na samarthanīyaḥ vartate yaḥ saṃskārāt eva siddhyet
translated: Here, in this smrti, the mere manifestation of the object is not to be established, which would be accomplished by impression alone.

original: kiṃtu anubhavaprakāśena vinā tat ityevaṃrūpā kathaṃ smṛtiḥ syāt /
analyzed: kiṃtu anubhava prakāśena vinā tat iti evaṃrūpā katham smṛtiḥ syāt
translated: But how could smrti be of the form 'that without the manifestation of experience'?

original: kathaṃ ca tayā vinā abhilāṣeṇa vyavahāraḥ syāt /
analyzed: katham ca tayā vinā abhilāṣeṇa vyavahāraḥ syāt
translated: And how could there be activity without desire in its absence?

analyzed: anubhavena hi asya sukha sādhana tā niścitā
translated: For by experience, its being a means of attaining pleasure is ascertained.

analyzed: tatas upādānam
translated: Then there is acceptance of it.

analyzed: tatra pūrva anubhava janitāt saṃskārāt etāvat jātam
translated: In that, this much has come from the impression born of prior experience.

analyzed: yadi api tat jñānam viṣayeṇa na janitam
translated: Even though that cognition is not produced by the object,

analyzed: tathā api tad viṣayam iti
translated: still it is said to have that as its object.

analyzed: na ca etāvatā kiṃcid
translated: And by this much nothing is accomplished.

original: ātmaniṣṭhe svaprakāśajñāne viṣayasyeva anubhavasya prācyasya aprakāśāt ////
analyzed: ātma niṣṭhe sva prakāśa jñāne viṣayasya iva anubhavasya prācyasya aprakāśāt
translated: Because, like the object, the prior experience is not manifested in the self-luminous cognition abiding in the self.

original: nanu saṃsk/arajatvādeva prācyamanubhavamapi viṣayīkurutāṃ smṛtiḥ ityāśaṅkyāha
analyzed: nanu saṃskara ja tvāt eva prācyam anubhavam api viṣayīkurutām smṛtiḥ iti āśaṅkya āha
translated: But it may be objected that memory should make the previous experience its object simply because it is produced by the impressions of that experience. To this he says:

analyzed: dṛś su ābhāsā eva na anyena vedyā rūpa dṛśā iva dṛś
translated: The cognition is self-luminous only, not to be known by another, like the cognition of form.

original: rase saṃskārajatvaṃ tu tattulyatvaṃ na tadgatiḥ // / / //
analyzed: rase saṃskāra ja tvam tu tad tulya tvam na tad gatiḥ
translated: But the impression-bornness in taste is its similarity, not its cognition.

original: dṛk jñānam / tacca jaḍāt vibhidyate svaprakāśaikarūpatayā /
translated: Cognition is knowledge. And that is distinguished from the insentient by being of the nature of self-luminous.

analyzed: jaḍaḥ hi prakāśāt pṛthak bhūtaḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: For the insentient must be said to be separate from light.

analyzed: tena dṛś su ābhāsā
translated: Therefore, cognition is self-luminous.

original: ābhāsaḥ prakāśamānatā sā svaṃ rūpamavyavhicāri yasyāḥ /
analyzed: ābhāsaḥ prakāśamāna tā sā svam rūpam avyavhicāri yasyāḥ
translated: Light is manifestation. That which has it as its invariable form.

analyzed: svasya ca ābhāsanam rūpam yasyāḥ
translated: And that which has the manifestation of its own as its form.

original: satyapi bāhye taccharīrasaṃkrāntaṃ na prakāśanaṃ jñānasya rūpaṃ bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: sati api bāhye tat śarīra saṃkrāntam na prakāśanam jñānasya rūpam bhavitum arhati
translated: Even when there is an external object, the manifestation that has entered its body is not fit to be the form of cognition.

analyzed: para prakāśana ātmaka nija rūpa prakāśanam eva hi sva prakāśa tvam jñānasya bhaṇyate
translated: For self-luminousness of cognition is said to be the manifestation of its own nature, which consists in manifesting another.

original: nanu svābhāsameva sat tat anubhavajñānaṃ smaraṇe bhāsiṣyate /
analyzed: nanu sva ābhāsam eva sat tat anubhava jñānam smaraṇe bhāsiṣyate
translated: But it may be objected that that cognition of experience, which is self-luminous, will appear in memory.

analyzed: na iti āha na anyena vedyā
translated: No, he says, it is not to be known by another.

original: paratra yadi dṛk bhāseta tarhi na sā svābhāsā /
analyzed: paratra yadi dṛś bhāseta tarhi na sā svābhāsā
translated: If it appeared in another, then it would not be self-luminous.

original: idameva hi svaprakāśasya lakṣaṇam svayaṃ hi yadi prakāśeta tadā pareṇa saha asaṃbandhāt saṃbandhaprāṇā kathaṃ paratra iti saptamī saṃgacchatām
analyzed: idam eva hi sva prakāśasya lakṣaṇam svayam hi yadi prakāśeta tadā pareṇa saha asaṃbandhāt saṃbandha prāṇā katham paratra iti saptamī saṃgacchatām
translated: For this is the definition of self-luminous: if it itself were to shine, then, being unrelated to another, how could the genitive ending in of that make sense, since it depends on a relation?

original: tathā ca rūpajñānena rase dṛk rasaviṣayaṃ jñānaṃ na vedyate /
analyzed: tathā ca rūpa jñānena rase   rasa viṣayam jñānam na vedyate
translated: And thus, the visual cognition of form does not cognize the taste-object.

original: evaṃ hi cakṣuṣaiva rasaḥ phalato gṛhīta eva syāt /
analyzed: evam hi cakṣuṣā eva rasaḥ phalataḥ gṛhītaḥ eva syāt
translated: In this way, the taste would be grasped by the eye itself.

original: nanu yadi na ābhāti smaraṇe 'nubhavaḥ kiṃ tarhi saṃskāreṇa kṛtaṃ syāt /
analyzed: nanu yadi na ābhāti smaraṇe nubhavaḥ kim tarhi saṃskāreṇa kṛtam syāt
translated: But if the experience does not shine in the memory, then what would be done by the impression?

analyzed: rūpa jñānam na rasa jñāna jāt saṃskārāt jātam
translated: The visual cognition is not produced from the impression of the gustatory cognition.

analyzed: tat katham ayam prasaṅgaḥ
translated: How then is this consequence?

analyzed: tasmāt saṃskāraḥ eva bhavat saṃbhāvita doṣa bhaṅgāya prabhavet
translated: Therefore, the impression itself would be able to remove the fault suspected by you.

original: naitat / yato hi asau tatsaṃskārasaṃskṛtāt samanantarapratyayāt utthitaḥ smṛtibodhaḥ /
analyzed: na etat yatas hi asau tad saṃskāra saṃskṛtāt samanantara pratyayāt utthitaḥ smṛti bodhaḥ
translated: This is not so, because that cognition of memory arises from the immediate condition that is modified by that impression.

original: tena tatsadṛśo bhavatu śāsvāsaṃniveśa iva pūrvasaṃniveśatulyaḥ /
analyzed: tena tad sadṛśaḥ bhavatu śāsvā saṃniveśaḥ iva pūrva saṃniveśa tulyaḥ
translated: Therefore, let it be similar to that, like a subsequent arrangement being similar to a previous arrangement.

original: na tu yo yatsaṃskārāt jātaḥ sa tasya vedanasvabhāvo bhavati iti yuktam /
analyzed: na tu yaḥ yad saṃskārāt jātaḥ sa tasya vedana svabhāvaḥ bhavati iti yuktam
translated: But it is not proper to say that whatever is produced from a certain impression has the nature of cognizing that.

analyzed: sadṛśa tvasya api gatiḥ avagamaḥ katham
translated: How is the cognition of similarity also possible?

analyzed: na hi anubhava jñānam sādṛśyam gamayati
translated: The knowledge of experience does not convey similarity.

analyzed: na api smṛti jñānam
translated: Nor does the knowledge of memory.
Because when they are not mutually experienced, it is not possible to ascertain the similarity that is based on both.

original: abhyasya ca tadubhayavedanarūpasya abhāvāt iti saṃskārāt paraṃ saviṣayatāmātraṃ smṛteḥ siddham /
analyzed: abhyasya ca tad ubhaya vedana rūpasya abhāvāt iti saṃskārāt param sa viṣaya tā mātram smṛteḥ siddham
translated: And because there is no form of experiencing both of them repeatedly, it is established that memory has only the nature of having an object after the impression.

analyzed: na tu anubhava viṣaya tvam
translated: But not the nature of being the object of experience.

original: nāpi asya viṣayasya pūrvānubhavaviṣayīkṛtatvam iti niścayaḥ eṣaḥ ////
analyzed: nā api asya viṣayasya pūrva anubhava viṣayīkṛta tvam iti niścayaḥ eṣaḥ
translated: Nor is there the certainty that this object has been made the object of prior experience.

original: nanu yadi smṛtijñāne anubhavasya satyataḥ prakāśaḥ syāt /
