analyzed: smarāmi aham
translated: I am remembering.

analyzed: vikalpitam mayā
translated: I have conceptualized.

original: smṛtaṃ mayā iti ahantārūḍhyaiva vikalpādeḥ avabhāsāt /
analyzed: smṛtam mayā iti ahantā rūḍhyā eva vikalpa ādeḥ avabhāsāt
translated: I have remembered. Thus, conceptual cognition, etc. appear only when they are based on the notion of 'I'.

original: ata eva ātmano'mī vikalpādyāḥ śaktiviśeṣāḥ tadviśrāntaśarīratvāt iti darśitam jñānasmṛtyapohanaśaktimān ityatra ////
analyzed: atas eva ātmanaḥ amī vikalpa ādyāḥ śakti viśeṣāḥ tad viśrānta śarīra tvāt iti darśitam jñāna smṛti apohana śaktimān iti atra
translated: For this very reason, it has been shown that these conceptual cognitions, etc. are specific powers of the self, because they rest in that body. Thus it is said that it possesses the powers of knowledge, memory, and suppression.

analyzed: evam iyataḥ prameyasya yat phalam tat upasaṃhartum āha
translated: Thus, in order to conclude the result of so much knowable, he says

analyzed: tat mayā dṛśyate dṛṣṭaḥ yam saḥ iti āmṛśati api
translated: When one sees it, one thinks, I have seen that.🔽

analyzed: grāhya grāhaka tā bhinnau arthau bhātaḥ pa mātari
translated: Even when one reflects, This is the one seen by me, the two objects, the perceived and the perceiver, appear as different in the cognizer.

original: tat iti tasmādarthe pūrvoktasya prameyasya hetubhāvena upajīvanam iha sūcayati /
analyzed: tat iti tasmāt arthe pūrvoktasya prameyasya hetu bhāvena upajīvanam iha sūcayati
translated: The word tat (that) in the verse indicates the previously mentioned object of knowledge as the basis for the argument here.

original: yata evamuktam anubhavasya arthasyeva smaraṇāt na bhedena avabhāsaḥ smrṭiśaktiśca parameśvarasyaiva /
analyzed: yatas evam uktam anubhavasya arthasya iva smaraṇāt na bhedena avabhāsaḥ smrṭi śaktiḥ ca parameśvarasya eva
translated: Because it has been said that memory arises from the object of experience, not as different from it, and the power of memory belongs to the Supreme Lord alone.

analyzed: tatas idam atra pariniṣṭhitam tattvam iti
translated: Therefore, this is the final truth in this matter.

analyzed: iha smṛtiḥ anubhavam kroḍīkaroti iti uktam
translated: Here it has been said that memory includes experience.

analyzed: anubhavaḥ ca dvidhā
translated: And experience is of two kinds.

original: parāmarśabhedāt kadācit svātmaparāmarśapūrvakam anubhāvyam parāmṛśati yatra asya abhisaṃdhipradhānatā mayā dṛśyate iti /
analyzed: parāmarśa bhedāt kadācid sva ātma parāmarśa pūrvakam anubhāvyam parāmṛśati yatra asya abhisaṃdhi pradhāna tā mayā dṛśyate iti
translated: Due to the difference in the reflective awareness, sometimes one reflects on the object to be experienced after the reflective awareness of one's own self, where the intention is primary, thinking I am seen by me.

original: kadācit anubhavanīyameva pradhānatayā parāmṛśati yatra anabhisaṃdhereva sahasā vastūpanipātaḥ /
analyzed: kadācid anubhavanīyam eva pradhāna tayā parāmṛśati yatra anabhisaṃdheḥ eva sahasā vastu upanipātaḥ
translated: Sometimes one reflects on the object to be experienced as primary, where there is a sudden encounter with an object without any intention.

original: arthakriyāṃ prati āgrahaviśeṣo vā ayam iti /
analyzed: arthakriyām prati āgraha viśeṣaḥ vā ayam iti
translated: Or this is a special insistence on the function of the object.

analyzed: tatra api ca prakāśa parāmarśaḥ sti eva
translated: And even in that case, there is indeed the reflective awareness of light.

analyzed: anyathā prakāśa ayogāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be no possibility of illumination.

original: evamubhayathānubhave pratyekaṃ smṛtirapi dvayaparāmarśamayī udeti iti catvāraḥ smaraṇabhedāḥ /
analyzed: evam ubhayathā anubhave pratyekam smṛtiḥ api dvaya parāmarśa mayī udeti iti catvāraḥ smaraṇa bhedāḥ
translated: Thus, in both ways, memory also arises consisting of the reflection of both, so there are four types of memory.

analyzed: dvau anubhava bhedau
translated: There are two types of experience.

analyzed: anusaṃdhānam pratyabhijñānam api etat ubhaya melana ātmakam atra eva antarbhūtam
translated: Recognition, which is the connecting of the past and present, is also included here as consisting of the union of these two.

analyzed: tat ca etad bhedāt aṣṭadhā
translated: And that is eightfold due to the difference in that.

analyzed: pūrva apara viśrānti kṛtāt pratyekam dvidhā bhedāt ca ṣoḍaśadhā
translated: And due to the difference of each being twofold due to the resting in the past and future, it is sixteenfold.

original: tadete dvāviṃśatiḥ saṃvedanabhedāḥ /🔽teṣu ca grāhyaṃ tāvat prakāśāt abahirbhūtam /
analyzed: tat ete dvāviṃśatiḥ saṃvedana bhedāḥ  teṣu ca grāhyam tāvat prakāśāt a bahis bhūtam
translated: These are the twenty-two types of consciousness.🔽And among them, the object is not external to the light.

analyzed: anyathā prakāśana ayogāt
translated: Otherwise, it could not be illuminated.

analyzed: bahis bhūtam ca tat
translated: And it is external.

analyzed: anyathā ārtha tva asaṃbhavāt
translated: Otherwise, it could not be an object.

analyzed: na ca tatas eva
translated: And it is not from that itself.

original: tadaiva /🔽tadevāpṛthagbhūtaṃ atra pṛthagbhūtaṃ ca bhavati iti nūnamanyaḥ kalpitaprakāśātmā kaścit atra artho 'sti /
analyzed: tadā eva  tat eva apṛthak bhūtam atra pṛthak bhūtam ca bhavati iti nūnam anyaḥ kalpita prakāśa ātmā kaścid atra arthaḥ sti
translated: At that very time.🔽That very thing, which is not separate, becomes separate here. Therefore, there must be some other object here, whose nature is imagined light,

original: yato 'yam artharāśiḥ pṛthagbhavan anyonyamapi pṛthaktām adhigacchet /
analyzed: yatas yam artha rāśiḥ pṛthak bhavan anyonyam api pṛthaktām adhigacchet
translated: from which this mass of objects, becoming separate, would attain separateness from each other.

original: anyathā prakāśābhinnānāṃ parasparamapi kathaṅkāraṃ pṛthagbhāvo bhavet /
analyzed: anyathā prakāśa abhinnānām parasparam api kathaṅkāram pṛthagbhāvaḥ bhavet
translated: Otherwise, how could those that are not separate from the light have separateness from each other?

analyzed: saḥ yam vedya eka deśe eva
translated: This is indeed only a part of the knowable.

analyzed: vicchinnaḥ eva
translated: It is indeed separate.

analyzed: anujjhita vedya bhāvaḥ eva
translated: It is indeed not abandoned as the state of the knowable.

original: aham iti vicchedaśūmyaprakāśocitena parāmarśena parāmṛśyamāno māyāpramātā iti vakṣyate dehe buddhau / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / /
analyzed: aham iti viccheda śūmya prakāśa ucitena parāmarśena parāmṛśyamānaḥ māyā pramātā iti vakṣyate dehe buddhau
translated: It will be said that the limited knower of reality, who is contemplated by the reflective awareness of the light of the separation of I, in the body, in the intellect, etc.,

analyzed: iti atra
translated: in this [verse].

analyzed: sa ca grāhakaḥ iti ucyate
translated: And that is called the apprehender.

original: evaṃ samameva svātmani nirmalamakurasthānīye yat yugalakaṃ svasmāt prakāśarūpāt avyatiriktam
analyzed: evam samam eva sva ātmani nirmala makura sthānīye yat yugalakam svasmāt prakāśa rūpāt a vyatiriktam
translated: Thus, in the same way, the pair, which is not separate from its own light, which is like a clear mirror in one's own Self,

original: avabhāsayati parameśvaraḥ tadeva etat bhagavato jñānakartṛtvaṃ smaraṇakartṛtvaṃ jñānaśaktismṛtiśaktirūpam
analyzed: avabhāsayati parameśvaraḥ tat eva etat bhagavataḥ jñāna kartṛ tvam smaraṇa kartṛ tvam jñāna śakti smṛti śakti rūpam
translated: is illuminated by the Supreme Lord. That very thing is the Lord's agency of knowledge, agency of recollection, which is in the form of the power of knowledge and the power of memory,

analyzed: ucyate iti tātparyārthaḥ
translated: it is said. This is the intended meaning.

analyzed: akṣara arthaḥ tu mayā dṛśyate iti
translated: The meaning of the syllables is I am seen.

original: ayam iti ca yat āmṛśati pramātā prakāśarūpo yena anubhavati iti ucyate /
analyzed: ayam iti ca yat āmṛśati pramātā prakāśa rūpaḥ yena anubhavati iti ucyate
translated: And when the knower, who is of the nature of light, contemplates this, by which he is said to experience,

analyzed: tatas āmarśanāt etat lakṣyate
translated: from that contemplation, this is indicated.

original: grāhyarūpeṇa grāhakarūpeṇa yojitau ghaṭādidehādisvabhāvau arthau vedyau pramātari viśuddhaprakāśarūpe bhātaḥ prakāśete /
analyzed: grāhya rūpeṇa grāhaka rūpeṇa yojitau ghaṭa ādi deha ādi svabhāvau arthau vedyau pramātari viśuddha prakāśa rūpe bhātaḥ prakāśete
translated: The two objects, which are connected with the form of the object to be grasped and the form of the grasper, and which have the nature of a pot, etc. and the body, etc., appear in the cognizer, who has the nature of pure light, as shining in the light.

original: evaṃ dṛṣṭaḥ iti sa iti ca yat parāmṛśati prakāśarūpaḥ pramātā /
analyzed: evam dṛṣṭaḥ iti saḥ iti ca yat parāmṛśati prakāśa rūpaḥ pramātā
translated: Thus, when he refers to it as seen and that, the cognizer, who has the nature of light,

analyzed: yatas sau smarati iti vyapadeśyaḥ
translated: is designated as he who remembers.

analyzed: etat eva lakṣyate
translated: Therefore, this alone is indicated.

original: anubhavarūpopajīvitvaṃ pūrvoktaṃ draḍhayituṃ prasaṅgāt atra jñānaśakterapi unmīlanaṃ kṛtam /
analyzed: anubhava rūpa upajīvi tvam pūrva uktam draḍhayitum prasaṅgāt atra jñānaśakteḥ api unmīlanam kṛtam
translated: In order to strengthen the previously stated dependence on the form of experience, the manifestation of the power of knowledge is also presented here incidentally.

analyzed: lakṣaṇe śatṛ ādeśaḥ
translated: The suffix śatṛ is used in the definition.

analyzed: api śabdaḥ ca arthe
translated: And the word api has the meaning of ca (and).

analyzed: artha śabdaḥ vicchinna vedya vācī
translated: The word artha (object) denotes the limited object of knowledge.

original: grāhako māyīyaḥ kalpitaḥ pramātā aśuddhaprakāśasvabhāvaḥ iti śivam / āditaḥ ślo / //
analyzed: grāhakaḥ māyīyaḥ kalpitaḥ pramātā aśuddha prakāśa svabhāvaḥ iti śivam āditaḥ ślo
translated: The grasper is the imaginary cognizer based on māyā, whose nature is impure light. Thus, it is auspicious. The verses begin with ślo.

original: iti śrīmadācāryābhinavaguptaviracitāyāṃīśvarapratyabhijñāsūtravimarśinyāṃ prathame jñānādhikāre smṛtiśaktinirūpaṇaṃ nāma caturthamāhnikam //
analyzed: iti śrīmat ācārya abhinavagupta viracitāyām īśvarapratyabhijñā sūtravimarśinyām prathame jñāna adhikāre smṛtiśaktinirūpaṇam nāma caturtham āhnikam
translated: Thus ends the fourth chapter named Determination of the Power of Memory in the first section on knowledge in the Vimarśinī commentary on the Aphorisms of the Recognition of God composed by the illustrious teacher Abhinavagupta.

analyzed: atha pañcamam āhnikam
translated: Now, the fifth chapter.
The one who reveals the nature born from being immersed in the great cave,

original: jñānaśaktipradīpena yaḥ sadā taṃ stumaḥ śivam //
analyzed: jñānaśakti pradīpena yaḥ sadā tam stumaḥ śivam
translated: We always praise that Śiva, who is the light of the lamp of the power of knowledge.

analyzed: evam tāvat smṛtiśakteḥ svarūpam pratipāditam
translated: Thus far, the nature of the power of memory has been explained.

analyzed: adhunā tad upajīvanīya jñānaśakti parama artha nirṇayam vitatya
translated: Now, extensively, the determination of the ultimate truth of the power of knowledge, which is the basis for that [memory],

analyzed: iti ādikayā
translated: [is presented] beginning with the verse The manifestation of the present...

analyzed: sakramam pratibhāsate ityantayā śloka ekaviṃśatyā nirūpayati
translated: and ending with the verse appears in sequence.

original: tatrādyeva ślokena vastuni pratijñāṃ karoti evaṃbhūtā jñānaśaktiḥ iti /
analyzed: tatra ādi eva ślokena vastuni pratijñām karoti evaṃbhūtā jñānaśaktiḥ iti
translated: In that [set of verses], in the very first verse, he makes a statement about the subject, saying The power of knowledge is of such a nature...

original: tataḥ ślokadvayena prakāśa evārthānāṃ svarūpa / ityāha /
analyzed: tatas śloka dvayena prakāśaḥ eva arthānām svarūpaḥ iti āha
translated: Then, in two verses, he says that the nature of objects is nothing but light.

original: tato dvayena prakāśabāhyānāmarthānāṃ sadbhāvaṃ vijñānavādyupagatavāsanādūṣaṇena dṛḍhīkṛtam āśaṅkya /
analyzed: tatas dvayena prakāśa bāhyānām arthānām sadbhāvam vijñāna vādi upagata vāsanā dūṣaṇena dṛḍhīkṛtam āśaṅkya
translated: Then, in two [verses], having strengthened the belief in the existence of external objects through the refutation of imprints accepted by the Vijñānavādins,

original: tṛtīyena tadanabhyupagame 'pi tāvat na kiñcit uparudhyata iti darśayati /
analyzed: tṛtīyena tad anabhyupagame pi tāvat na kiñcid uparudhyate iti darśayati
translated: in the third [verse], he shows that even if [the existence of external objects] is not accepted, nothing is contradicted.

original: atha ślokena svadarśane 'rthatattvam upadarśayan bāhyārthasadbhāve pratyakṣaṃ parākaroti pramāṇatvena /
analyzed: atha ślokena sva darśane rtha tattvam upadarśayan bāhya artha sadbhāve pratyakṣam parākaroti pramāṇa tvena
translated: Then, in one verse, showing the truth of objects in his own view, he rejects direct perception as a means of valid knowledge in establishing the existence of external objects.

analyzed: tatas dvayena anumeya tām api bāhyasya nirasyati
translated: Then, in two [verses], he rejects the possibility of external objects being inferred.

original: anantaraṃ ślokena cidātmani arthānām avaśyaṃ sadbhāvaḥ parāmarśātmanā iti prakaṭayati /
analyzed: anantaram ślokena cit ātmani arthānām avaśyam sadbhāvaḥ parāmarśa ātmanā iti prakaṭayati
translated: Then, in the next verse, he makes it clear that the existence of objects is necessarily in the conscious self in the form of reflection.

original: tato 'pi prakāśasya pramātṛrūpasya pratyavamarśa eva jīvatam iti ślokacatuṣṭayena anubhavāgamanyāyasvarūpanirūpaṇābhiḥ abhidhatte /
analyzed: prakāśasya pramātṛ rūpasya pratyavamarśaḥ eva jīvatam iti śloka catuṣṭayena anubhava āgama nyāya svarūpa nirūpaṇābhiḥ abhidhatte
translated: Then, he states in four verses that the life of the manifestation, which is in the form of the cognizer, is indeed the reflective awareness itself.

original: anantaraṃ jñānaparāmarśa eva jñeyaṃ śuddhaṃ pramātṛrūpatānujjhitaṃ ca prakṣayati iti tasyaiva pradhānatve nyāyaṃ ślokatrayeṇāha /
analyzed: anantaram jñāna parāmarśaḥ eva jñeyam śuddham pramātṛ rūpa tā anujjhitam ca prakṣayati iti tasya eva pradhāna tve nyāyam śloka trayeṇa āha
translated: Then, in three verses, he states the reason for the primacy of that [reflective awareness] itself, that the object of knowledge is pure and does not abandon the form of the pure cognizer, and is destroyed by the reflective awareness itself.

original: prakāśaikarūpatve ca jñānajñātrādi bhinnam iti ślokenāha /
analyzed: prakāśa eka rūpa tve ca jñāna jñātṛ ādi bhinnam iti ślokena āha
translated: And in the verse [on the nature of the cognizer], he states that when there is only the form of manifestation, the distinction of knowledge, knower, etc. is not tenable.

original: tato jñātari iva viśuddhe jñāne 'pi avikalpakasavikalpakarūpe vimarśa eva prāṇitam iti ślokadvayenāha /
analyzed: tatas jñātari iva viśuddhe jñāne pi avikalpaka savikalpaka rūpe vimarśe eva prāṇitam iti śloka dvayena āha
translated: Then, in two verses, he states that in pure knowledge also, like in the cognizer, the life is indeed the reflective awareness itself, which is of the nature of non-conceptual and conceptual [knowledge].

analyzed: tatas jñātuḥ jñānasya ca pūrvapakṣe
translated: Then, in the first part [of the chapter], the distinction between the cognizer and knowledge is refuted.

original: yat bhinnatvaṃ tat upasaṃhāradiśā ślokena samarthayate /
analyzed: yat bhinna tvam tat upasaṃhāra diśā ślokena samarthayate
translated: Then, in a verse, he establishes that distinction, which is to be concluded in the same way.

analyzed: iti tātparyam āhnikasya
translated: This is the purport of the chapter.

analyzed: śloka arthaḥ tu nirūpyate
translated: Now, the meaning of the verses is being explained.

analyzed: nanu smaraṇa vikalpa ādīnām anubhavaḥ eva jīvitam
translated: But surely, memory, imagination, etc. have experience alone as their life.

original: tatra yadi bhedena ābhāsānte 'rthāḥ tat teṣvapi tathaiva avabhāsa ucitaḥ /
analyzed: tatra yadi bhedena ābhāsa ante rthāḥ tat teṣu api tathā eva avabhāsaḥ ucitaḥ
translated: If objects appear as different in them, then their appearance should be just like that.

analyzed: no ced anyathā
translated: If not, then otherwise.

original: tadanubhava eva tāvat jñānaśaktirūpo vicāraṇīya ityāśayenāha
analyzed: tad anubhavaḥ eva tāvat jñānaśakti rūpaḥ vicāraṇīyaḥ iti āśayena āha
translated: With the intention that the experience itself, which is in the form of the power of knowledge, should be considered, he says:

analyzed: vartamāna avabhāsānām bhāvānām avabhāsanam
translated: The manifestation of present appearing entities

analyzed: antar sthitavatām eva ghaṭate bahis ātmanā
translated: is possible only for those who are internally situated as external selves.

original: vartamānatvena sphuṭatayā avabhāsanam idamityevamākāraṃ yeṣāṃ teṣām /🔽yadetat bahirātmanā kalpitamāyīyaśūnyādiśarīrāntapramātṛpṛthagbhāvena hetunā /
analyzed: vartamāna tvena sphuṭa tayā avabhāsanam idam iti evam ākāram yeṣām teṣām  yat etat bahis ātmanā kalpita māyīya śūnya ādi śarīra anta pramātṛ pṛthagbhāvena hetunā
translated: Those whose manifestation is as clear as the present, in the form of this,

original: bhinnānām tato māyāpramātuḥ vicchinnānām avabhāsanam tat paramārthapramātari śuddhacinmaye antaḥsthitavatām tena saha aikātmyam anujjhitavatāmeva
analyzed: bhinnānām tatas māyā pramātuḥ vicchinnānām avabhāsanam tat paramārtha pramātari śuddha cit maye antar sthitavatām tena saha aikātmyam anujjhitavatām eva  /
translated: that manifestation of separate entities, from the illusory cognizer, is possible for those who are internally situated in the ultimate cognizer, who is pure consciousness, and who have not abandoned oneness with Him.

analyzed: ghaṭate pramāṇena upapadyate
translated: It is logically consistent.

original: tena anujjhitasaṃvidabhedasya bhāvasya kalpitapramātrapekṣayā bhedena prakāśanaṃ bhagavato jñānaśaktirityuktaṃ bhavati ////
analyzed: tena anujjhita saṃvid abhedasya bhāvasya kalpita pramātṛ apekṣayā bhedena prakāśanam bhagavataḥ jñānaśaktiḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: Thus, the manifestation of an entity whose identity with consciousness is not abandoned as being different due to the limited perceiver's perspective is said to be the Lord's power of knowledge.

original: pramāṇenopapadyate ityuktaṃ tat pramāṇaṃ darśayati 🔽prāgivārtho'prakāśaḥ syātprakāśātmatayā vinā /
analyzed: pramāṇena upapadyate iti uktam tat pramāṇam darśayati  prāk iva arthaḥ uprakāśaḥ syāt prakāśa ātma tayā vinā
translated: It has been said that it is established by means of valid cognition. He shows that valid cognition:🔽The object would be as if it were not manifest, without the nature of manifestation.

original: na ca prakāśo bhinnaḥ syādātmārthasya prakāśatā // / / //
analyzed: na ca prakāśaḥ bhinnaḥ syāt ātma arthasya prakāśa tā
translated: And the manifestation would not be different, the object's state of being manifest.

analyzed: arthaḥ nīla ādiḥ
translated: The object is blue and so on.

original: tasya nīlādirūpataiva yadi prakāśamānatā na punaḥ sāparā kācit arthaśarīrottīrṇā prakāśātmatā tarhi yathā sarvān prati nīlameva tatsaṃbhāvanayā 🔽bhaṇyate /
analyzed: tasya nīla ādi rūpa tā eva yadi prakāśamāna tā na punar sā aparā kācid artha śarīra uttīrṇā prakāśa ātma tā tarhi yathā sarvān prati nīlam eva tat saṃbhāvanayā  bhaṇyate
translated: If its very form as blue and so on is its state of being manifest, and not some other state of being manifest that transcends the body of the object, then just as it is said to be blue for everyone due to the possibility of that,

analyzed: na kaṃcid vā prati
translated: it is said for no one.

original: vastuto vā svātmanyeva tat nīlaṃ parasya paraniṣṭhatvānupapatteḥ /
analyzed: vastutas vā svātmani eva tat nīlam parasya para niṣṭhatva anupapatteḥ
translated: Or in reality, it is blue only for itself, because it cannot be established in another due to being dependent on another.

original: svātmani vā na nīlaṃ na anīlam prakāśānugraheṇa vinā vyavasthānāyogāt /
analyzed: sva ātmani vā na nīlam na anīlam prakāśa anugraheṇa vinā vyavasthāna ayogāt
translated: Or it is neither blue nor non-blue in itself, because without the favor of manifestation, it cannot be established.

original: tathā prakāśamānatāpi asya sarvān prati na kaṃcit vā prati api tu svātmanyeva /
analyzed: tathā prakāśamāna tā api asya sarvān prati na kaṃcid vā prati api tu sva ātmani eva
translated: In the same way, its state of being manifest is also for everyone, or for no one, but only in itself.

original: svātmanyapi vā na syāt iti andhatā jagataḥ /
analyzed: sva ātmani api vā na syāt iti andha tā jagataḥ
translated: Or it would not be in one's own self either, so the world would be blind.

original: atha indriyālokādikṣaṇavargāt prakāśarūpo 'sau nīlakṣaṇo viśiṣṭa eva jātaḥ /
analyzed: atha indriya āloka ādi kṣaṇa vargāt prakāśa rūpaḥ sau nīla kṣaṇaḥ viśiṣṭaḥ eva jātaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, it is produced as a distinct blue form of light from the group of moments of sense faculties, light, etc.,

analyzed: evam api saḥ eva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: then the same consequence applies.

analyzed: prakaṭa tā vāde pi ayam eva doṣaḥ
translated: Even in the theory of manifestation, this is the same fault.

original: sarvathā arthaśarīraviśrāntaḥ cet prakāśo mama avabhāsate iti pramātṛlagnatayā prakāśasthitiḥ durupapādā /
analyzed: sarvathā artha śarīra viśrāntaḥ ced prakāśaḥ mama avabhāsate iti pramātṛ lagna tayā prakāśa sthitiḥ durupapādā
translated: If the manifestation rests entirely in the body of the object, then the establishment of manifestation as connected with the cognizer, I perceive it as manifest, is difficult to establish.

original: pramātā hi tadānīm indriyādimayo 'rtharūpaprakāśasya kāraṇaṃ bhavet bījamivāṅkurasya /
analyzed: pramātā hi tadānīm indriya ādi mayaḥ ṛtha rūpa prakāśasya kāraṇam bhavet bījam iva aṅkurasya
translated: For at that time, the cognizer, consisting of the sense faculties and so on, would be the cause of the manifestation in the form of the object, like a seed for a sprout.

analyzed: na ca aṅkuraḥ bīja apekṣaḥ ṅkura ātmā
translated: And a sprout is not the self of a seed, dependent on a seed.

original: tato yadi na prakāśātmā sa syāt prāgiva jñānodayāt pūrvaṃ yathā'sāvaprakāśaḥ tathā jñānodaye 'pi syāt /
analyzed: tatas yadi na prakāśa ātmā sa syāt prāk iva jñāna udayāt pūrvam yathā asau aprakāśaḥ tathā jñāna udaye syāt
translated: Therefore, if it were not the self of manifestation, it would be as it was before the arising of knowledge, just as it was before the arising of knowledge.

analyzed: nanu jñānam artha prakāśa rūpam eva
translated: But knowledge is indeed the form of the manifestation of the object.

original: tat kathaṃ jñānasya udayānudayayoḥ arthasya tulyatā syāt /
analyzed: tat katham jñānasya udaya anudayayoḥ arthasya tulya tā syāt
translated: So how could there be equality of the object in the arising and non-arising of knowledge?

analyzed: syāt etat yadi upapadyet
translated: This would be so if it were possible.

original: yāvatā arthāt bhinnaṃ yat jñānaṃ prakāśarūpam /
analyzed: yāvatā arthāt bhinnam yat jñānam prakāśa rūpam
translated: But as long as knowledge, which is different from the object and is of the form of manifestation,

analyzed: tat arthasya saṃbandhi tayā katham syāt
translated: How could it be related to the object in that sense?

original: yadi tāvat arthaḥ prakāśate ityevaṃbhūtaṃ jñānasya svarūpaṃ tat arthajñānayoḥ abheda evāyātaḥ /
analyzed: yadi tāvat arthaḥ prakāśate iti evaṃbhūtam jñānasya svarūpam tat artha jñānayoḥ abhedaḥ eva āyātaḥ
translated: If the form of cognition is such that the object appears, then the non-difference of the object and cognition has come about.

analyzed: artha svabhāvasya jñāna tvena ukta tvāt
translated: Because the nature of the object is said to be cognition.

original: arthasvabhāvatve ca sati prakāśasya arthātmatāyām uktaṃ dūṣaṇam /
analyzed: artha svabhāva tve ca sati prakāśasya artha ātma tāyām uktam dūṣaṇam
translated: And if it has the nature of the object, the fault stated in the case of the self of the object in the case of manifestation is the same.

original: atha arthaṃ prakāśayati iti jñānasya svarūpam /
analyzed: atha artham prakāśayati iti jñānasya svarūpam
translated: Or if the form of cognition is that it manifests the object,

original: tarhi prakāśamānamarthaṃ karoti jñānam iti āpatite punarapi sa eva doṣaḥ /
analyzed: tarhi prakāśamānam artham karoti jñānam iti āpatite punar api saḥ eva doṣaḥ
translated: then it follows that cognition makes the object manifest, and again the same fault arises.

original: kṛtapratānaśca ayaṃ prakṛtyarthaṇyarthaviveko mayaiva bhedavidāraṇe iti tata eva anveṣyaḥ /
analyzed: kṛta pratānaḥ ca ayam mayā eva bheda vidāraṇe iti tatas eva anveṣyaḥ
translated: And this distinction between the meaning of the root and the object has been extensively discussed by me in the Bhedaviveka, so it should be sought there.

original: tasmāt bhinnaḥ prakāśo 'rthasya saṃbandhī bhavati iti saṃbhāvanaiva nāsti /
analyzed: tasmāt bhinnaḥ prakāśaḥ rthasya saṃbandhī bhavati iti saṃbhāvanā eva na asti
translated: Therefore, there is no possibility at all that manifestation, which is different, could be related to the object.

original: tacca idam upapattyā āyātam arthasya svarūpaṃ prakāśamānatā prakāśābhinnatvam iti /
analyzed: tat ca idam upapattyā āyātam arthasya svarūpam prakāśamāna tā prakāśa abhinna tvam iti
translated: And this nature of the object, which has come about through reasoning, is the manifestation, the non-difference from the manifestation.

original: prakāśaśca yadi ghaṭe 'nyaḥ paṭe 'nyaḥ tadā anusaṃdhānasya ayogaḥ /
analyzed: prakāśaḥ ca yadi ghaṭe nyaḥ paṭe nyaḥ tadā anusaṃdhānasya ayogaḥ
translated: And if the manifestation is different in the pot and different in the cloth, then there cannot be any connection.

original: dvayoḥ prakāśayoḥ svātmamātraparyavasānād iti vitatya upapāditaṃ naśyet janasthitiḥ ityatra /
analyzed: dvayoḥ prakāśayoḥ sva ātma mātra paryavasānāt iti vitatya upapāditam naśyet jana sthitiḥ iti atra
translated: It has been extensively established in the line the existence of the world would perish that the two manifestations end only in their own self.

analyzed: tasmāt eka eva prakāśaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is only one manifestation.

original: etadeva āvṛttyā darśitaṃ na ca prakāśo bhinnaḥ syāt iti ////
analyzed: etat eva āvṛttyā darśitam na ca prakāśaḥ bhinnaḥ syāt iti
translated: This very thing is shown by repetition in the line and the manifestation would not be different.

analyzed: vyatiriktasya jñānasya artha prakāśa rūpa tām abhyupagamya api bādhaka antaram āha
translated: Even accepting the idea that knowledge, which is different [from the object], has the form of the manifestation of the object, he states another objection:

original: bhinne prakāśe cābhinne saṃkaro viṣayasya tat /
analyzed: bhinne prakāśe ca abhinne saṃkaraḥ viṣayasya tat
translated: If the manifestation is different, there would be a confusion of the object with that.

analyzed: prakāśa ātmā prakāśya ūrthaḥ na aprakāśaḥ ca siddhi ati
translated: The object, which is of the nature of manifestation, cannot be established as non-manifest.

original: yadi arthāt anya eva jñānātmā prakāśaḥ ata eva bhinno 'rthataḥ tarhi svātmani tasya prakāśamātrarūpatvāt abheda eva /
analyzed: yadi arthāt anyaḥ eva jñāna ātmā prakāśaḥ atas eva bhinnaḥ ṛthataḥ tarhi svātmani tasya prakāśa mātra rūpa tvāt abhedaḥ eva
translated: If the manifestation, which is of the nature of knowledge, is different from the object, and therefore different from the object, then it is indeed non-different, because it has the form of mere manifestation in its own self.

analyzed: tathā hi nīlasya prakāśaḥ
translated: For example, the manifestation of blue,

original: pītasya prakāśaḥ iti yo nīlāṃśaḥ pītāṃśaśca /
analyzed: pītasya prakāśaḥ iti yaḥ nīla aṃśaḥ pīta aṃśaḥ ca
translated: the manifestation of yellow - the part that is blue and the part that is yellow,

original: sa na tāvat jñānasya svarūpam bhedavādatyāgāpatteḥ /
analyzed: sa na tāvat jñānasya svarūpam bheda vāda tyāga āpatteḥ
translated: that is not the form of knowledge, because it would lead to the abandonment of the doctrine of difference.

analyzed: atha viṣayaḥ
translated: If it is the object,

original: tadevedaṃ vicāryate iha prakāśabalāt nīlapītayoḥ bhedo 'bhyupagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: tat eva idam vicāryate iha prakāśa balāt nīla pītayoḥ bhedaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: then this is to be considered: here, the difference between blue and yellow must be accepted due to the power of manifestation.

original: yenaiva ca prakāśena nīlo nīla eva iti upagamyate /
analyzed: yena eva ca prakāśena nīlaḥ nīlaḥ eva iti upagamyate
translated: And by the same light by which blue is cognized as blue,

original: tenaiva ca prakāśena pītaḥ pīta iti kathaṃ saṃgacchatām /🔽nīlena janitaḥ /
analyzed: tena eva ca prakāśena pītaḥ pītaḥ iti katham saṃgacchatām  nīlena janitaḥ
translated: how can yellow be cognized as yellow by that same light?🔽Generated by blue,

analyzed: pītena janitaḥ
translated: generated by yellow,

original: tena vā saha samānasāmagrīka ityādi yat ucyate tat siddhe nīlapītayorbhede syāt /
analyzed: tena vā saha samāna sāmagrīkaḥ ityādi yat ucyate tat siddhe nīla pītayoḥ bhede syāt
translated: or existing together with that, etc., all this would be possible if the difference between blue and yellow were established.

original: sa eva vicāryaḥ /🔽atha nīlākāro 'sau tat yadi pratibimbabalāt taddvitīyabimbānavabhāsāt ayuktam /
analyzed: saḥ eva vicāryaḥ  atha nīla ākāraḥ sau tat yadi pratibimba balāt tad dvitīya bimba an avabhāsāt ayuktam
translated: That very [difference] needs to be examined.

analyzed: atha abhedaḥ
translated: If that [light] has the form of blue, then if it is due to the power of the reflection, because the second object does not appear, it is not reasonable.🔽Or if there is non-difference,

original: tarhi tyakto bhedavādaḥ /🔽tathā karaṇatādivāde śikharasthajñānaṃ bahutaranīlādijanyam ekatra paṭu anyatra mandam iti kathaṃ bhedaḥ prakāśaśarīrasya abhedāt /
analyzed: tarhi tyaktaḥ bheda vādaḥ  tathā karaṇa tā ādi vāde śikhara stha jñānam bahutara nīla ādi janyam ekatra paṭu anyatra mandam iti katham bhedaḥ prakāśa śarīrasya abhedāt
translated: then the doctrine of difference is abandoned.🔽Similarly, in the doctrine of instrumentality, etc., the cognition located at the peak is produced by many more blues, etc., being sharp in one place and dull in another - how is there difference, since the body of light is non-different?

original: tathābhūte ca anyataradarśanodbhūte 'pi saṃskāre balādeva aśeṣasmaraṇaprasaṅga iti bhūyān saṅkaraḥ /
analyzed: tathābhūte ca anyatara darśana udbhūte saṃskāre balāt eva aśeṣa smaraṇa prasaṅgaḥ iti bhūyān saṅkaraḥ
translated: And in that case, even when the impression produced by the perception of one of the two [objects] arises, there would be the consequence of the recollection of the entire [object] by the power [of that impression] alone. Thus there would be a great confusion.

analyzed: syāt etat arthaḥ eva astu
translated: This may be said: Let there be just the object.

analyzed: kim anena doṣa āpādakena prakāśena iti
translated: What is the use of this light that brings about faults?

analyzed: atra āha aprakāśasya prasiddhiḥ eva na kācid
translated: To this he says: There is no well-known existence at all of what is not light.

original: svātmani hi nīlaṃ yadi pūtaṃ na kiṃcit vā /
analyzed: sva ātmani hi nīlam yadi pūtam na kiṃcid vā
translated: For if the blue is pure in itself, it is nothing at all.

analyzed: tat kim duṣyet
translated: Then what is spoiled?

original: ata eva granthakṛtaiva anyatra uktam 🔽evamātmanyasatkalpāḥ prakāśasyaiva santyamī /
analyzed: atas eva granthakṛtā eva anyatra uktam  evam ātmani asat kalpāḥ prakāśasya eva santi amī
translated: For this very reason, it is said by the author of the treatise elsewhere:🔽Thus, these which are like non-existent in the self are of the light itself.

analyzed: jaḍāḥ prakāśaḥ eva asti sva ātmanaḥ sva para ātmabhiḥ
translated: The dull ones exist only in the light, by the self's own and other's selves.

original: iti / tat yadi prakāśaḥ tadā bhavati arthaḥ /
analyzed: iti tat yadi prakāśaḥ tadā bhavati arthaḥ
translated: Thus, if it is light, then it becomes the object.

analyzed: prakāśaḥ ca asau katham
translated: And how is that light?

original: yadi prakāśataiva ghaṭasya vapuḥ saiva paṭasya ityādi viśvavapuḥ prakāśaḥ siddhaḥ ////
analyzed: yadi prakāśa tā eva ghaṭasya vapuḥ sā eva paṭasya ityādi viśva vapuḥ prakāśaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: If the very manifestation of the pot is the very manifestation of the cloth, etc., then the light which is the body of the universe is established.

analyzed: ekasya eva prakāśasya evaṃbhūta kramākrama kārya kāraṇa bhāva ādi vicitra vaiśvarūpya pradarśana sāmarthya rūpam aiśvaryam iti etāvat paryavasāyayitavyam
translated: The power of the light itself to display the various forms such as the sequence and non-sequence of causes and effects in this way is the lordship. This much should be concluded.

analyzed: tat ca evam paryavasyati
translated: And that is concluded in this way.

analyzed: yadi prakāśasya vicitra bhāve hetu antaram apākṛtam
translated: If another cause is rejected in the various states of light,

original: tatra prakāśasya avicitrasya krameṇa vicitratākāraṇaṃ pratibimbātmakaṃ tatpratibimbasajātīyaṃ yat tadeva nīlādirūpaṃ bāhyam /
analyzed: tatra prakāśasya avicitrasya krameṇa vicitra tā kāraṇam pratibimba ātmakam tad pratibimba sajātīyam yat tat eva nīla ādi rūpam bāhyam
translated: then the cause of the various states of the light which is not various is the external object which is of the same kind as that reflection, which is of the nature of a reflection, which is the very form of blue, etc.

analyzed: tat ca yadi api anumeyam
translated: And although that [external object] is to be inferred,

original: tathāpi idaṃ nīlamiti pratyakṣeṇa adhyavasāyāt adhyavasāyaprāṇitatvācca pramāṇasthiteḥ pratyakṣavyapadeśyaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: tathā api idam nīlam iti pratyakṣeṇa adhyavasāyāt adhyavasāya prāṇita tvāt ca pramāṇa sthiteḥ pratyakṣa vyapadeśyam bhaviṣyati
translated: nevertheless, because of the ascertainment by perception that this is blue, and because the establishment of a means of knowledge is animated by ascertainment, it will be designated as perception.

analyzed: bāhya artha vāda ukathitam iti hetu antaram anumīyamāna bāhya rūpam āśaṅkyamāna tvena darśayati
translated: The statement about external objects is a different reason, showing that the external form which is being inferred is suspected.

original: tattadākasmikābhāso bāhyaṃ cedanumāpayet /🔽na hyabhinnasya bodhasya vicitrābhāsahetutā // / / //
analyzed: tat tat ākasmika ābhāsaḥ bāhyam ced anumāpayet  na hi abhinnasya bodhasya vicitra ābhāsa hetu tā
translated: If the external object were to be inferred from that sudden appearance,🔽then the cause of the various appearances of the non-different cognition would not be...

original: na vāsanāprabodho'tra vicitro hetutāmiyāt /🔽tasyāpi tatprabodhasya vaicitrye kiṃ nibandhanam // / / //
analyzed: na vāsanā prabodhaḥ utra vicitraḥ hetu tām iyāt  tasya api tad prabodhasya vaicitrye kim nibandhanam
translated: Nor could the various awakenings of latent impressions here become the cause.🔽For what is the basis of the variety of that awakening of it?

analyzed: iha bodhaḥ tāvat abhinnaḥ
translated: Here, the cognition is indeed non-different.

analyzed: prakāśa mātram eva hi asya paramārthaḥ
translated: For its ultimate reality is mere manifestation.

analyzed: prakāśa adhikam yadi nīlasya rūpam
translated: If the form of the blue is more than manifestation,

original: tarhi tat aprakāśarūpam iti na prakāśeta /
analyzed: tarhi tat a prakāśa rūpam iti na prakāśeta
translated: then it would not manifest as a form that is not manifest.

analyzed: atha tathā prakāśa tvam eva asya rūpam
translated: Or if its form is indeed just manifestation,

analyzed: pīta prakāśaḥ katham syāt
translated: how could it be the manifestation of yellow?

analyzed: atha api kramika nīla pīta ādi prakāśa rūpam eva tasya svarūpam
translated: Or if its own form is indeed just the form of the successive manifestations of blue, yellow, and so on,🔽then...

analyzed: nīla ādi ābhāsa śūnyaḥ ham iti prakāśaḥ svāpa ādi avasthāsu na syāt
translated: The manifestation I am devoid of the appearances of blue etc. would not occur in states such as sleep.

analyzed: tasmāt prakāśaḥ prakāśaḥ eva
translated: Therefore, manifestation is manifestation itself.

original: aṇumātramapi na rūpāntaram asya asti iti abhinno bodhaḥ /
analyzed: aṇu mātram api na rūpa antaram asya asti iti abhinnaḥ bodhaḥ
translated: It has no other form even as small as an atom, thus cognition is undifferentiated.

original: tasya ca abhinnasya kadācit nīlābhāsatā kadācit pītābhāsatā iti ye vicitrābhāsāḥ tatra kāraṇatvam hi yasymāt na upapannam hetau abhinne kāryabhedasya
analyzed: tasya ca abhinnasya kadācid nīla ābhāsa tā kadācid pīta ābhāsa tā iti ye vicitra ābhāsāḥ tatra kāraṇa tvam hi na upapannam hetau abhinne kārya bhedasya  /
translated: And of that undifferentiated [cognition], sometimes there is the appearance of blue, sometimes the appearance of yellow, thus the various appearances. There, the causality of that is not tenable, because the difference of effects is

original: asaṃbhavāt /🔽tasmāt sa sa vicitranīlapītādirūpa ākāsmiko 'jñātapratyakṣasiddhahetukaḥ san bāhyaṃ🔽vijñānagatapratibimbātmakasvasvabhāvasaṃpādakam aucityāt nijarūpasadṛśaṃ kramopanipatadrūpabahutarabhedātmakaṃ
analyzed: asaṃbhavāt  tasmāt sa sa vicitra nīla pīta ādi rūpaḥ ākāsmikaḥ jñāta pratyakṣa siddha hetukaḥ san bāhyam  vijñāna gata pratibimba ātmaka sva svabhāva saṃpādakam aucityāt nija rūpa sadṛśam krama upanipatat rūpa bahutara bheda ātmakam
translated: impossible when the cause is undifferentiated.🔽Therefore, that [cognition] with the various forms of blue, yellow etc., being causeless, established by unknown perception, producing its own nature in the form of a reflection in consciousness,🔽convinces by inference, as befits, an external object that is completely different from cognition, having many forms that fall in sequence, having a nature consisting of many differences,

original: jñānāt sarvathā pṛthagbhūtam anumāpayati iti saṃbhāvayate bāhyārthavādī // //
analyzed: jñānāt sarvathā pṛthak bhūtam anumāpayati iti saṃbhāvayate bāhya artha vādī
translated: similar to its own form. Thus the proponent of external objects imagines [it].

analyzed: na ca asya idam saṃbhāvanā mātram
translated: And this [inference] is not mere imagination for him.

analyzed: api tu niścaya paryavasāyi eva bhavati
translated: But it ends in certainty.

original: tathā hi vijñānavādinā yo hetuḥ vaicitrye vāsanāprabodhalakṣaṇa uktaḥ sa na upapadyate /
analyzed: tathā hi vijñāna vādinā yaḥ hetuḥ vaicitrye vāsanā prabodha lakṣaṇaḥ uktaḥ sa na upapadyate
translated: For thus, the cause that the proponent of consciousness has stated for the diversity, which is characterized by the awakening of latent impressions, is not reasonable.

original: smṛtijanakaḥ saṃskāro vāsanā iti tāvat prasiddham /
analyzed: smṛti janakaḥ saṃskāraḥ vāsanā iti tāvat prasiddham
translated: It is well-known that a latent impression that generates memory is a latent impression.

analyzed: iha tu anubhava vaicitrya hetuḥ paryeṣaṇīyaḥ vartate
translated: But here, a cause for the diversity of experience is being sought.

original: astu vā nīlādyābhāsasaṃpādanasāmarthyarūpā jñānasya yogyatātmikā śaktiḥ vāsanā /
analyzed: astu vā nīla ādi ābhāsa saṃpādana sāmarthya rūpā jñānasya yogya tā ātmikā śaktiḥ vāsanā
translated: Or let there be a latent impression in the form of the potentiality of consciousness, which has the nature of being fit for producing the appearance of blue etc.

analyzed: tasyāḥ ca sva kārya saṃpādana unmukhyam prabodhaḥ
translated: And the awakening of that is the tendency to produce its own effect.

analyzed: tatas bodheṣu ābhāsa vaicitryam iti
translated: From that, there is diversity of appearance in cognitions.

original: tatrāpi tu brūmaḥ iha yadyāpi ābhāsānāṃ jñānāntarvartinām apāramārthikatvaṃ saṃvṛtisattvam ucyetāpi /
analyzed: tatra api tu brūmaḥ iha yadi api ābhāsānām jñāna antarvartinām apāramārthika tvam saṃvṛti sattvam ucyeta api
translated: But even in that case, we say: Here, even if the unreality of appearances, which exist within consciousness, is said to be conventional existence,

original: tathāpi yadeṣāṃ tad vastusadeva aṅgīkāryam avastunaḥ sarvasāmarthyavirahitālakṣaṇasya kāryasaṃpādanaprāṇitasāmārtthyātmakasvabhāvānupapatteḥ
analyzed: tathā api yat eṣām tat vastu sat eva aṅgīkāryam avastunaḥ sarva sāmarthya virahita alakṣaṇasya kārya saṃpādana prāṇita sāmārtthya ātmaka svabhāva anupapatteḥ
translated: nevertheless, their being that [conventional existence] must be accepted as real. Because it is not possible for a non-entity, which is characterized by being devoid of all capacities, to have an essence consisting of the capacity to produce an effect.

original: evaṃsthite yā etā vāsanā ābhāsakāraṇatvena iṣyante /
analyzed: evaṃsthite yāḥ etāḥ vāsanāḥ ābhāsa kāraṇa tvena iṣyante
translated: In this situation, those latent impressions that are accepted as the cause of appearances,

analyzed: tāsām bodhāt yadi bhinnam rūpam
translated: if their form is different from consciousness,

analyzed: tat ca paramārtha sat
translated: And that is ultimately real.

analyzed: tat ayam śabda antara pracchannaḥ bāhya artha vāda prakāraḥ eva
translated: And this is just the external object theory, disguised under different terminology.

analyzed: atha saṃvṛti sat
translated: Now, if it is conventionally real,

analyzed: tarhi tena rūpeṇa kāraṇatā anupapattiḥ
translated: then the causal relation is not possible in that form.

original: tathā yena rūpeṇa āsāṃ pāramārthikatā tena kāraṇatā /
analyzed: tathā yena rūpeṇa āsām pāramārthika tā tena kāraṇa tā
translated: In that way, the causal relation is in the form in which they are ultimately real.

original: tat tarhi jñānamātraṃ tacca abhinnam iti nīlādyābhāsarūpasya kāryabhedasya asiddhiḥ /
analyzed: tat tarhi jñāna mātram tat ca abhinnam iti nīla ādi ābhāsa rūpasya kārya bhedasya asiddhiḥ
translated: But then that is just consciousness, and that is non-different, so the effect in the form of the appearance of blue etc. is not established.

original: evaṃ vāsanānām abicitratve tatprabodho vicitra iti kā pratyāśā /
analyzed: evam vāsanānām a vicitra tve tad prabodhaḥ vicitraḥ iti kā pratyāśā
translated: In the same way, if the latent impressions are not variegated, what hope is there that their awakening will be variegated?

analyzed: bhavantu vā vāsanāḥ bhinnāḥ
translated: Or let the latent impressions be different.

original: tathāpi bodhamātrātiriktasya deśakālabhāvādeḥ prabodhakābhimatasya vicitrasya kāraṇasya abhāvāt prabodho'vicitra iti eka eva prabodhaḥ iti
analyzed: tathā api bodha mātra atiriktasya deśa kāla bhāva ādeḥ prabodhaka abhimatasya vicitrasya kāraṇasya abhāvāt prabodhaḥ vicitraḥ iti ekaḥ eva prabodhaḥ iti
translated: Even so, because of the absence of a variegated cause, such as space, time, etc., which are supposed to awaken, the awakening is not variegated, so there is only one awakening.

analyzed: samam eva nīla ādi vaicitryam bhāseta
translated: Therefore, the variegation of blue etc. would appear equally.

original: atha svasaṃtānavartīni jñānāntarāṇi vicitrāṇi prabodhakāraṇāni iti /
analyzed: atha sva saṃtāna vartīni jñāna antarāṇi vicitrāṇi prabodha kāraṇāni iti
translated: Or if the various other cognitions occurring in one's own continuum are the variegated causes of awakening,

analyzed: tat asat
translated: that is not so.

original: sukhaduḥkhanīkapīlādipūrvāparādideśakālabhedasya vijñānamātrarūpatve vijñānasya ca prakāśamātrapramārthatāyāṃ svarūpabhedāsaṃbhave tathā bodhavailakṣaṇyānupapatteḥ
analyzed: sukha duḥkha nīka pīla ādi pūrva apara ādi deśa kāla bhedasya vijñāna mātra rūpa tve vijñānasya ca prakāśa mātra pramā artha tāyām svarūpa bheda asaṃbhave tathā bodha vailakṣaṇya anupapatteḥ
translated: When the difference of place and time, such as east and west, before and after, of the groups of pleasure and pain, etc., is of the nature of mere consciousness, and when consciousness is essentially mere light, and there is no possibility of difference in its nature, then the difference in cognition is not possible.

analyzed: para pramātṛ rūpeṣu bodha antariṣu saṃtāna antara śabda vācyeṣu api tulyaḥ yam a vailakṣaṇya prakāraḥ
translated: In the case of other cognizers, which are called other continua, this same kind of non-difference is applicable.

analyzed: tatra api parakīya abhimatasya kṛśa sthūla ādeḥ kāyasya
translated: There also, of the body, which is considered to belong to another, as thin or fat, etc.

analyzed: śvāsa praśvāsa ādeḥ prāṇasya
translated: Of the life-force, such as inhalation and exhalation, etc.

analyzed: sukha duḥkha ādeḥ dhī guṇasya
translated: Of the qualities of the mind, such as pleasure, pain, etc.

original: anumātrabhimatasaṃbinmātrarūpābhede paratvaṃ kasya bhavet iti na vidmaḥ /
analyzed: anumātṛ abhimata saṃbid mātra rūpa abhede paratvam kasya bhavet iti na vidmaḥ
translated: In the non-difference of the mere connection, which is considered to be mere cognition, whose otherness can there be? We do not know.

analyzed: bodhasya tad niṣṭhasya iti ced
translated: If it is said that it belongs to the cognition that is based on that,

original: so 'pi pramāṇena yadi na siddhaḥ tat asat eva /
analyzed: so pi pramāṇena yadi na siddhaḥ tat asat eva
translated: if that is not established by a means of knowledge, then it does not exist.

original: siddho 'pi prameyatayā cet tat jaḍa eva /
analyzed: siddhaḥ u pi prameya tayā ced tat jaḍaḥ eva
translated: If it is established, but as an object of knowledge, then it is inert.

original: tathāpi ca kāyādivat eva jñānamātrasvabhāvaḥ svasaṃvinmātrarūpatve paraṃ prati asya asiddheḥ /
analyzed: tathā api ca kāya ādi vat eva jñāna mātra svabhāvaḥ sva saṃvid mātra rūpa tve param prati asya asiddheḥ
translated: Even so, like the body, etc., it is of the nature of mere knowledge. In the case of its being of the nature of mere self-awareness, it is not established for another.

original: nanu vyāhārādikriyā svātmani icchayā vyāhareyam ityevaṃrūpayā hetubhāvena vyāptā dṛṣṭā tat caitrakāye'pi tayā taddhetukayā bhāvyam /
analyzed: nanu vyāhāra ādi kriyā sva ātmani icchayā vyāhareyam iti evaṃrūpayā hetu bhāvena vyāptā dṛṣṭā tat caitra kāye pi tayā tad hetukayā bhāvyam
translated: But isn't the action of speaking and so on pervaded by the causal state of the form I wish to speak in one's own self? And that should exist in the body of Caitra also, caused by that [wish].

original: na ca matsaṃtatipatitā samīhā asti iti svasaṃvedanena niścitam /
analyzed: na ca mad saṃtati patitā samīhā asti iti sva saṃvedanena niścitam
translated: And it is ascertained by one's own awareness that there is no wish that has fallen into one's own continuum.

analyzed: tatas ca para samīhā siddhi ati
translated: Therefore, the wish of another is established.

analyzed: tat eva saṃtāna antaram iti
translated: That itself is another continuum.

original: atrocyate iha anumātuḥ vyāhārābhāso dvidhā bhavati vyāptigrahaṇakāle 'vicchedaprāṇo 'haṃ vyāharāmi ityevaṃrūpaḥ /🔽anumānāvasare ca vyāharati ayam iti vicchedajīvita iti anyasya vyāptiḥ gṛhītā anyaśca ābhāsaḥ katham idānīṃ hetuḥ syāt /
analyzed: atra ucyate iha anumātuḥ vyāhāra ābhāsaḥ dvidhā bhavati vyāpti grahaṇa kāle viccheda prāṇaḥ ham vyāharāmi iti evaṃrūpaḥ  anumāna avasare ca vyāharati ayam iti viccheda jīvitaḥ iti anyasya vyāptiḥ gṛhītā anyaḥ ca ābhāsaḥ katham idānīm hetuḥ syāt
translated: To this it is said: Here, the appearance of the speaker of the inferrer is twofold: at the time of grasping the pervasion, it is of the form I speak with an unbroken life;🔽and at the time of inference, it is of the form He speaks with a life of discontinuity. How then can the pervasion of another be grasped and the appearance of another be the reason?

original: vyāharati iti ābhāsasya hetuḥ avidita eva iti kathaṃ tato hetoḥ samīhā anumīyeta /
analyzed: vyāharati iti ābhāsasya hetuḥ aviditaḥ eva iti katham tatas hetoḥ samīhā anumīyeta
translated: If the appearance he speaks is unknown as the reason, how can the wish be inferred from that reason?

original: kiṃ ca vyāharati ayam iti yaḥ pramātrantare 'numātṛsaṃmate vicchinnatayā avabhāsaḥ so'numeyasaṃmatāyāḥ paramīhāyāḥ kathaṃ kāryaḥ syāt /
analyzed: kim ca vyāharati ayam iti yaḥ pramātṛ antare nu mātṛ saṃmate vicchinna tayā avabhāsaḥ saḥ nu meya saṃmatāyāḥ param īhāyāḥ katham kāryaḥ syāt
translated: Moreover, how can this [appearance] which is manifested as disconnected to another cognizer who is accepted as the inferrer, be the effect of the supreme will which is accepted as the object of inference?

original: tasyā hi vyāharāmītyābhāsaḥ kāryo yo'sau avicchedajīvitaḥ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ hi vyāharāmi iti ābhāsaḥ kāryaḥ yaḥ asau a viccheda jīvitaḥ
translated: For, the effect of that [supreme will] is the appearance I am speaking, which has the life of non-separation.

original: na ca avicchedamayasya vicchedamayaḥ kāryam iti yuktaṃ tathābhūtakāryakāraṇabhāvagrahaṇopāyābhāvāt /
analyzed: na ca aviccheda mayasya viccheda mayaḥ kāryam iti yuktam tathābhūta kārya kāraṇa bhāva grahaṇa upāya abhāvāt
translated: And it is not proper that the effect of that which is of the nature of non-separation should be of the nature of separation, because there is no means of apprehending such a relation of cause and effect.

original: na hi svātmani yo'yam avicchinnābhāsaḥ sa paratra vicchinnaṃ vyāharati ityevaṃrūpam ābhāsaṃ janayati iti kenacit pramāṇena siddham /
analyzed: na hi sva ātmani yaḥ ayam avicchinna ābhāsaḥ sa paratra vicchinnam vyāharati iti evaṃrūpam ābhāsam janayati iti kenacid pramāṇena siddham
translated: For, it is not established by any means of valid knowledge that this appearance which is of the nature of non-separation in one's own self generates an appearance of the form it speaks as disconnected to another, in this way.

analyzed: para siddhi pūrvaka tvāt asya arthasya
translated: Because this matter [of the relation of cause and effect] is preceded by the establishment of the other [cognizer].

analyzed: para pramātṛ siddhaḥ ca evaṃbhūta artha adhīna tvena itaretara āśrayāt
translated: And the establishment of another cognizer is dependent on such a matter, and thus there is a mutual dependence.

original: na ca avaśyan avicchinnāt vicchinnena bhāvyam iti niyamo 'sti vyavhicārāt /
analyzed: na ca avaśyan avicchinnāt vicchinnena bhāvyam iti vyavhicārāt
translated: And there is no rule that something necessarily must be of the nature of separation from that which is of the nature of non-separation, because of deviation [from the rule].

original: na ca vicchinno 'pi ābhāsa upadyatām iti tadanusaṃdhānāt tadutpattiḥ niyatā tatsadbhāve 'pyasyānutpatteḥ tadabhāve ca utpatteḥ /
analyzed: na ca vicchinnaḥ pi ābhāsaḥ upadyatām iti tad anusaṃdhānāt tad utpattiḥ niyatā tad sadbhāve pi asya anutpatteḥ tad abhāve ca utpatteḥ
translated: And even if the manifestation were interrupted, it would not arise, because it arises from the remembrance of that. Its arising is determined by the connection with that. Because it does not arise even when that exists, and because it arises when that does not exist.

original: vicchinna ābhāsaḥ paratra utpadyatām iti yā samīhā tayā saha pratra utpannasya vicchinnābhāsasya kāryakāraṇabhāvagrahaṇameva parāsiddhau na
analyzed: vicchinnaḥ ābhāsaḥ paratra utpadyatām iti yā samīhā tayā saha pratra utpannasya vicchinna ābhāsasya kārya kāraṇa bhāva grahaṇam eva para asiddhau na
translated: If there were a desire that the interrupted manifestation should arise in another, then the apprehension of the relation of cause and effect of the interrupted manifestation that arises in that would be impossible for the other.

analyzed: iti vyāpteḥ eva asiddhiḥ
translated: Thus, the pervasion itself is not established.

original: pramātrantarāṇi ca yadi bhinnāni tadā tanniṣṭhānām avabhāsānāṃ bheda eva jñānādavyatiriktaṃ ca iti nyāyāt /
analyzed: pramātṛ antarāṇi ca yadi bhinnāni tadā tad niṣṭhānām avabhāsānām bhedaḥ eva jñānāt avyatiriktam ca iti nyāyāt
translated: And if the other cognizers are different, then the manifestations based on them are indeed different, because of the principle that knowledge is not different from the object.

original: tataśca ekābhāsaniṣṭhatvābhāvāt ekābhāsaviśrāntaḥ saṃbhūya pramātḥṇāṃ vyavahāro na syāt iti anyosaṃbhavaḥ yat prameyaṃ bodhāt bhinnaṃ 🔽bhavati iti /
analyzed: tatas ca eka ābhāsa niṣṭha tva abhāvāt eka ābhāsa viśrāntaḥ saṃbhūya pramātḥṇām vyavahāraḥ na syāt iti anya usaṃbhavaḥ yat prameyam bodhāt bhinnam  bhavati iti
translated: And from that, because of the absence of being based on a single manifestation, the collective activity of the cognizers resting on a single manifestation would not occur. This is the possibility of another. The object of knowledge becomes different from cognition.

original: sahopalambhaniyamādeḥ anaikāntikatvāt nīlapītādināpi prameyarāśinā kim apakṛtam /
analyzed: saha upalambha niyama ādeḥ anaikāntika tvāt nīla pīta ādinā api prameya rāśinā kim apakṛtam
translated: Because of the non-exclusiveness of the rule of simultaneous apprehension, what harm has been done even by the object of knowledge such as blue, yellow, etc.?

analyzed: yena asya sva rūpa viśrāntiḥ na sahyate
translated: By which its resting in its own nature is not tolerated.

analyzed: tasmāt pramātṛ antarāṇām api asiddhiḥ eva
translated: Therefore, the non-establishment of other cognizers is itself.

original: siddhau vā sarvapramātrantargatā ābhāsā ekaikatra paratra ābhāsavaicitryahetuṃ vāsanodvodhavaicitryaṃ janayeyuḥ niyame hetvantarābhāvāt iti
analyzed: siddhau vā sarva pramātṛ antargatāḥ ābhāsāḥ eka ekatra paratra ābhāsa vaicitrya hetum vāsanā udvodha vaicitryam janayeyuḥ niyame hetu antara abhāvāt iti
translated: If established, then all the appearances included in each cognizer would generate the diversity of the causes of the diversity of appearances in each other, because there is no other cause for the restriction.

analyzed: tathā api na nīla ādi vaicitrya siddhiḥ
translated: Even so, the diversity of blue etc. is not established.

original: evaṃ vāsanānāṃ tadudbodhahetūnāṃ ca vicitrāṇām anupapattireva /
analyzed: evam vāsanānām tad udbodha hetūnām ca vicitrāṇām anupapattiḥ eva
translated: Thus, the diversity of latent impressions and their causes is not logically possible.

analyzed: tatas ca sthitam etat
translated: And from that, this is established.

original: abhinno bodhaḥ tasya ākasmikābhāsabhedahetutvānupapatteḥ bāhyo'rtho'numeyaḥ saṃbhāvyate iti yadi bāhyārthavādinā ucyate iti ślokadvayārthaḥ
analyzed: abhinnaḥ bodhaḥ tasya ākasmika ābhāsa bheda hetu tva anupapatteḥ bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ anumeyaḥ saṃbhāvyate iti yadi bāhya artha vādinā ucyate iti śloka dvaya arthaḥ
translated: If it is said by the proponent of external objects that cognition is undifferentiated, and that the external object is inferred because the cause of the sudden diversity of appearances is not logically possible, this is the meaning of the two verses.

analyzed: ced śabdaḥ śloka dvaya vākya artha śaṅkā dyotakaḥ
translated: The word if indicates doubt about the meaning of the sentence of the two verses.

analyzed: evam āśaṅkyamāna tvena para saṃbhāvanā dṛḍhā darśitā
translated: Thus, the firm appearance of the suspicion of others is shown.

original: adhunā tu enāṃ saṃbhāvanāṃ śithilayituṃ tāvadāha
analyzed: adhunā tu enām saṃbhāvanām śithilayitum tāvat āha
translated: Now, in order to loosen this suspicion, he says this:

analyzed: syāt etat avabhāseṣu teṣu eva avasite sati
translated: This may be so, if it is concluded that the appearances themselves are real,

analyzed: vyavahāre kim anyena bāhyena anupapattinā
translated: what is the use of another external object in worldly transactions, which is logically impossible?

original: syādetat iti pūrvoktasaṃbhāvanābhyupagame yadā vyākhyāyate tadā kiṃ tu iti vākyaśeṣeṇa tacchaithilyaviṣayaṃ saṃbhāvanāntaraṃ śeṣaślokena darśayate
analyzed: syāt etat iti pūrva ukta saṃbhāvanā abhyupagame yadā vyākhyāyate tadā kim tu iti vākyaśeṣeṇa tad śaithilya viṣayam saṃbhāvanā antaram śeṣa ślokena darśayate  /
translated: This may be said - when the above-mentioned possibility is accepted and explained, then in the remainder of the sentence but the author shows another possibility regarding the looseness of that [possibility] with the remaining verse.

analyzed: iti vyākhyeyam
translated: This is to be explained.

original: yadi tu adhyāhāro na sahyate tadā syādetaditi idamapi saṃbhāvanāntaraṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi tu adhyāhāraḥ na sahyate tadā syāt etat iti idam api saṃbhāvanā antaram syāt
translated: But if the insertion is not acceptable, then this may be said - this is also another possibility.

original: yadanena ślokena ucyate iti ekavākyatayā yojyam /
analyzed: yat anena ślokena ucyate iti ekavākyatayā yojyam
translated: This is to be connected as a single sentence with what is said by this verse.

original: anayāpi kaṣṭakalpanayā bāhyān arthān prasādhayatā bhavatā taiḥ na kiṃcit kartavyam /
analyzed: anayā api kaṣṭa kalpanayā bāhyān arthān prasādhayatā bhavatā taiḥ na kiṃcid kartavyam
translated: Even by this difficult construction, if you establish external objects, nothing is to be done by them for you.

analyzed: ābhāsaiḥ eva taiḥ bhavatā abhyupagataiḥ vyavahāra siddheḥ
translated: Because the business is accomplished by those appearances accepted by you.

original: na hi nityānumeyena kaścit vyavahāra iti kiṃ bāhyena /
analyzed: na hi nitya anumeyena kaścid vyavahāraḥ iti kim bāhyena
translated: For no one has any business with the eternal and inferred [object]. What is the use of the external [object]?

original: yatra sādhakaṃ ca nāsti pramāṇam /🔽bādhakaṃ ca prakāśāt bhede anumeyatayāpi prakāśanābhāva iti tāvat mukhyam /
analyzed: yatra sādhakam ca na asti pramāṇam  bādhakam ca prakāśāt bhede anumeya tayā api prakāśana abhāvaḥ iti tāvat mukhyam
translated: Where there is no valid means of knowledge to establish [the external object],

analyzed: abhyuścaya bādhakaḥ tu avayavinaḥ vṛtti anupapattiḥ
translated: and there is no means of knowledge to refute [the external object], then the primary [means of knowledge] is the absence of manifestation even as an inferred object due to the difference from manifestation.🔽But the secondary means of knowledge refuting [the external object] is the impossibility of the operation of the whole.

analyzed: samavāya asiddhiḥ
translated: The non-establishment of inherence.

analyzed: kampa akampa āvaraṇa anāvaraṇa rakta arakta digbhāga bheda ādi viruddha dharma yogaḥ
translated: The connection with contradictory properties such as trembling and not trembling, covered and uncovered, red and not red in different directions, etc.

original: aṇusaṃcayabāhyavāde 'pi saṃcayasya anyasya abhāve paramāṇava eva /
analyzed: aṇu saṃcaya bāhya vāde pi saṃcayasya anyasya abhāve paramāṇavaḥ eva
translated: Even in the doctrine of external atoms and collections, in the absence of any other collection, it is only the atoms themselves.

original: te ca yadi saṃyujyante nirantaratayā tat avaśyaṃ digbhāgabhedaḥ /
analyzed: te ca yadi saṃyujyante nirantara tayā tat avaśyam diś bhāga bhedaḥ
translated: And if they combine without interstices, then there must be a difference in the directions.

original: evanākṣe ṣaṭsu dikṣu saṃcīyamāneṣu ṣaṭsu aṇuṣu madhyamasya paramāṇoḥ yatraiva dhāmni eko lagnaḥ tatraiva yadi aparaḥ tat ekaparamāṇumātratā
analyzed: ṣaṭsu dikṣu saṃcīyamāneṣu ṣaṭsu aṇuṣu madhyamasya paramāṇoḥ yatra eva dhāmni ekaḥ lagnaḥ tatra eva yadi aparaḥ tat eka paramāṇu mātra tā
translated: In this way, when six atoms are collected in the six directions, if the central atom is attached to one place where one is attached, then if another is attached there, it becomes only one atom.

original: atha anyatra ekaḥ anyatar aparaḥ tat avaśyaṃ bhāgabhedāpattiḥ /
analyzed: atha anyatra ekaḥ anyatar aparaḥ tat avaśyam bhāga bheda āpattiḥ
translated: But if one is in another place and another in another, then it must necessarily fall into the category of having parts.

original: iti bhāga eva san /🔽tasyāpi eṣaiva saraṇiḥ iti na kiṃcit avaśiṣyate bāhyaṃ tattvataḥ /
analyzed: iti bhāgaḥ eva san  tasya api eṣā eva saraṇiḥ iti na kiṃcid avaśiṣyate bāhyam tattvataḥ
translated: Thus, being a part itself,🔽its path is the same, so nothing external remains as a reality.

analyzed: na ca etat vācyam mūrtānām eka deśa tva ayogāt
translated: And this should not be said, because it is impossible for material things to have parts.

original: saṃyoge bhinnadeśatvāvyāvṛtteḥ tanniṣṭaṃ dvyaṇukaṃ nāma kāryadravyam aṇuparimāṇam /
analyzed: saṃyoge bhinna deśa tva avyāvṛtteḥ tat niṣṭam dvyaṇukam nāma kārya dravyam aṇu parimāṇam
translated: When there is no cessation of having different places in conjunction, the effect substance called dyad, which is based on that, has atomic size.

analyzed: tebhyaḥ tribhyaḥ mahatkāryam iti
translated: From those three, the great effect arises.

analyzed: avayavi vādaḥ hi ayam
translated: This is the doctrine of the whole.

analyzed: sa ca pūrvam eva apabādhitaḥ
translated: And that has already been refuted before.

original: yacca avyāpyavṛttitvaṃ saṃyogasya ucyate tanniraṃśe kathaṃ saṃgacchatām /
analyzed: yat ca avyāpya vṛtti tvam saṃyogasya ucyate tat niraṃśe katham saṃgacchatām
translated: And as for the non-pervasiveness of conjunction, how can that be reconciled in what is partless?

original: svāśraye hi yadi asau samavaiti kim anyāt asya avaśiṣyate yat na vyāpnuyāt iti /
analyzed: svāśraye hi yadi asau samavaiti kim anyāt asya avaśiṣyate yat na vyāpnuyāt iti
translated: For if it inheres in its own substratum, what else remains of it that it would not pervade?

original: abhyuścayabādhakaṃ ca idam iti na atra asmābhiḥ bharaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: abhyuścaya bādhakam ca idam iti na atra asmābhiḥ bharaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: And this is also a refutation of the objection, so we have not taken up the burden here.

analyzed: vistareṇa ca prajñālaṅkāre darśitam ācārya śaṅkaranandanena
translated: And it has been shown in detail in the Prajñālamkāra by Ācārya Śaṅkaranandana.

original: nanu bādhakaṃ nāma pramāṇasiddhe vastuni na kiṃcit kartuṃ samartham /
analyzed: nanu bādhakam nāma pramāṇa siddhe vastuni na kiṃcid kartum samartham
translated: Now, a refutation is not capable of doing anything to a thing established by valid cognition.

original: tenaiva dṛḍhena pramāṇena bādhakābhimatasya bādhitasya apramāṇatvasaṃpādanāt /
analyzed: tena eva dṛḍhena pramāṇena bādhaka abhimatasya bādhitasya apramāṇa tva saṃpādanāt
translated: Because that firm valid cognition establishes the refuted object, which is considered to be refuted, as being without a valid cognition.

original: darśitaṃ ca iha sādhakaṃ pramāṇaṃ kāryahetuḥ tattadākasmikābhāsa iti kārikayā ityāśaṅkya āha 🔽cidātmaiva hi devo'ntaḥsthitamicchāvaśādbahiḥ /
analyzed: darśitam ca iha sādhakam pramāṇam kārya hetuḥ tat tat ākasmika ābhāsaḥ iti kārikayā iti āśaṅkya āha  cit ātmā eva hi
translated: And a valid means of knowledge that establishes this has been shown here in the verse The effect-reason is a sudden appearance at that time. Anticipating this doubt, he says:

analyzed: yogī iva nirupādānam artha jātam prakāśayet
translated: The divine Self alone, by the power of will, residing within, would manifest the multitude of objects outside, without a cause, like a yogi.

original: iha tāvat svapna smaraṇa manorājya saṃkalpādiṣu nīlādyābhāsavaicitryaṃ bāhyasamarpakahtuvyatirekeṇaiva nirbhāsate iti yadyapi asti
analyzed: iha tāvat svapna smaraṇa manas rājya saṃkalpa ādiṣu nīla ādi ābhāsa vaicitryam bāhya samarpaka htu vyatirekeṇa eva nirbhāsate iti yadi api asti
translated: Here, in the case of dream recollection, imagination, resolution, etc., the variety of appearances such as blue manifests only without an external cause to convey it. Although this possibility exists,

analyzed: saṃbhavaḥ
translated: it is still possible.

original: tathāpi tadābhāsavaicitryam asthairyāt sarvapramātrasādhāraṇyāt pūrvānubhavasaṃskārajatvasaṃbhāvanāt avastu iti śaṅkyeta /
analyzed: tathā api tad ābhāsa vaicitryam asthairyāt sarva pramātṛ sādhāraṇyāt pūrva anubhava saṃskāra ja tva saṃbhāvanāt avastu iti śaṅkyeta
translated: Nevertheless, the variety of appearances may be suspected to be unreal because of their instability, because of their commonality to all cognizers, and because of the possibility that they arise from the impressions of previous experiences.

original: yat punaridaṃ yoginām icchāmātreṇa purasenādivaicitryanirmāṇaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: yat punar idam yoginām icchā mātreṇa pura senā ādi vaicitrya nirmāṇam dṛṣṭam
translated: Now, this creation of variety such as an army, etc. by yogins merely by their will is seen.

original: tatra upādānaṃ prasiddhamṛtkāṣṭhaśukra śoṇi tādivaicitryamayaṃ na saṃbhavatyeva /
analyzed: tatra upādānam prasiddha mṛd kāṣṭha śukra śoṇi tā ādi vaicitrya mayam na saṃbhavati eva
translated: There, the material cause consisting of the variety of well-known clay, wood, semen, blood, etc. simply does not exist.

original: na hi evaṃ vaktuṃ śakyam sarvagatāḥ paramāṇavo yogīcchayā jhaṭiti saṃghaṭitāḥ kāryam ārapsyante iti /
analyzed: na hi evam vaktum śakyam sarvagatāḥ paramāṇavaḥ yogi icchayā jhaṭiti saṃghaṭitāḥ kāryam ārapsyante iti
translated: For it cannot be said in this way: The omnipresent atoms will suddenly come together by the will of the yogin and will begin the effect.

original: yat etat lokaprasiddhakāraṇabhāvānatikramasiddhaye nirūpyate /🔽na ca etat prasiddham pramāṇubhya eva sthūlaṃ ghaṭādi jāyate iti /
analyzed: yat etat loka prasiddha kāraṇa bhāva anatikrama siddhaye nirūpyate  na ca etat prasiddham pramāṇubhyaḥ eva sthūlam ghaṭa ādi jāyate iti
translated: This is examined in order to avoid transgressing the well-known causal nature.🔽And this is not well-known: The gross pot, etc. is produced only from the atoms.

analyzed: kim tu kapāla ādi vyavadhānena
translated: But rather, through the obstruction of the potsherds, etc.

original: tathāpi niyatasahakārisamavalambanam karacaraṇādivyāpāre viśiṣṭadeśakāladharmādhipatyayogaḥ śikṣābhyāsaprakarṣa iti /
analyzed: tathā api niyata sahakāri samavalambanam kara caraṇa ādi vyāpāre viśiṣṭa deśa kāla dharma ādhipatya yogaḥ śikṣā abhyāsa prakarṣaḥ iti
translated: Nevertheless, the possession of the lordship of the particular place and time in the operation of the hands, feet, etc., is the excellence of the practice of training, which is based on the necessary auxiliaries.

original: iyati ca āṃśrīyamāṇe yogī kumbhaṃ nirmimāṇaḥ kumbhakāraprasiddhasanastasāmagrīsanarjanapuraḥsaraṃghaṭaṃ ghaṭayan kumbhakāra eva syāt /
analyzed: iyati ca āṃśrīyamāṇe yogī kumbham nirmimāṇaḥ kumbhakāra prasiddha sana sta sāmagrī sanarjana puraḥsaram ghaṭam ghaṭayan kumbhakāraḥ eva syāt
translated: And when this much is accepted, the yogin, while creating a pot, would be a potter only, producing the pot by first collecting the necessary materials, like a well-known potter.

analyzed: tasmāt prasiddha kāraṇa ullaṅghane kim a saṃcetyamāna paramāṇu ādi upādānakāraṇa antara cintayā iti
translated: Therefore, in transgressing the well-known cause, what is the use of thinking of other material causes like atoms, which are not intended?

original: tatra yogisaṃvida eva sā tādṛśī śaktiḥ yat ābhāsavaicitryarūpam arthajātaṃ prakāśayati iti /🔽tadasti saṃbhavaḥ yat saṃvit eva abhyupagatasvātantryā apratīdhātalakṣaṇāt icchāviśeṣavaśāt
analyzed: tatra yogi saṃvidaḥ eva sā tādṛśī śaktiḥ yat ābhāsa vaicitrya rūpam artha jātam prakāśayati iti  tat asti saṃbhavaḥ yat saṃvid eva abhyupagata svātantryā a pratīdhāta lakṣaṇāt icchā viśeṣa vaśāt
translated: In that case, that is the power of the yogin's consciousness itself, by which it illuminates the variety of objects in the form of appearances.🔽It is possible that even consciousness, whose independence is accepted, by the power of a particular desire characterized by non-obstruction,

original: saṃvido 'nidhikātmatāyā anapāyāt antaḥsthitameva sat bhāvajātam idamityevaṃ prāṇabuddhidehādeḥ
analyzed: saṃvidaḥ nidhika ātma tāyāḥ anapāyāt antar sthitam eva sat bhāva jātam idam iti evam prāṇa buddhi deha ādeḥ
translated: because of the non-abandonment of the nature of consciousness, the group of entities that exist internally, as this, of the vital breath, intellect, body, etc.,

original: vitīrṇakiyanmātrasaṃvidūpāt svātantryaṃ kiṃ na abhyupagamyate svasaṃvedanasiddham /
analyzed: vitīrṇa kiyat mātra saṃvid ūpāt svātantryam kim na abhyupagamyate sva saṃvedana siddham
translated: Why is not the independence of consciousness, which is established by self-awareness, accepted, merely on the basis of the fact that it has been granted a certain amount of knowledge?

analyzed: kim iti hetu antara paryeṣaṇā prayāsena khidyate
translated: Why is one troubled by the effort of searching for another cause?

original: evakāreṇa idamāha sarveṇa tāvat vādinā viṣayavyavasthāpanaṃ saṃvidrūpam anapahnavanīyam ādisiddhaṃ hi tat iti uktam /
analyzed: eva kāreṇa idam āha sarveṇa tāvat vādinā viṣaya vyavasthāpanam saṃvid rūpam anapahnavanīyam ādi siddham hi tat iti uktam
translated: By the word 'only', he says this: First of all, the establishment of the object is the form of consciousness, which must not be denied, for it is primordially established.

original: tasya ca svātantryameva devaśabdanirdiṣṭaṃ cidrūpatvam iti kim aparakāraṇānveṣaṇavyasanitayā /
analyzed: tasya ca svātantryam eva deva śabda nirdiṣṭam cit rūpa tvam iti kim apara kāraṇa anveṣaṇa vyasani tayā
translated: And that is indeed the independence indicated by the word 'God', which is the nature of consciousness. So why be addicted to the trouble of searching for another cause?

original: hi yasmāt evaṃ prakāśayati deva iti saṃbhāvyate /
analyzed: hi yasmāt evam prakāśayati deva iti saṃbhāvyate
translated: For, since it is thus, it is possible that God illuminates.

original: tasmāt kiṃ bāhyena anupapattinā iti pūrveṇa saṃbandhaḥ ////
analyzed: tasmāt kim bāhyena anupapattinā iti pūrveṇa saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Therefore, what is the use of an external impossibility? This is the connection with the previous [verse].

analyzed: nanu evam ubhayathā api saṃbhāvanā anumānam unmiṣati
translated: But in this way, inference based on possibility arises in both cases.

original: tatra kiṃ makurapratibimbitaghaṭādidṛṣṭāntena jñānapratibimbatābhāsavaicitrye vijñānadarpaṇātiriktaṃ tata eva bāhyābhimataṃ hetuṃ kalpayema
analyzed: tatra kim makura pratibimbita ghaṭa ādi dṛṣṭāntena jñāna pratibimba tā ābhāsa vaicitrye vijñāna darpaṇa atiriktam tatas eva bāhya abhimatam hetum kalpayema
translated: There, should we imagine a cause that is externally accepted, apart from the mirror of consciousness, for the variety of appearances as reflections of consciousness, using the example of a pot and so on reflected in a mirror?

original: kiṃ vā yogidṛṣṭāntena saṃvitsvātantryameva hetubhāvena brūyāma /
analyzed: kim vā yogi dṛṣṭāntena saṃvid svātantryam eva hetu bhāvena brūyāma
translated: Or, should we speak of the independence of consciousness itself as the cause, using the example of a yogi?

original: tadidaṃ sāṃśayikaṃ vartate iti āśaṅkya bāhyārthānumānasaṃbhāvanāṃ sūtradvayena apākartumāha
analyzed: tat idam sāṃśayikam vartate iti āśaṅkya bāhya artha anumāna saṃbhāvanām sūtra dvayena apākartum āha
translated: This is doubtful, so fearing the possibility of inferring external objects, he refutes that with two aphorisms.

analyzed: anumānam an ābhāta pūrve na eva iṣṭam indriyam  ābhātam eva bīja ādeḥ ābhāsāt hetu vastunaḥ
translated: The sense organ is not accepted as an inference for what has not appeared before.🔽The appearance is only from the cause, the object, which appears from the seed, etc.

analyzed: ābhāsaḥ punar ābhāsat bāhyasya āsīt kathaṃcana
translated: The appearance of the external object has somehow appeared again.

analyzed: arthasya nā eva tena asya siddhiḥ nā api anumānataḥ
translated: Therefore, its establishment is not by that, nor by inference.

original: na kevalam anantaraślokanirdiṣṭābhiḥ yuktabhiḥ pratyakṣeṇa bāhyo'rtho na bhāsate /
analyzed: na kevalam anantara śloka nirdiṣṭābhiḥ yuktabhiḥ pratyakṣeṇa bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ na bhāsate
translated: Not only is the external object not manifested by the valid means of knowledge indicated in the next verse,

original: iyadeva hi pratyakṣaṃ tacca nīlaṃ bhāti iti svaprakāśasaṃvidrūpaṃ nādhikaṃ kiṃcit iti /
analyzed: iyat eva hi pratyakṣam tat ca nīlam bhāti iti sva prakāśa saṃvid rūpam na adhikam kiṃcid iti
translated: this alone is perception, and that appears as blue. It is the form of self-luminous consciousness, nothing more than that.

original: yāvat anumānenāpi na asya bāhyāsya siddhiḥ iti apiśabdasyābhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: yāvat anumānena api na asya bāhyā asya siddhiḥ iti apiśabdasya abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word also is that its external establishment is not even by inference.

original: tatra anumānam atra naiva pravartitum utsahate /
analyzed: tatra anumānam atra na eva pravartitum utsahate
translated: There, inference is not able to operate at all.

original: pravṛttamapi na prakṛtasiddhim ādavyāt iti anena sūtradvayena upadarśyate /
analyzed: pravṛttam api na prakṛta siddhim ādavyāt iti anena sūtra dvayena upadarśyate
translated: Even if it operates, it will not lead to the establishment of the subject matter, this is shown by these two aphorisms.

analyzed: tatra anumānam vikalpaḥ
translated: Among them, inference is conceptual.

analyzed: sarvaḥ ca ayam vikalpaḥ anubhava mūlaḥ iti prasiddham
translated: And it is well-known that all this conceptualization is rooted in experience.

original: tena yat sarvathā anābhātapūrvam ananubhūtacaraṃ tatra anumānam anumitivyāpāro vikalpātmā naiva kenacit vādinā iṣyate /
analyzed: tena yat sarvathā an ābhāta pūrvam an anubhūta caram tatra anumānam anumiti vyāpāraḥ vikalpa ātmā nā eva kenacid vādinā iṣyate
translated: Therefore, in regard to what has never been perceived at all, what has never been experienced before, no proponent accepts inference, the activity of inferring, which has the nature of conceptualization.

original: nanu bhavatu pratyakṣato dṛṣṭe 'numāne saṃkathā iyam /
analyzed: nanu bhavatu pratyakṣatas dṛṣṭe numāne saṃkathā iyam
translated: Well then, let this discussion be about inference seen through perception.

original: sāmānyato dṛṣṭe tu kiṃ vakṣyasi yathā arthopalabdhyā indriyānumāne /
analyzed: sāmānyatas dṛṣṭe tu kim vakṣyasi yathā artha upalabdhyā indriya anumāne
translated: But what will you say about inference seen in general, like the inference of the senses through the perception of objects?

original: ucyate tatrāpi vikalpena yathā so'rthaḥ spṛśyate tathā anumeya iti sthitiḥ /
analyzed: ucyate tatra api vikalpena yathā saḥ ṛthaḥ spṛśyate tathā anumeyaḥ iti sthitiḥ
translated: It is said that even there, the position is that the object is to be inferred just as it is touched by conceptualization.

original: vikalpaśca na indriyādikam arthaṃ kenacit saṃniveśaviśeṣādinā viśeṣātmanā spṛśati /
analyzed: vikalpaḥ ca na indriya ādikam artham kenacid saṃniveśa viśeṣa ādinā viśeṣa ātmanā spṛśati
translated: And conceptualization does not touch the object, such as the senses, with any particular nature such as a specific arrangement.

original: api tu kiṃcidupalabdheḥ kāraṇam iti amunā svabhāvena /
analyzed: api tu kiṃcid upalabdheḥ kāraṇam iti amunā svabhāvena
translated: But rather, it is the cause of the perception of something, with that nature.

original: sa ca svabhāvaḥ kāraṇatālakṣaṇaḥ pratyakṣagṛhīta eva /
analyzed: sa ca svabhāvaḥ kāraṇa tā lakṣaṇaḥ pratyakṣa gṛhītaḥ eva
translated: And that nature, characterized by the relation of cause and effect, is grasped by perception itself.

original: tathā ca bījāt aṅkuraḥ tantubhyaḥ paṭa ityādau kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ pratyakṣānupalambhabalena tāvat niśceyaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca bījāt aṅkuraḥ tantubhyaḥ paṭaḥ ityādau kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ pratyakṣa anupalambha balena tāvat niśceyaḥ
translated: And in that way, the relation of cause and effect is to be ascertained first by the power of perception and non-perception, as in the case of 'the sprout from the seed, the cloth from the threads' and so on.

original: tatra ca pratyakṣaṃ pratyābhāsaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ bhajate /
analyzed: tatra ca pratyakṣam pratyābhāsam prāmāṇyam bhajate
translated: And there, perception has validity only in relation to appearances.

original: vimarśalakṣaṇasya pramitivyāpārasya ekaikaśabdavācye'rthe pravṛtteḥ tadanusāritvācca pramāṇasya iti vakṣyate /
analyzed: vimarśa lakṣaṇasya pramiti vyāpārasya ekaika śabda vācya ṛthe pravṛtteḥ tad anusāri tvāt ca pramāṇasya iti vakṣyate
translated: It will be said that the operation of cognition, which is characterized by reflection, occurs in relation to an object denoted by each word, and because the means of knowledge follows that.

analyzed: eka abhidhāna viṣaye mitiḥ vastuni abādhitā
translated: Cognition is unobstructed in relation to an object denoted by one word.

original: iti / ābhāsamātraṃ ca sāmānyam iti nir /eṣuate /
analyzed: iti ābhāsa mātram ca sāmānyam iti
translated: And it is established that a universal is merely an appearance.

original: anupalambho'pi anyopalambharūpa ābhāsamātraviśrānta eva iti kāraṇābhāso viśeṣaśūnyaḥ parigṛhīta eva bījāt aṅkura iti pratītau /
analyzed: anupalambhaḥ api anya upalambha rūpaḥ ābhāsa mātra viśrāntaḥ eva iti kāraṇa ābhāsaḥ viśeṣa śūnyaḥ parigṛhītaḥ eva bījāt aṅkuraḥ iti pratītau
translated: Non-apprehension also rests only on mere appearances in the form of the apprehension of something else. Thus, the appearance of the cause, devoid of particulars, is accepted as the sprout from the seed in the cognition.

original: yat yasya niyamam anuvidhatte avyatiriktam tat tasya kāryam iti pratighaṭaṃ mṛttikādirūpahetutadvanmātrasya āmāsāt ////
analyzed: yat yasya niyamam anuvidhatte a vyatiriktam tat tasya kāryam iti pratighaṭam mṛttikā ādi rūpa hetu tadvat mātrasya
translated: That which follows the rule of something is its effect if it is not different from it. Thus, the mere presence of the cause, such as clay, etc., is the cause of each pot, due to the non-apprehension of the effect.

analyzed: ābhāsāt bāhyaḥ
translated: Moreover, the external object is not of the form of an appearance.

analyzed: sa ca ābhāsate iti vipratiṣiddham
translated: And it is contradictory to say that it appears.

original: anābhāse ca nāsti vikalparūpasya anumānasya vyāpāraḥ /
analyzed: anābhāse ca na asti vikalpa rūpasya anumānasya vyāpāraḥ
translated: And in the non-appearance, there is no operation of inference, which is of the form of conceptual thought.
