translated: Those two, namely, the sound and the object characterized by name and form, are reflected upon as having one form, as this is that, and that is the supreme Lord's power, which is of the nature of reflection, shining forth like the self,

analyzed: aham iti anavacchinna tvena bhāti
translated: as I without any limitation.

original: na tu kadācit idantayā vicchinnatvena bhāti vicchinnatvena avabhāse parapratiṣṭhatvāt punarvimarśāntareṇa bhāvyam /
analyzed: na tu kadācid idantayā vicchinna tvena bhāti vicchinna tvena avabhāse para pratiṣṭha tvāt punar vimarśa antareṇa bhāvyam
translated: But it never shines forth as limited by this, and if it shone forth as limited, it would depend on another, and so there would have to be another reflection.

original: tatrāpi evam iti anavasthāto nīlasya prakāśanameva na syāt pratiṣṭhālābhābhāvāt /
analyzed: tatra api evam iti anavasthātaḥ nīlasya prakāśanam eva na syāt pratiṣṭhā lābha abhāvāt
translated: And in that case, there would be no manifestation of blue at all, because of the absence of attainment of a basis.

original: tasmāt sarva eva vimarśaḥ prakāśāt avicchinna eva iti /
analyzed: tasmāt sarva eva vimarśaḥ prakāśāt avicchinna eva iti
translated: Therefore, all reflection is indeed not separate from manifestation.

analyzed: adhyavasā iti  ā taḥ ca upasarga īpāḥ vyā
translated: Adhyavasā (determination).🔽Ā is a prefix. Tvach (skin) is the root.

analyzed: iti aṅ antaḥ striyām
translated: Aṅ is the ending. In the feminine, it is ā.

original: nanu evaṃ sarvasyaiva jñānakalāpasya ahamityeva pratiṣṭhāne vedyabhūmisparśo nāsti vedyabhuvi ca deśakālayogaḥ na tu vedakāṃśe /
analyzed: nanu evam sarvasya eva jñāna kalāpasya aham iti eva pratiṣṭhāne vedya bhūmi sparśaḥ na asti vedya bhuvi ca deśa kāla yogaḥ na tu vedaka aṃśe
translated: Now, if in this way, the entire collection of knowledge is indeed based on I, there is no contact with the realm of the object of knowledge, and the connection of place and time is in the realm of the object of knowledge, not in the part of the knower.

original: deśakālayogābhāve ca yat idaṃ jñānāṃ deśāpekṣayā pramātrādyaṃśāpekṣayā ca sakramatvaṃ lakṣyate tat kathaṃ syāt /
analyzed: deśa kāla yoga abhāve ca yat idam jñānām deśa apekṣayā pramātṛ ādi aṃśa apekṣayā ca sakrama tvam lakṣyate tat katham syāt
translated: And in the absence of a connection with place and time, how could this sequence be observed in knowledge, which depends on place and on the aspects of the cognizer etc.?

analyzed: krama abhāve ca eka tvam eva vastutas bhavet
translated: And in the absence of sequence, there would be only oneness in reality.

original: tataśca jñānasmṛtyādibhistadvān parameśvaraḥ iti yat uktaṃ tat kathaṃ nirvahet ityāśaṅkāṃ śamayan pūrvoktamupasaṃharati
analyzed: tatas ca jñāna smṛti ādibhiḥ tadvān parameśvaraḥ iti yat uktam tat katham nirvahet iti āśaṅkām śamayan pūrva uktam upasaṃharati
translated: And then, how could the statement that the Supreme Lord possesses that [oneness] through knowledge, memory etc. be fulfilled? Thus, dispelling this doubt, he concludes what was said before:

analyzed: kevalam bhinna samvedya deśa kāla anurodhataḥ
translated: Only in accordance with the different cognizable places and times,

analyzed: jñāna smṛti avasāya ādi sakramam pratibhāsate
translated: knowledge, memory, determination etc. appear to have sequence.

analyzed: satyam evam akramam eva saṃvid tattvam
translated: It is true that the essence of consciousness is indeed without sequence.

original: kintu svaśaktivaśāt bhinnatvena bhāsitāni yāni vedyāni teṣāṃ mūrtibhedakṛto yo dūrādūravaitatyāvaitatyādiḥ deśaḥ /
analyzed: kintu sva śakti vaśāt bhinna tvena bhāsitāni yāni vedyāni teṣām mūrti bheda kṛtaḥ yaḥ dūra adūra vaitatya avaitatya ādiḥ deśaḥ
translated: But the cognizable objects that appear as different by the power of its own capacity, their place, which is created by the difference in their forms, such as far, near, extensive, non-extensive etc.,

analyzed: kriyā bheda kṛtaḥ ca yaḥ cira śīghra krama ādi rūpaḥ kālaḥ
translated: and the time, which is created by the difference in their actions, such as long, short etc.,

analyzed: tau anurudhya chāyā mātreṇa abalambya
translated: following those [place and time] only as shadows, not as real,

analyzed: jñāna smaraṇa adhyavasāyānām sva aṃśāḥ iva bhānti niraṃśānām api
translated: the parts of knowledge, memory and determination appear as if they were parts, even though they are partless.

analyzed: tad bhāsamāna aṃśa kṛtaḥ ca sakrama tva avabhāsaḥ paraspara apekṣayā sva aṃśa apekṣayā ca
translated: And the appearance of sequence is due to the part that is illuminated by that [consciousness], in relation to each other and in relation to its own part.

original: yadyapi kālakrama eva sphuṭo vijñāneṣu bhāti na deśakramaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api kāla kramaḥ eva sphuṭaḥ vijñāneṣu bhāti na deśa kramaḥ
translated: Although the sequence of time itself clearly appears in cognitions, not the sequence of space,

original: tathāpi vimūḍhasya parvatasaṃvedanaṃ vitatamiva vadarasaṃvedanaṃ ca sūkṣmamiva bhāti iti deśakramo 'pi darśitaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api vimūḍhasya parvata saṃvedanam vitatam iva vadara saṃvedanam ca sūkṣmam iva bhāti iti deśa kramaḥ pi darśitaḥ
translated: nevertheless, for the deluded one, the perception of a mountain appears as if extensive, and the perception of a jujube fruit appears as if subtle. Thus, the sequence of space is also shown.

original: tena vedyagatakramasvīkārābhāsāt sakramatvam ābhāsamānamapi na apāramārthikam ābhāsamānasya parārthatvāt /
analyzed: tena vedya gata krama svīkāra ābhāsāt sakrama tvam ābhāsamānam api na apāramārthikam ābhāsamānasya parārtha tvāt
translated: Therefore, due to the appearance of accepting the sequence belonging to the object of knowledge, even though the appearance of sequence is apparent, it is not unreal, because what appears is for the sake of another.

original: tataśca yuktamuktam jñānādayo 'sya bhagavataḥ śaktayaḥ iti /
analyzed: tatas ca yuktam uktam jñāna ādayaḥ sya bhagavataḥ śaktayaḥ iti
translated: And hence it is rightly said that knowledge and so on are the powers of this Lord.

analyzed: māyā śaktyā vibhoḥ
translated: By the verse beginning By the power of Māyā of the Lord...

analyzed: iti ślokena svarūpa vaicitryam jñānām darśitam
translated: The diversity of form of knowledge is shown.

original: anena tu deśakālavaicitryam iti viśeṣaḥ / iti śivam ////
analyzed: anena tu deśa kāla vaicitryam iti viśeṣaḥ iti śivam
translated: But by this [verse], the diversity of space and time is shown. Thus, may there be well-being.

original: iti śrīmadācāryābhinavaguptaviracitāyāṃīśvarapratyabhijñāsūtravimarśinyāṃ prathame jñānādhikāre jñānaśaktinirūpaṇaṃ nāma pañcamāhnikam //
analyzed: iti śrīmat ācārya abhinavagupta viracitāyām īśvarapratyabhijñā sūtravimarśinyām prathame jñāna adhikāre jñānaśaktinirūpaṇam nāma pañcama āhnikam
translated: Thus ends the fifth chapter named The Determination of the Power of Knowledge in the first section on knowledge in the Vimarśinī commentary on the Aphorisms of the Recognition of God composed by the illustrious teacher Abhinavagupta.

analyzed: atha ṣaṣṭham āhnikam
translated: Now begins the sixth chapter.

analyzed: sva ātma abheda dhanān bhāvān tad apohana ṭaṅkataḥ
translated: We praise Śiva, who, with the hammer of the negation of those entities that are rich in non-difference from his own self,

analyzed: vhindanyaḥ sva icchayā citra rūpa kṛtam stumaḥ śivaḥ
translated: breaks them at will and creates a variegated form.

analyzed: evam smṛti śaktiḥ jñāna śaktiḥ ca nirūpitā
translated: Thus, the power of memory and the power of knowledge have been described.

original: atha tadubhayānuprāhiṇī apohanaśaktirvitatya ślokaikādaśakena ahaṃ pratyavamarśo yaḥ prakāśātmā ityādinā siddhe sarvasya jīvataḥ ityantena
analyzed: atha tad ubhaya anuprāhiṇī apohana śaktiḥ vitatya śloka ekādaśakena aham pratyavamarśaḥ yaḥ prakāśa ātmā ityādinā siddhe sarvasya jīvataḥ ityantena
translated: Now, the power of negation, which impels both of them, is extensively described with eleven verses beginning with I am the self-reflection which is the essence of light and ending with of all living beings.

original: tatra ślokena pratyavamarśe avikalpo viśeṣaḥ iti sūcyate /
analyzed: tatra ślokena pratyavamarśe avikalpaḥ viśeṣaḥ iti sūcyate
translated: There, by one verse, it is indicated that in self-reflection, there is no conceptualization, a special feature.

analyzed: tatas ślokena śuddhe haṃ pratyavamarśe pohana vyāpāra asaṃbhavaḥ ucyate
translated: Then, by one verse, it is said that in the pure self-reflection, the operation of negation is not possible.

analyzed: tatas sva dṛṣṭau eva tad upapattiḥ iti ślokena
translated: Then, by one verse, its possibility is in one's own vision.

analyzed: dvayena aśuddhasya aham iti avamarśasya vikalpa rūpa tā
translated: Then, by two [verses], the impure form of self-reflection is conceptual.
Then, by one verse, the sleep of continuity is also conceptual.

analyzed: evaṃrūpa anusaṃdhāna ādi rūpam eva parameśvarasya sraṣṭṛ tvam iti ślokena
translated: By one verse, it is said that the form of the Supreme Lord as the creator is of the form of such continuity and so on.

analyzed: tatas prakṛte cit ātmani artha avabhāsasya sattā upasaṃhiyate ślokena
translated: Then, by one verse, the existence of the manifestation of objects in the primordial consciousness is concluded.

analyzed: tatas dvayena tasmai eva artha avabhāsasya anubhava smaraṇa ādau vaicitryam ucyate
translated: Then, by the two, the variety of the manifestation of the object in experience, memory, etc. is described.

analyzed: tad uktiḥ ca prakṛtāyām īśvara rūpa sva ātma pratyabhijñāyām upayujyate iti ślokena
translated: And that statement is useful in the context of the recognition of one's own nature in the form of the Lord. Thus, with a verse.

analyzed: iti āhnikasya tātparyārthaḥ
translated: This is the purport of the chapter.

analyzed: atha grantha arthaḥ vyākhyāyate
translated: Now, the meaning of the text is explained.

analyzed: uktim idam
translated: This is said.

analyzed: vimarśam
translated: The self-awareness of the manifestation, which is of the nature of reflective awareness, is...

original: iti / tatra vimarśo 'bhilāpātmanā śabdena yojita eva /
analyzed: iti tatra vimarśaḥ bhilāpa ātmanā śabdena yojitaḥ eva
translated: There, reflective awareness is indeed connected with speech in the form of verbal expression.

original: tadyojanākṛtaṃ ca vikalparūpatvaṃ śuddhe 'pi parameśvare prāptam /
analyzed: tad yojanā kṛtam ca vikalpa rūpa tvam śuddhe pi parameśvare prāptam
translated: And the form of conceptualization produced by that connection is obtained even in the pure Supreme Lord.

original: na caitadiṣṭaṃ tasya saṃsārapade māthātmanyupapatteḥ ityāśaṅkyāha
analyzed: na ca etat iṣṭam tasya saṃsāra pade mātha ātmani upapatteḥ iti āśaṅkya āha
translated: And this is not accepted, because it is not appropriate in the state of worldly existence. With this doubt in mind, he says:

analyzed: ahaṃpratyavamarśaḥ yaḥ prakāśa ātmā api vāc vapuḥ
translated: The self-awareness which is of the nature of light and also has the form of speech,

original: nāsau vikalpaḥ sa hyukto dvayākṣepī viniścayaḥ // / / //
analyzed: na asau vikalpaḥ sa hi uktaḥ dvaya ākṣepī viniścayaḥ
translated: is not conceptual. It is said that conceptual cognition is a determination that excludes duality.

original: prakāśasya śuddhasaṃvidrūpasya dehādisaṃsparśairanāvilībhūtasya yaḥ ātmā jīvitabhūtaḥ
analyzed: prakāśasya śuddha saṃvid rūpasya deha ādi saṃsparśaiḥ anāvilībhūtasya yaḥ ātmā jīvita bhūtaḥ
translated: The self, which is the life-force, of light, which is of the nature of pure consciousness, which is not defiled by contact with the body and so on,

analyzed: sāra svabhāvaḥ viccheda śūnyaḥ ntar abhyupagama kalpaḥ
translated: The nature of essence is devoid of discontinuity, resting in the form of independence, which is the nature of not looking to another's face, in the form of the acceptance of the internal.

original: aham iti pratyavamarśaḥ asau vikalpo na bhavati /
analyzed: aham iti pratyavamarśaḥ asau vikalpaḥ na bhavati
translated: That self-awareness which is the reflection I is not a conceptualization.

analyzed: vikalpa tva āśaṅkāyām bījam darśayati vāc vapuḥ api iti
translated: He shows the seed of the doubt of being a conceptualization in and also the body of speech.

original: viṣayarūpāt śrotragrāhyāt śabdādanya eva antaravabhāsamānaḥ saṃvidrūpāveśī śabdanātmābhilāpo vāgityanenoktaḥ vakti arthaṃ svādhyāsena
analyzed: viṣaya rūpāt śrotra grāhyāt śabdāt anyaḥ eva antar avabhāsamānaḥ saṃvid rūpa āveśī śabdana ātma abhilāpaḥ vāc iti anena uktaḥ vakti artham svādhyāsena
translated: Speech is said to be the nature of sound that appears internally, which is different from the sound that is the object of the ear, and which is absorbed in the nature of consciousness by the sound of expression. It expresses the meaning by superimposition on itself.

analyzed: saḥ yam iti abhisaṃdhānena
translated: By the intention this is that.

analyzed: yadi vāc vapuḥ
translated: If it is the body of speech,

analyzed: kasmāt na vikalpaḥ
translated: why is it not a conceptualization?

original: āha na hyasya vikalpalakṣaṇamasti /🔽tathā hi vividhā kalpanā vividhatvena ca śaṅkitasya kalpo 'nvavyavacchedanaṃ vikalpaḥ /
analyzed: āha na hi asya vikalpa lakṣaṇam asti  tathā hi vividhā kalpanā vividha tvena ca śaṅkitasya kalpaḥ nu avyavacchedanam vikalpaḥ
translated: He says it does not have the characteristic of a conceptualization.🔽Thus, conceptualization is the determination of what is suspected as various by various means.

analyzed: vividha tvam ca bahnau anagni saṃbhāvanā samāropa nirāse sati bhavat
translated: And various means exist when the superimposition of the possibility of both fire and non-fire is removed.

analyzed: dvayam vahni avahni rūpam samākṣipati
translated: It includes both the form of fire and non-fire.

original: tena vikalpe 'vaśyaṃ tacca niścetavyam atacca apohitavyaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tena vikalpe vaśyam tat ca niścetavyam a tat ca apohitavyam bhavati
translated: Therefore, in a conceptualization, that must necessarily be ascertained and that which is not that must be excluded.🔽And thus...

analyzed: tathā ca
translated: And so🔽

analyzed: bhinnayoḥ avabhāsaḥ hi syāt ghaṭa aghaṭayoḥ dvayoḥ
translated: For there would be the appearance of both the pot and the non-pot, if they were different.

analyzed: prakāśasya iva na anyasya bhedinaḥ tu avabhāsanam
translated: For the appearance is of light, not of anything else that is different.

original: ghaṭe hi dṛṣṭe ghaṭasthāna evāghaṭe 'pi yogyadeśābhimatasthānākramaṇaśīlo vijñānajanakaḥ svakāraṇopanītaḥ saṃbhāvyate paṭādisvabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: ghaṭe hi dṛṣṭe ghaṭa sthāne eva aghaṭe pi yogya deśa abhimata sthāna ākramaṇa śīlaḥ vijñāna janakaḥ sva kāraṇa upanītaḥ saṃbhāvyate paṭa ādi svabhāvaḥ
translated: For when a pot is seen, what is capable of occupying the same place as the pot, which is capable of occupying the place intended to be occupied by the non-pot, which is produced by its own cause and is presented, is imagined to be of the nature of a cloth or something else.

original: ato ghaṭāghaṭayordvayoravabhāvasasya saṃbhāvanāt samāropaḥ sāvakāśo bhavati /
analyzed: atas ghaṭa aghaṭayoḥ dvayoḥ avabhāva sasya saṃbhāvanāt samāropaḥ sa avakāśaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, since the appearance of both the pot and the non-pot is possible, superimposition has an opportunity.

original: aghaṭasya satyārope niṣedhanalakṣaṇopohanavyāpāraḥ iti tadanuprāṇitā vikalparūpatā ghaṭa ityetasya niścayasya /
analyzed: aghaṭasya sati ārope niṣedhana lakṣaṇa upohana vyāpāraḥ iti tad anuprāṇitā vikalpa rūpa tā ghaṭaḥ iti etasya niścayasya
translated: When there is superimposition of the non-pot, the function of exclusion, which is characterized by negation, is supported by it. Therefore, the form of exclusion, which is the life of that [superimposition], is the certainty that [the object] is a pot.

original: liṅ saṃbhāvanāyām /🔽yastvayaṃ prakāśo nāma tasya sthāne yaḥ saṃbhāvyate sa tāvadaprakāśarūpo na bhavati tulyakakṣasya hi saṃbhāvanaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: liṅ saṃbhāvanāyām  yaḥ tu ayam prakāśaḥ nāma tasya sthāne yaḥ saṃbhāvyate sa tāvat aprakāśa rūpaḥ na bhavati tulya kakṣasya hi saṃbhāvanam bhavati
translated: The suffix 'lin' (in the word 'sambhāvanā') indicates possibility.🔽But that which is imagined to be in the place of what is called light is not of the nature of non-light. For there is possibility of what is of equal status.

original: na ca yatprakāśena kartavyaṃ tadaprakāśasya kadācit dṛṣṭam saṃbhāvanāropaṇādibalādeva ca asyāprakāśarūpatvaṃ vighaṭeta /
analyzed: na ca yad prakāśena kartavyam tat aprakāśasya kadācid dṛṣṭam saṃbhāvanā āropaṇa ādi balāt eva ca asya aprakāśa rūpa tvam vighaṭeta
translated: And what is to be done by light has never been seen of what is non-light. And the nature of being non-light would be destroyed by the power of possibility and superimposition itself.

analyzed: atas prakāśa tulyasya anyasya aprakāśa rūpasya bhedinaḥ tad tulya kakṣyasya apohana ātmaka bhedana vyāpāra asāhiṣṇoḥ avabhāsanam eva nā asti
translated: Therefore, of something similar to light, which is not of the nature of light, which is different, which is in the same position as that [light], which is not capable of the operation of exclusion, which is the nature of difference, there is no manifestation at all.

analyzed: tad abhāve kasya apoṣṭhanam
translated: In the absence of that, what is to be excluded?

analyzed: avabhāsa saṃbhave pi prakāśa rūpa tvam eva
translated: Even in the possibility of manifestation, it is of the nature of light.

original: na ca prakāśasya svarūpadeśakālabhedo yena dvitīyaḥ prakāśa ekasmādapohyeteti /
analyzed: na ca prakāśasya sva rūpa deśa kāla bhedaḥ yena dvitīyaḥ prakāśaḥ ekasmāt apohyeta iti
translated: And there is no difference in the form, place, or time of light, by which a second light is to be excluded from one.

original: hīti / yasmādevaṃ tato dvayābhāvādpohāsaṃbhave vikalparūpatvābhāvāt cinmātre parāmarśātmani ahamiti pratyavamarśa eva /
analyzed: hi iti yasmāt evam tatas dvaya abhāvāt poha asaṃbhave vikalpa rūpa tva abhāvāt cit mātre parāmarśa ātmani aham iti pratyavamarśaḥ eva
translated: Thus. Since it is so, from the non-existence of duality, from the impossibility of exclusion, from the absence of the form of an option, in pure consciousness, which is of the nature of reflection, there is only the reflexive awareness I, not an option.

analyzed: na tu vikalpaḥ
translated: Not an option.

original: nanu ghaṭe pariniṣthitarūpe dṛṣṭe taddarśanamupajīvatā vikalpena kathamaghaṭasya niṣedhanaṃ kriyate /
analyzed: nanu ghaṭe pariniṣthita rūpe dṛṣṭe tad darśanam upajīvatā vikalpena katham aghaṭasya niṣedhanam kriyate
translated: But when a pot is seen as having a well-established form, how is the exclusion of non-pot made by the option that depends on the perception of that [pot]?

analyzed: na hi a ghaṭasya kenacid nāma api gṛhītam
translated: For the name of non-pot is not grasped by anyone.

analyzed: aghaṭa vāsanā api ghaṭe dṛṣṭe kathaṃkāram prabudhyatām
translated: And how can the impression of non-pot awaken when a pot is seen?

original: satyam / evaṃ śākyaḥ paryanuyojyo na tu vayam / yataḥ
analyzed: satyam evam śākyaḥ paryanuyojyaḥ na tu vayam yatas
translated: True, the Śākyas should be questioned about this, not us. Because

analyzed: tad a tad pratibhā bhājā mātrā eva a tad vyapohanāt
translated: from the mere exclusion of that which is not, by that which possesses the manifestation of that and that which is not,

analyzed: tat niścayana muktaḥ hi vikalpaḥ ghaṭaḥ iti ayam
translated: For this conceptualization jar is said to be the ascertainment of that.

original: iha pramātā nāma pramāṇādatiriktaḥ pramāsu svatantraḥ saṃyojanaviyojanādyādhānavaśāt kartā darśitaḥ /
analyzed: iha pramātā nāma pramāṇāt atiriktaḥ pramāsu svatantraḥ saṃyojana viyojana ādi ādhāna vaśāt kartā darśitaḥ
translated: Here, the knower is shown as the independent agent in cognitions, distinct from the means of knowledge, by virtue of his engagement and disengagement.

analyzed: tasya ca pramātuḥ antar sarva artha avabhāsaḥ
translated: And within that knower, all objects appear.

original: cinmātraśarīro 'pi tatsāmānādhikaraṇyavṛttirapi darpaṇanagaranyāyenāsti ityapi uktam /🔽evaṃ ca tatpratibhāṃ ghaṭābhāsam /
analyzed: cit mātra śarīrā u pi tad sāmānādhikaraṇya vṛttiḥ api darpaṇa nagara nyāyena asti iti api uktam  evam ca tad pratibhām ghaṭa ābhāsam
translated: It is also said that he has a body of pure consciousness, and that he exists in the same substratum as that, like a mirror and a city, according to the analogy of the mirror and the city.🔽And thus, the knower enjoys, serves, the appearance of the jar which is his own manifestation,

original: atatpratibhāṃ ca aghaṭābhāsaṃ pramātā bhajate sevate tāvat /
analyzed: a tad pratibhām ca a ghaṭa ābhāsam pramātā bhajate sevate tāvat
translated: and the non-appearance of the jar which is not his own manifestation, as long as he is in the state of non-discrimination.

original: tadavikalpadaśāyāṃ citsvabhāvo 'sau ghaṭaḥ cidvadeva viśvaśarīraḥ pūrṇaḥ /
analyzed: tad avikalpa daśāyām cit svabhāvaḥ sau ghaṭaḥ cit vat eva viśva śarīraḥ pūrṇaḥ
translated: And in that state of non-discrimination, that jar, which is of the nature of consciousness, is complete, having the body of the universe like consciousness itself.

original: na ca tena kaścidvyavahāraḥ /🔽tat māyāvyāpāramukkāsayanpūrṇamapi khaṇḍayati bhāvam /
analyzed: na ca tena kaścid vyavahāraḥ  tat māyā vyāpāram ukkāsayan pūrṇam api khaṇḍayati bhāvam
translated: And no transaction is carried out by him.🔽Having set aside the operation of māyā, he breaks even the complete entity.

analyzed: tena a ghaṭasya ātmanaḥ paṭa ādeḥ ca apohanam kriyate niṣedhana rūpam
translated: By that, the negation in the form of denial is done of the non-jar, the self, and the cloth etc.

original: tadeva vyapohanamāśritya tasma ghaṭasya niścayanamucyate ghaṭa eva iti /
analyzed: tat eva vyapohanam āśritya ghaṭasya niścayanam ucyate ghaṭaḥ eva iti
translated: Relying on that very negation, the ascertainment of the jar is stated as it is a jar alone.

analyzed: eva arthasya saṃbhāvyamāna apara vastu niṣedha rūpa tvāt
translated: Because the meaning of 'eva' (only) is of the nature of the negation of another thing that is possible.

analyzed: eṣaḥ eva paritas chedāt takṣaṇa kalpāt paricchedaḥ
translated: This very [negation] is 'pariccheda' (definition) because it is a 'pariccheda' (definition) of the moment-concept.

analyzed: hi iti yatas evam
translated: 'Hi' (because) is used in the sense of 'yata' (since).

original: tasmāt yuktaṃ dvayākṣepī vikalpaḥ iti pūrvaślokoltena vastudvayena hetū krameṇoktau
analyzed: tasmāt yuktam dvaya ākṣepī vikalpaḥ iti pūrva śloka ultena vastu dvayena hetū krameṇa uktau
translated: Therefore, it is proper to say that the vikalpa (conceptual thought) is that which excludes the two [possibilities]. In the previous verse, the two things are mentioned as the reasons in order.

original: yasmādevaṃ vikalpaḥ tato 'hamiti śuddho vimarśaḥ na vikalpaḥ iti ślokatraye mahāvākyārthaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt evam vikalpaḥ tatas ham iti śuddhaḥ vimarśaḥ na vikalpaḥ iti śloka traye mahāvākya arthaḥ
translated: Since the vikalpa (conceptual thought) is like this, therefore the pure reflection 'I' is not a vikalpa (conceptual thought). This is the meaning of the three verses.

original: śākyairapi pramāturevāyaṃ vyāpāra uktaḥ ekaḥ pratyavamarśākhyaḥ ityatra prapattā iti svayam iti ca vadadbhiḥ /
analyzed: śākyaiḥ api pramātuḥ eva ayam vyāpāraḥ uktaḥ ekaḥ pratyavamarśa ākhyaḥ iti atra prapattā iti svayam iti ca vadadbhiḥ
translated: Even the Buddhists have stated that this is the activity of the cognizer, called 'pratyavamarsa' (reflection), by saying 'prapanna' (one who has entered) and 'svayam' (himself).

original: sa tvetaiḥ kathaṃ samarthyaḥ ityāstāmetat ////🔽nanvevamahamityapi pratyavamarśe 'nahaṃrūpasya ghaṭādeḥ pratiyogino ' /
analyzed: sa tu etaiḥ katham samarthyaḥ iti āstām etat  nanu evam aham iti api pratyavamarśe na ahaṃrūpasya ghaṭa ādeḥ
translated: But how can this be established by them? Let this be so.

original: pohanīyasyāpohe vikalparūpatā kathaṃ na syāt ityāśayenāha 🔽cittattvaṃ māyayā hitvā bhinna evāvabhāti yaḥ /
analyzed: pohanīyasya apohe vikalpa rūpa tā katham na syāt iti āśayena āha  cit tattvam māyayā hitvā bhinnaḥ evā avabhāti yaḥ
translated: Now, in this way, even in the reflection 'I', how can the form of 'not I', which is to be excluded, not be of the nature of vikalpa (conceptual thought) in the exclusion of the pot and other things that are to be excluded? With this idea in mind, he says:🔽He who, having abandoned the essence of consciousness by maya, appears as different,

original: dehe buddhāvatha prāṇe kalpite nabhasīva vā // / / //
analyzed: dehe buddhau atha prāṇe kalpite nabhasi iva vā
translated: In the body, in the intellect, or in the life force, or as imagined in space.

analyzed: pramātṛ tvena aham iti vimarśaḥ nya vyapohanāt
translated: The reflection I as the cognizer, by excluding others,

analyzed: vikalpaḥ eva sa para pratiyogi avabhāsa jaḥ
translated: is indeed a conceptual thought, born from the manifestation of something else as its counter-correlate.

analyzed: aham iti avamarśaḥ dvidhā śuddhaḥ māyīyaḥ ca
translated: The reflection I is of two kinds: pure and māyā-based.

original: tatra śuddho yaḥ saṃvinmātre viśvābhinne viśvacchāyācchuritācchātmani vā /
analyzed: tatra śuddhaḥ yaḥ saṃvid mātre viśva abhinne viśva chāyā ācchurita accha ātmani vā
translated: Among them, the pure one is that which is in pure consciousness alone, non-different from the universe, or in the self that is clear like a reflection of the universe.

analyzed: aśuddhaḥ tu vedya rūpe śarīra ādau
translated: The impure one is in the object, such as the body.

original: tatra śuddhe 'haṃpratyavamarśe pratiyogī na kaścidapohitavyaḥ saṃbhavati ghaṭāderapi prakāśasāratvenāpratiyogitvenānapohyatvāt /
analyzed: tatra śuddhe haṃpratyavamarśe pratiyogī na kaścid apohitavyaḥ saṃbhavati ghaṭa ādeḥ api prakāśa sāra tvena apratiyogi tvena anapohya tvāt
translated: There, in the pure reflection of I, no counter-correlate can be excluded, because even a pot, being the essence of light, is not a counter-correlate and cannot be excluded.

analyzed: iti apohya abhāve katham tatra vikalpa rūpa tā
translated: So, in the absence of something to be excluded, how can it be of the nature of a conceptual thought there?

original: aśuddhastu vedyarūpe śarīrādau anyasmād dehāderghaṭādeśca vyavacchedena bhavan vikalpa eva iti vākyārthaḥ /
analyzed: aśuddhaḥ tu vedya rūpe śarīra ādau anyasmāt deha ādeḥ ghaṭa ādeḥ ca vyavacchedena bhavan vikalpaḥ eva iti vākya arthaḥ
translated: But the impure one, in the object such as the body, occurring by excluding something else such as the body or a pot, is indeed a conceptual thought. This is the meaning of the sentence.

original: akṣarārthastu cittattvaṃ prakāśamātrarūpaṃ hitvā sadapyapahastanayā apradhānīkṛtya
analyzed: akṣara arthaḥ tu cit tattvam prakāśa mātra rūpam hitvā sat api apahastanayā a pradhānīkṛtya
translated: The meaning of the words is: Having abandoned the principle of consciousness, which is of the nature of mere light, and even though existing, by disregarding it,

original: bhinne dehādāvahameva dehādiḥ nīlādau prameye pramātā ityabhimānena yo 'haṃ
analyzed: bhinne deha ādau aham eva deha ādiḥ nīla ādau prameye pramātā iti abhimānena yaḥ haṃ
translated: in the different body etc., I am indeed the body etc., in the object such as blue, I am the cognizer, by the conceit.

analyzed: sthūlaḥ ityādi vimarśaḥ sa vikalpaḥ eva
translated: The reflection gross and so on is indeed conceptual.

analyzed: na tu śuddham pratyavamarśa mātram
translated: But not pure mere reflection.🔽Here the reason is the second other, which is the body etc. and the pot etc., which is a counter-correlate in the same class, and which is contradictory due to mutual exclusion.

original: atra hetuḥ paro dvitīyo dehādirghaṭādiśca yaḥ pratiyogī tulyakakṣyo 'nyonyaparihārācca viruddhastasya yo 'vabhāsaḥ samāropaṇalakṣaṇaḥ🔽tasmādyato 'sāvatanniṣedhānuprāṇito ' /
analyzed: atra hetuḥ paraḥ dvitīyaḥ deha ādiḥ ghaṭa ādiḥ ca yaḥ pratiyogī tulya kakṣyaḥ nyonya parihārāt ca viruddhaḥ tasya yaḥ vabhāsaḥ samāropaṇa lakṣaṇaḥ  tasmāt yatas saḥ a tad niṣedha anuprāṇitaḥ
translated: The appearance of that, which is characterized by superimposition,🔽is from that, because this reflection I has arisen, impelled by the negation of that.

analyzed: ham iti avamarśaḥ jātaḥ aham sthūlaḥ
translated: I am gross.

analyzed: na kṛśaḥ
translated: I am not thin.

analyzed: na ghaṭa ādiḥ iti
translated: I am not a pot etc.

analyzed: śuddha prakāśa rūpasya apahastanā eva deha ādeḥ bheda hetuḥ
translated: The mere exclusion of the body etc. is the cause of difference.

original: tadapahastane tu parameśvarasya svātmapracchādanecchārūpā 'bhedāprakāśanaṃ bhrāntirūpaṃ prati svātantryarūpā māyāśaktirhetuḥ /
analyzed: tad apahastane tu parameśvarasya sva ātma pracchādana icchā rūpā bheda aprakāśanam bhrānti rūpam prati svātantrya rūpā māyā śaktiḥ hetuḥ
translated: But in the exclusion of that, the cause is the power of māyā, which is of the nature of independence with respect to error, in the form of the supreme Lord's desire to conceal his own self, which is the non-manifestation of non-difference.

original: cidrūpasya cāpahastanaṃ dehādereva atyaktavedyabhāvasya bhinnasyaiva upapattiśūnyatayaiva pramātṛtvābhimānaḥ /
analyzed: cit rūpasya ca apahastanam deha ādeḥ eva atyakta vedya bhāvasya bhinnasya eva upapatti śūnyatayā eva pramātṛ tva abhimānaḥ
translated: And the exclusion of the nature of consciousness is only of the body etc., which has not abandoned the state of the known, which is different, only by the absence of proof, the conceit of being the experiencer.

original: tathā ca dehābhimānabhūmikāyāṃ sthitāścārvākāḥ caitanyaviśiṣṭaḥ kāyaḥ puruṣaḥ iti kāyameva prādhānyenāhuḥ /🔽strībālamūrkhāṇāṃ tathābhimānāt tato 'pi vivekayuktāḥ pākajotpattipariṇāmādibalādasthiraṃ
analyzed: tathā ca deha abhimāna bhūmikāyām sthitāḥ cārvākāḥ caitanya viśiṣṭaḥ kāyaḥ puruṣaḥ iti kāyam eva prādhānyena āhuḥ  strī bāla mūrkhāṇām tathā abhimānāt viveka yuktāḥ pāka ja utpatti pariṇāma ādi balāt asthiram
translated: And thus the Cārvākas, who are established on the level of the identification with the body, say that the body itself is the primary Puruṣa, which is consciousness-embellished.🔽Because of the same identification in women, children, and fools, those who are more discerning than them consider the body to be impermanent

original: śarīraṃ manvānāḥ prāṇaśaktisamadhiṣṭhānena ca vinā vikāraśatāveśaṃ śarīrasya paśyanto
analyzed: śarīram manvānāḥ prāṇa śakti samadhiṣṭhānena ca vinā vikāra śata āveśam śarīrasya paśyantaḥ
translated: due to the strength of the production, transformation, etc. of the cooked substances. And seeing the body to be subject to hundreds of transformations without the presiding of the power of prāṇa,

analyzed: bubhukṣā pipāsā yoga yogyam prāṇam eva ātmānam kecana śruti anta vidaḥ manyante
translated: some who know the end of the Vedas consider prāṇa itself, which is fit for the union of hunger and thirst, to be the self.

original: tato 'pi samadhikavivekabhājaḥ prāṇasyāpi anityatvādanusaṃdhānayogyatāmapaśyanto jñānasukhādyāśrayabhūtāṃ buddhimeva kāṇādaprabhṛtaya ātmānamāhuḥ
analyzed: samadhika viveka bhājaḥ prāṇasya api anitya tvāt anusaṃdhāna yogyatām a paśyantaḥ jñāna sukha ādi āśraya bhūtām buddhim eva kāṇāda prabhṛtayaḥ ātmānam āhuḥ
translated: Those who are even more discerning than them, not seeing the fitness for connection due to the impermanence of prāṇa also, consider the intellect itself, which is the substratum of knowledge, happiness, etc., to be the self, as stated by Kaṇāda and others.

original: apare tasyā api yogidśāyāṃ vedyabhāvādaparatvaṃ manyamānāḥ asaṃvedyaparvarūpaṃ yanna
analyzed: apare tasyāḥ api yogi dśāyām vedya bhāvāt apara tvam manyamānāḥ asaṃvedya parva rūpam yat na
translated: Others, considering that even that (intellect) is secondary due to being the object of knowledge in the state of yoga, say that the self is that which has the nature of no-thing whatsoever,

original: kiṃcidrūpaṃ sakalavedyarāśivinirmuktaṃ śūnyatvānnabhastulyaṃ na tu mahābhūtākāśasvabhāvaṃ
analyzed: kiṃcid rūpam sakala vedya rāśi vinirmuktam śūnya tvāt nabhaḥ tulyam na tu mahābhūta ākāśa svabhāvam
translated: which is not an object of consciousness, which is free from the entire mass of objects of knowledge, which is like the sky due to emptiness, but not of the nature of the great element space,

analyzed: tat pramātṛ tattvam śūnya brahma vādinaḥ sāṃkhya prabhṛtayaḥ āhuḥ
translated: That is the reality of the knower, which the proponents of the doctrine of void Brahman, the Sāṃkhyas and others, speak of.

original: tasminnapi vedye śunyāntaraṃ tatrāpi śūnyāntram iti yāvadbhedaḥ tāvatkalpanā na truṭyatīti tadarthamāha kalpite iti /
analyzed: tasmin api vedye śunya antaram tatra api śūnyāntram iti yāvat bhedaḥ tāvat kalpanā na truṭyati iti tad artham āha kalpite iti
translated: Even in that knowable, there is another void, and in that too another void, and so on, as long as there is difference, the imagination does not cease. For that purpose, he says in the imagined.

original: na cānavasthā paramārthaprakāśabalena yataḥ sarvasya prakāśo na tu dehādivaśāt /
analyzed: na ca anavasthā paramārtha prakāśa balena yatas sarvasya prakāśaḥ na tu deha ādi vaśāt
translated: And there is no infinite regress, because all manifestation is by the power of the manifestation of the ultimate reality, not by the power of the body etc.

analyzed: tayā tu abhimāna mātram dehaḥ pramātā iti
translated: By that, the body is merely the superimposition of the knower.

analyzed: saṅkoca mātra rūpam cit tattvam śūnyam
translated: And the principle of consciousness, which is mere contraction, is void.

analyzed: bhū talam yathā ghaṭa abhāvaḥ
translated: As the absence of a pot is the ground.

analyzed: saṅkoca upari vedya aṃśa chāyā ācchuritam tu cit tattvam eva buddhi prāṇa deha ādi iti
translated: But the principle of consciousness itself, which is tinged with the shadow of the part of the knowable that is superimposed, is the intellect, the vital breath, the body etc.

original: amī eva bhūmikāviśeṣā uttarottaramārohatāṃ yogināṃ jāgradāditayā piṇḍasthāditayā cāgameṣu bhaṇyante /
analyzed: amī eva bhūmikā viśeṣāḥ uttarottaram ārohatām yoginām jāgrat ādi tayā piṇḍa stha ādi tayā ca āgameṣu bhaṇyante
translated: These very specific stages are spoken of in the scriptures as the waking state etc. and the state of the stabilized body etc. for the yogis who ascend higher and higher.

analyzed: apahastanam ca vyākhyāsyateḥ  kalā udvalitam etat ca cit tattvam kartṛtā mayam
translated: And the rejection will be explained.

analyzed: acit rūpasya śūnya ādeḥ mitam guṇa tayā sthitam
translated: And this principle of consciousness, which is impelled by kalā, exists as an attribute of the insentient void etc., which is measured.

original: iti / tatsthitam aśuddhaḥ aham ityavamarśo vikalpa eva ////
analyzed: iti tat sthitam aśuddhaḥ aham iti avamarśaḥ vikalpaḥ eva
translated: Thus, the ascertainment that I am impure is indeed a conceptualization.

original: dvividho 'pi cāyam ahaṃpratyayo dvidhā anubhavamātrarūpaścānusaṃdhānātmā ca /🔽śivātmani aham iti sadāśivātmani ahamidam iti śuddho dvidhā /
analyzed: ca ayam ahaṃpratyayaḥ dvidhā anubhava mātra rūpaḥ ca anusaṃdhāna ātmā ca  śiva ātmani aham iti sadāśiva ātmani aham idam iti śuddhaḥ dvidhā
translated: And this I-notion, of two kinds, is twofold: in the form of mere experience and in the form of recollection.🔽The pure one is twofold: I am Śiva and I am Sadāśiva.

analyzed: aśuddhaḥ pi aham sthūlaḥ iti
translated: The impure one is also twofold: I am gross and I am subtle.

analyzed: yaḥ ham sthūlaḥ bhavam saḥ ham kṛśa
translated: I who was gross, I have become thin.

analyzed: bālaḥ
translated: I was a child.

analyzed: yuvā
translated: I was a youth.

analyzed: sthaviraḥ
translated: I am an old man.

original: sa eva aham iti ca aśuddho dvividhaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ eva aham iti ca aśuddhaḥ dvividhaḥ
translated: I am the same. Thus, the impure one is twofold.

analyzed: tatra śuddhe vikalpa rūpa tvam apratiṣṭham eva iti uktam
translated: Among them, it has been said that the pure one, in the form of conceptualization, is indeed unestablished.

analyzed: aśuddhe tu anubhava rūpe vikalpa tvam upapāditam
translated: But in the impure one, in the form of experience, the nature of being a conceptualization has been established.

original: aśuddhe 'pi tu anusaṃdhānātmakatayā abhedasya prasphuraṇāt kaścidavikalpakatvaṃ śaṅketa tasya vyāmohaṃ vyapohitumāha
analyzed: aśuddhe tu anusaṃdhāna ātmaka tayā abhedasya prasphuraṇāt kaścid avikalpaka tvam śaṅketa tasya vyāmoham vyapohitum āha
translated: But even in the impure one, due to the manifestation of non-difference through the nature of recollection, someone might suspect it to be non-conceptual. To remove his delusion, it is said:

original: kādācitkāvabhāse yā pūrvābhāsādiyojanā /🔽saṃskārātkalpanā proktā sāpi bhinnāvabhāsini // / / //
analyzed: kādācitka avabhāse yā pūrva ābhāsa ādi yojanā  saṃskārāt kalpanā proktā sā api bhinna avabhāsini
translated: The arrangement of the previous appearance, in the appearance that occurs occasionally,🔽is said to be imagination due to impressions. That also occurs in what appears as different.

analyzed: dehe ityādi vartate
translated: In the body and so on is used.

original: kādācitkaḥ kadācidbhavo niyatadeśakālākāro 'vabhāso yasya dehādeḥ svalakṣaṇarūpasya /🔽tatra yā pūrvābhāsena bālādiśarīrāvabhāsena yojanā yo 'haṃ bālaḥ sa evādya yuvā ityanusaṃdhānam /
analyzed: kādācitkaḥ kadācid bhavaḥ niyata deśa kāla ākāraḥ vabhāsaḥ yasya deha ādeḥ sva lakṣaṇa rūpasya  tatra yā pūrva ābhāsena bāla ādi śarīra avabhāsena yojanā yaḥ ham bālaḥ saḥ eva adya yuvā iti anusaṃdhānam
translated: That which has occasional existence, appearing at some time in a definite place, time, and form, is the particular characteristic of the body, etc.🔽There, the connection with the previous appearance, with the appearance of the body of a child, etc., is the remembrance, I who was a child am the same today as a youth.

original: ādigrahaṇāduttareṇa bhāvinā ābhāsena saha yojanā sthaviro bhavitāsmi iti /
analyzed: ādi grahaṇāt uttareṇa bhāvinā ābhāsena saha yojanā sthaviraḥ bhavitāsmi iti
translated: By the word etc., the connection with the future appearance is included, I will become an old man.

original: sā yojanā sarvā kalpanā vikalpa eva /
analyzed: sā yojanā sarvā kalpanā vikalpaḥ eva
translated: All that connection is imagination, conceptualization itself.

analyzed: na tu śuddhaḥ pratyavamarśaḥ
translated: But it is not pure reflective awareness.

original: atra dehāderviśeṣaṇaṃ hetutvāśayena yato bhinnatāvabhāsitvameva dehādestadānīmapi avichinnam /🔽yadi hi tasya dehādeḥ sarvataḥ pūrṇatvam avacchedahīnatvaṃ paśyan anusaṃdhānam ahamidam
analyzed: atra deha ādeḥ viśeṣaṇam hetutva āśayena yatas bhinnatā avabhāsi tvam eva deha ādeḥ tadānīm api avichinnam  yadi hi tasya deha ādeḥ sarvatas pūrṇa tvam avaccheda hīna tvam paśyan anusaṃdhānam aham idam
translated: Here, the qualification of the body, etc., is intended as the cause, because the appearance of difference of the body, etc., is uninterrupted even at that time.

original: iti vidadhyāt tadiyaṃ sadāśivabhūḥ kena vikalpātpadatvena bhaṇyeta yāvatā 'vicchinne eva so 'nusaṃdhiḥ /🔽bhinnepiKSS / hi
analyzed: iti vidadhyāt tat iyam sadāśiva bhūḥ kena vikalpāt pada tvena bhaṇyeta yāvatā vicchinne eva saḥ 🔽bhinnepikss hi
translated: If one were to make the remembrance, I am this, seeing that the body, etc., are completely full, without any limitation, then this state of Sadasiva would be called by what name of conceptualization? Since that remembrance is uninterrupted even in the differentiated.

original: kathamanusaṃdhānam iti cedāha saṃskārāt prāktanānubhavakṛtavāsanāprabodhajasmṛtivaśāt iti yāvat /
analyzed: katham anusaṃdhānam iti ced āha saṃskārāt prāktana anubhava kṛta vāsanā prabodha ja smṛti vaśāt iti yāvat
translated: If it is asked how there is recollection, he says: from the awakening of the latent impressions created by past experience, that is, from memory.

analyzed: prāṇe bala abala vaśāt anusaṃdhiḥ
translated: Recollection is based on the strength of the vital force.

analyzed: buddhau jñāna sukha ādi tāratamyāt
translated: In the intellect, it is due to the gradation of knowledge, happiness, etc.

analyzed: śūnye vaitatya avaitatya yogāt
translated: In the Void, it is due to the union of expansion and contraction.

analyzed: ayam api vikalpaḥ eva
translated: This is also just an option.

original: evaṃ sa evāyaṃ ghaṭaḥ iti ghaṭādyanusaṃdhāne 'pi vikalpatvaṃ mantavyam /
analyzed: evam saḥ eva ayam ghaṭaḥ iti ghaṭa ādi anusaṃdhāne pi vikalpa tvam mantavyam
translated: Thus, even in the recollection of a pot, such as this is the same pot, it should be understood to be an option.

original: kintu etāsu anusaṃdhānabhūmiṣu vidyāśaktirādhikyena aciradyutivaddīpyate iti tāsāṃ parapadapariśīlanaprathamakalpābhyupāyatvamabhyupāgaman
analyzed: kintu etāsu anusaṃdhāna bhūmiṣu vidyā śaktiḥ ādhikyena acira dyuti vat dīpyate iti tāsām para pada pariśīlana prathama kalpa abhyupāya tvam abhyupāgaman
translated: But in these grounds of recollection, the power of knowledge shines with predominance like a lamp with a short flame. Thus, they are accepted as the primary means for the study of the supreme state.

original: na ca dehādīnāṃ pūrvapūrvapramātṛvedyatā yena pramāturaprakāśe prameyaṃ na bhāti tatprakāśaśca na pūrvaprakāśaṃ vinā /
analyzed: na ca deha ādīnām pūrva pūrva pramātṛ vedya tā yena pramātuḥ aprakāśe prameyam na bhāti tad prakāśaḥ ca na pūrva prakāśam vinā
translated: And it is not that the body, etc. are known by each preceding cognizer, by which the object does not appear in the absence of the illumination of the cognizer, and that illumination does not exist without the prior illumination.

original: so 'pi na pramātrantaraprakāśaṃ vinā ityanavasthā syāt /
analyzed: na pramātṛ antara prakāśam vinā iti anavasthā syāt
translated: And that also does not exist without the illumination of another cognizer, so there would be an infinite regress.

original: api tu śuddhaprakāśa eva viśvasya prakāśa iti nirūpayan uktayuktyā sadaiva sṛṣṭyādiśaktyaviyogo bhagavata ukto bhavati /
analyzed: api tu śuddha prakāśaḥ eva viśvasya prakāśaḥ iti nirūpayan ukta yuktyā sadā eva sṛṣṭi ādi śakti aviyogaḥ bhagavataḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: But rather, the manifestation of the universe is pure light itself. Thus, it is shown that by the stated reasoning, the Lord is always inseparable from the power of creation etc.

analyzed: iti darśayati
translated: This is shown by

analyzed: tat evam vyavahāre pi prabhuḥ deha ādim āviśan
translated: Thus, even in conventional usage, the Lord, entering the body etc.,

analyzed: bhāntam eva antar artha ogham icchayā bhāsayet bahis
translated: May externally illuminate the mass of objects that shines internally as 'I' by His will.

original: yat pūrvaṃ darśitaṃ dehe buddhau ityādi tat evam upapadyate / katham /
analyzed: yat pūrvam darśitam dehe buddhau ityādi tat evam upapadyate katham
translated: What was previously shown, such as 'in the body, in the intellect' etc., that is justified in this way. How?

original: yadi vyavahāre māyāpade dehaprāṇādimapi prabhureva prakāśaparamārtha icchayā māyāśaktirūpayā /
analyzed: yadi vyavahāre māyā pade deha prāṇa ādim api prabhuḥ eva prakāśa paramārthaḥ icchayā māyā śakti rūpayā
translated: If in conventional usage, in the state of Maya, the Lord, who is of the nature of light, by His will in the form of the power of Maya, enters even the body, life force etc.,

analyzed: āviśan deha prāṇa ādi prādhānyena svarūpam pradarśayan
translated: Displaying His own nature as primary in the body, life force etc.,

analyzed: antar saṃbid mātre
translated: Internally, in mere consciousness,

original: bhāntam ahamityevaṃrūpam arthaugham icchayaiva bahiḥ idamiti bhāsayati tata etadupapadyate /
analyzed: aham iti evaṃrūpam artha ogham icchayā eva bahis idam iti bhāsayati tatas etat upapadyate
translated: Illuminates the mass of objects in the form of 'I' as 'this' externally by His will alone. Therefore, this is justified.

analyzed: anyathā tu anavasthā syāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: hetau liṅ
translated: The suffix 'lin' is used in the reason.

analyzed: apiśabdaḥ evaśabdaḥ ca bhinnakramau
translated: The words 'api' and 'eva' are in a different order.

analyzed: yat etāvat uktam  tat iti
translated: As much as this has been stated.🔽'Tat' means that.

analyzed: tasmāt hetoḥ
translated: From that reason.

analyzed: evam jātam vakṣyamāṇa rūpam kiṃtat
translated: Thus born, having the form about to be described. What is that?

original: yat kila prabhuḥ parasparaṃ vyavahārakāle krayavikrayaprekṣāvyākhyādau caitramaitrādisaṃbandhino
analyzed: yat kila prabhuḥ parasparam vyavahāra kāle kraya vikraya prekṣā vyākhyā ādau caitra maitra ādi saṃbandhinaḥ
translated: It is said that the Lord, at the time of mutual transactions, in buying, selling, deliberation, explanation, etc.,🔽unites the body, life-force, etc. associated with Caitra, Maitra, etc. as one, in that much of transaction,

original: dehaprāṇādīn ekatayā tāvati vyavahāre āviśan antarbhāntameva anujjhitāntaḥprakāśameva
analyzed: deha prāṇa ādīn ekatayā tāvati vyavahāre āviśan antar bhāntam eva anujjhita antar prakāśam eva
translated: existing as internally shining, not abandoning internal illumination,

original: santaṃ bahiḥ ekābhāsatayā bhāsayati iti saṃbhāvyate ityetajjātam /🔽iti saṃbhāvanāyāṃ liṅ /
analyzed: santam bahis eka ābhāsa tayā bhāsayati iti saṃbhāvyate iti etat jātam  iti saṃbhāvanāyām liṅ
translated: it is possible that he manifests externally as one appearance. This is what is born.🔽The verbal root jan (to be born) is used in the sense of possibility.

original: tena tena pramātrā saha asminkāle aikyaṃ sṛjyate /
analyzed: tena tena pramātrā saha asmin kāle aikyam sṛjyate
translated: By that and that knower, unity is created at this time.

analyzed: anyena pramātrā aikyam saṃhriyate
translated: By another knower, unity is withdrawn.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādi mātra rūpe sthitiḥ kriyate  pūrṇa sva rūpa nimīlanāt tirobhāvaḥ ādhīyate
translated: In the mere form of a pot, etc., stability is created.🔽By closing the full form, concealment is imposed.

analyzed: tāvati ābhāse aikya avabhāsa pūrṇa tva vitaraṇāt anugrahaḥ kriyate
translated: By the distribution of the fullness of the manifestation of unity in that much of manifestation, grace is created.

original: tena na kevalaṃ mahāsṛṣṭiṣu mahāsthitiṣu mahāpralayeṣu prakopatirodhāneṣu dīkṣājñānādyanugraheṣu bhagavataḥ krṭyapañcakayogaḥ yāvat satatameva
analyzed: tena na kevalam mahā sṛṣṭiṣu mahā sthitiṣu mahāpralayeṣu prakopa tirodhāneṣu dīkṣā jñāna ādi anugraheṣu bhagavataḥ krṭya pañcaka yogaḥ yāvat satatam eva  /
translated: Therefore, not only in the great creations, great stabilities, great dissolutions, in the concealment of anger, in the grace of initiation, knowledge, etc., does the Lord possess the yoga of the five acts, but even in

analyzed: vyavahāre pi yat uktam
translated: constant transactions. As it is said:

analyzed: sadā sṛṣṭi vinodāya sadā sthiti sukha āsine
translated: Always for the amusement of creation, always seated in the bliss of persistence,

analyzed: sadā tribhuvana āhāra tṛptāya svāmine namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the Lord who is always satisfied by consuming the three worlds.

analyzed: iti  pratikṣaṇam aviśrāntaḥ trailokyam kalpanā śataiḥ
translated: Thus.🔽Unceasing every moment, with hundreds of imaginations,

analyzed: kalpayan api kaḥ pi ekaḥ nirvikalpaḥ jayati ajaḥ
translated: The unborn one alone, who creates the three worlds, is victorious, free from conceptualization.

analyzed: ityādi ca tathā
translated: And so on. And thus:

analyzed: prākāmyam ātmani yadā prakaṭīkaroṣi
translated: When you manifest supreme bliss in the self,

analyzed: vyaktoḥ
translated: The manifest...

analyzed: iti ca
translated: And so on.

analyzed: iha antar artha abhāva bhāsaḥ sthitaḥ eva
translated: Here, the manifestation of the absence of internal objects remains.

original: tat kiṃ tatra kāraṇāntaracintayā iti prakṛtaṃ prameyam /
analyzed: tat kim tatra kāraṇa antara cintayā iti prakṛtam prameyam
translated: So what is the use of thinking of other causes there? This is the main topic.

analyzed: tad siddhaye upapattiḥ uktā
translated: The reasoning for establishing that has been stated.

original: tena vinā icchārūpaḥ pratyavamarśo na syāt iti /
analyzed: tena vinā icchā rūpaḥ pratyavamarśaḥ na syāt iti
translated: Without that, the reflective awareness in the form of desire would not exist.

analyzed: tad prasaṅgāt pratyavamarśa vikalpa ādi svarūpam upapāditam
translated: Due to that, the nature of reflective awareness, conceptualization, etc. has been established.

original: iti śiṣyāṇāṃ dhiyaṃ samādhātuṃ prakṛtaṃ prameyam upapādayan upasaṃharati
analyzed: iti śiṣyāṇām dhiyam samādhātum prakṛtam prameyam upapādayan upasaṃharati
translated: Thus, in order to concentrate the minds of the disciples, the author concludes by establishing the main topic:

analyzed: evam smṛtau vikalpe vā api apohana parāyaṇe
translated: Thus, in memory or even in conceptualization, which is intent on exclusion,

analyzed: jñāne vā api antar ābhāsaḥ sthitaḥ evā iti niścitam
translated: or in knowledge, the internal manifestation is certainly present.

original: prakāśātmā parameśvara eva yato dehādipramātṛtābhimānadaśāyāmapi vastutaḥ pramātā /
analyzed: prakāśa ātmā parameśvaraḥ eva yatas deha ādi pramātṛtā abhimāna daśāyām api vastutas pramātā
translated: Because the Supreme Lord, who is of the nature of light, is indeed the knower even in the state of identification with the body etc. as the knower.

analyzed: evam iti
translated: Thus.

original: ato hetoḥ idaṃ siddhaṃ bhavati smaraṇe apohanajīvite ca vikalpe anubhavajñāne ca antarābhāsaḥ prakāśaviśrāntaḥ sthita eva /
analyzed: atas hetoḥ idam siddham bhavati smaraṇe apohana jīvite ca vikalpe anubhava jñāne ca antar ābhāsaḥ prakāśa viśrāntaḥ sthitaḥ eva
translated: For this reason, it is established that in memory, in the life of exclusion, in imagination, and in the knowledge of experience, the internal manifestation rests in the light.

analyzed: na atra saṃśayaḥ kaścid
translated: There is no doubt about this.

original: yadi hi dehādireva paramārthapramātā syāt tat śarīrasya prāṇasya dhiyaḥ śūnyasya vā antarghaṭādi iti na kiṃcit etat ghaṭādiparihāreṇa
analyzed: yadi hi deha ādiḥ eva paramārtha pramātā syāt tat śarīrasya prāṇasya dhiyaḥ śūnyasya vā antar ghaṭa ādi iti na kiṃcid etat ghaṭa ādi parihāreṇa
translated: If the body etc. itself were the ultimate knower, then this would be nothing but the internal of the body, life, intellect, or void, like a pot etc.

analyzed: deha ādeḥ sthita tvāt
translated: Because the body etc. exist apart from the pot etc.

analyzed: paramārtha prakāśaḥ tu sarvaṃsahaḥ iti tatra antar viśvam
translated: But the ultimate light is all-pervading, so the universe is within it.

analyzed: iti anāyāsa siddham etat
translated: Thus this is easily established.

original: nanu antarābhāsavargasya bahirābhāsanaṃ yadi sarvatrāsti kastarhi smaraṇādau ābhāsabhedaḥ /
analyzed: nanu antar ābhāsa vargasya bahis ābhāsanam yadi sarvatra asti kaḥ tarhi smaraṇa ādau ābhāsa bhedaḥ
translated: But if the internal manifestation class exists everywhere externally, then what is the difference in manifestation in memory etc.?

original: na ca asau na saṃvedyate sphuṭatāsphuṭatādiprasphuraṇasya anapahnavanīyatvāt ityāśaṅkyāha
analyzed: na ca asau na saṃvedyate sphuṭatā asphuṭatā ādi prasphuraṇasya anapahnavanīya tvāt iti āśaṅkya āha
translated: And it is not that it is not experienced at all, because the manifestation of vividness and lack of vividness, etc. cannot be denied. Thinking this, he says:

analyzed: kiṃtu naisargikaḥ jñāne bahis ābhāsana ātmani
translated: But in the natural knowledge, which has the nature of external manifestation,

analyzed: pūrva anubhava rūpaḥ tu sthitaḥ sa smaraṇa ādiṣu
translated: The form of previous experience exists in memory, etc.

original: anubhavajñānasya idaṃ nīlam iti antaravabhāsaṃ vahirābhāsayataḥ svāntarbhāvābhāso naisargika
analyzed: anubhava jñānasya idam nīlam iti antar avabhāsam vahis ābhāsayataḥ sva antarbhāva ābhāsaḥ naisargika
translated: The internal manifestation of the experience-knowledge, which manifests externally as this is blue, is natural.

original: nisṛṣṭeḥ svātantryāt āyāto na tu smaraṇāderiva anyajñānakṛtavāsanādibalāt /
analyzed: nisṛṣṭeḥ svātantryāt āyātaḥ na tu smaraṇa ādeḥ iva anya jñāna kṛta vāsanā ādi balāt
translated: It comes from independence, from being let loose, and not from the power of impressions created by other cognitions, as in memory, etc.

original: smaraṇe utprekṣaṇe pratyakṣapṛṣṭhabhāvini adhyavasāye ca yo 'ntarnīlādyavabhāso bāhyatayā adhyavasāyitavyaḥ nāsau svātmoyaḥ api tu pūrvānubhavasaṃskārajo
analyzed: smaraṇe utprekṣaṇe pratyakṣa pṛṣṭha bhāvini adhyavasāye ca yaḥ ntar nīla ādi avabhāsaḥ bāhya tayā adhyavasāyitavyaḥ na asau svātmoyaḥ api tu pūrva anubhava saṃskāra jaḥ
translated: In memory, imagination, and determination that occurs after perception, the internal manifestation of blue, etc., which is to be determined as external, is not one's own self, but arises from the impressions of previous experience.

analyzed: sau  tatra saṃskāraḥ nāma anubhavasya kāla antare pi anuvartamāna tā
translated: That is it.🔽There, impression means the continuation of experience even after some time.

original: ato 'sāvanuvartamāno 'nubhavo yato nīlādyābhāsasaṃbhinnaḥ tataḥ tattādātmyāpannaṃ smaraṇādyapi tathā nirbhāsate /
analyzed: atas saḥ anuvartamānaḥ nubhavaḥ yatas nīla ādi ābhāsa saṃbhinnaḥ tatas tad tādātmya āpannam smaraṇa ādi api tathā nirbhāsate
translated: Therefore, that continuing experience, which is mixed with the manifestation of blue, etc., from that, memory, etc., which has attained identity with that, appears in the same way.

original: tata eva smaraṇakālāsaṃbhavī ābhāsaḥ tadanubhavapūrvakālakalita eveti svayaṃ smaraṇādernirviṣayatvaṃ gṛhītagrāhitvaṃ ca uddhoṣyate /
analyzed: tatas eva smaraṇa kāla asaṃbhavī ābhāsaḥ tad anubhava pūrva kāla kalitaḥ eva iti svayam smaraṇa ādeḥ nirviṣaya tvam gṛhīta grāhi tvam ca
translated: Therefore, the appearance that is not possible at the time of recollection is only connected with the time prior to the experience of that. Thus, the self-cognition of memory etc. is said to be devoid of an object and to grasp what has already been grasped.

analyzed: etat eva asphuṭa tvam
translated: This itself is the lack of clarity.

original: iti siddho 'nubhavasmaraṇādau ābhāsabhedaḥ antarābhāsavargasya bahirābhāsanam anyāvyavadhānena sphuṭatā /
analyzed: iti siddhaḥ nubhava smaraṇa ādau ābhāsa bhedaḥ antara ābhāsa vargasya bahis ābhāsanam anya a vyavadhānena sphuṭatā
translated: Thus, the difference in appearances in experience, memory etc. is established. The appearance of the internal class of appearances as external is clarity without obstruction by something else.

analyzed: vyavadhānena tu tātkālika tva abhāvāt asphuṭatā iti
translated: But due to obstruction, there is lack of clarity due to the absence of contemporaneity.

original: nanu anubhavajñānāt aindriyakāt anyat sarvaṃ jñānaṃ vyavadhānena bahirābhāsanarūpaṃ prāptam ityāśaṅkya pravibhāgamāha
analyzed: nanu anubhava jñānāt aindriyakāt anyat sarvam jñānam vyavadhānena bahis ābhāsana rūpam prāptam iti āśaṅkya pravibhāgam āha
translated: Now, it is feared that all knowledge other than the sensory knowledge is obtained as appearing externally with obstruction. Suspecting this, he states the division:

analyzed: sa naisargikaḥ evā asti vikalpe svaira cāriṇi
translated: That is indeed natural in the independent imagination,

analyzed: yathā abhimata saṃsthāna ābhāsanāt buddhi gocare
translated: In the object of cognition appearing in the desired form.

original: yaḥ pratyakṣavyāpāram anupajīvan vyākṣepasāratayā manorājyasaṅkalpādivikalpaḥ sa svaraṃ kṛtvā svapreraṇena prapreraṇanairapekṣyeṇa svātantryeṇa 🔽carati udeti vyayate ca /
analyzed: yaḥ pratyakṣa vyāpāram an upajīvan vyākṣepa sāra tayā manaḥ rājya saṅkalpa ādi vikalpaḥ sa svaram kṛtvā sva preraṇena prapreraṇa nairapekṣyeṇa svātantryeṇa 🔽carati udeti vyayate ca
translated: That imagination which does not depend on the operation of perception, which rises up as the essence of distraction, such as mental speculation, resolve etc., it moves freely, rises and sets by itself, independently, without the need for any other instigation.

original: tatra yo bahirābhāso nīlādeḥ antarābhāsamayasya sa naisargika eva /
analyzed: tatra yaḥ bahis ābhāsaḥ nīla ādeḥ antar ābhāsa mayasya sa naisargikaḥ eva
translated: There, the external appearance of blue etc. is naturally internal.

original: tathā hi aparidṛṣṭapūrvamapi śvetaṃ daśanaśatakalotakarayugalayuktaṃ dantinam antaḥ🔽pramātṛbhūmau sthitaṃ bahiḥ antaḥkaraṇabhūmau svacchadhīdarpaṇātmikāyāṃ sa vikalpaḥ
analyzed: tathā hi a paridṛṣṭa pūrvam api śvetam daśana śata kalā ūta kara yugala yuktam dantinam antar  pramātṛ bhūmau sthitam bahis antaḥkaraṇa bhūmau svaccha dhī darpaṇa ātmikāyām sa vikalpaḥ
translated: Thus, even a white elephant never seen before, with tusks and a trunk,

analyzed: tātkālikam eva bhāsayati  asmāt ca antar ābhāsa saṃbhava samarthana prasaṅga āgatāt ābhāsa bheda vicārāt śāstre yat
translated: appears at that very moment on the internal ground of the knower, externally on the ground of the internal organ, in the form of a mirror of clear consciousness, along with conceptualization.🔽And from this consideration of the difference of appearances arising from the context of establishing the possibility of internal appearances, the application of the

original: prayoanaṃ mukhyatayā abhisaṃhitaṃ svātmani īśvarapratyabhijñānarūpaṃ tadadhikaraṇasiddhāntanītyā
translated: scripture, which is primarily intended for the recognition of God within one's own self,

analyzed: anāyāsa siddham iti darśayati
translated: is easily accomplished by the method of the conclusion of the topic, thus he shows.

analyzed: atas eva yathā abhīṣṭa samullekha avabhāsanāt
translated: And for this very reason, because of the appearance of the desired reflection,

original: jñānakriye sphuṭe eva siddhe sarvasya jīvataḥ // / / //
analyzed: jñāna kriye sphuṭe eva siddhe sarvasya jīvataḥ
translated: knowledge and action are clearly established for all living beings.

original: pratibhāti ghaṭaḥ iti yadyapi viṣayopaśliṣṭameva pratibhānaṃ bhāti tathāpi na tadviṣayasya svakaṃ vapuḥ /
analyzed: pratibhāti ghaṭaḥ iti yadi api viṣaya upaśliṣṭam eva pratibhānam bhāti tathā api na tat viṣayasya svakam vapuḥ
translated: Although the appearance as the pot appears appears as attached to the object, still that is not the self-nature of the object.

original: api tu saṃvedanameva tat tathā cakāsti māṃ prati bhāti iti pramātṛlagnatvāt /
analyzed: api tu saṃvedanam eva tat tathā cakāsti mām prati bhāti iti pramātṛ lagna tvāt
translated: But rather, that is consciousness itself, which appears thus to me, because it is attached to the cognizer.

analyzed: tathā ca veda
translated: And thus it is known

original: tameva bhāntamanu bhāti sarvaṃ tasya bhāsā sarvamidaṃ vibhāti /
analyzed: tam eva bhāntam anu bhāti sarvam tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti
translated: By that which shines, all this shines. By its light, all this shines.

original: iti / śatrā aviratasphuraṇatvaṃ karmapravacanīyena tadīyasvātantryopakalpitanirmāṇakriyājanito vedyavedakabhāvarūpo lakṣaṇātmā saṃbandho dyotitaḥ
analyzed: iti śatrā avirata sphuraṇa tvam karmapravacanīyena tadīya svātantrya upakalpita nirmāṇa kriyā janitaḥ vedya vedaka bhāva rūpaḥ lakṣaṇa ātmā saṃbandhaḥ dyotitaḥ
translated: Thus, the unceasing flashing is indicated by the grammatical operation, the relation in the form of the known and the knower, which is produced by the act of creation imagined by its independence,

analyzed: kevalam viṣaya ullekhana balāt bahis krama avabhāsaḥ samarthitaḥ
translated: Only the external sequence of manifestation is supported by the power of reflecting on the object.

original: sa sa kramayaugapadyādivicitrarūpo yaḥ padārthānāṃ vakṣyamāṇeśvarasvātantryarūpadeśakālaśaktyupakalpitaḥ kramaḥ deśakālaparipāṭī /
analyzed: sa sa krama yaugapadya ādi vicitra rūpaḥ yaḥ padārthānām vakṣyamāṇa īśvara svātantrya rūpa deśa kāla śakti upakalpitaḥ kramaḥ deśa kāla paripāṭī
translated: That sequence, simultaneity, and other diverse forms of entities, which is the sequence imagined by the power of space and time in the form of the independence of the Lord to be described, is the sequence of space and time.

analyzed: tena rūṣitā pratibimba kalpa tayā uparaktā
translated: It is colored by that, as if it were a reflection, as if it were tinged.

analyzed: yā pratibhā uktā
translated: That manifestation is said to be

analyzed: kevalam bhinna saṃvedya
translated: Only different from the cognized...

original: ityādinā / eṣā iti ca sarvasya svakāśarūpā /
analyzed: ityādinā eṣā iti ca sarvasya svakāśa rūpā
translated: And so on. This refers to the self-illumination of all.

analyzed: paramārthataḥ ca antarmukha tvena prakāśa mātra paramārtha tayā bheda abhāvāt akramā
translated: And in the ultimate sense, it is without sequence, because of the absence of difference due to the ultimate reality of light as mere inward-turned consciousness.

analyzed: saḥ eva maheśvaraḥ
translated: That itself is Maheśvara.

original: avidyamāno 'ntaḥ paricchedo deśataḥ kālataḥ svarūpataśca yasyāḥ cittaḥ saṃvidaḥ tadeva rūpaṃ yasya iti /
analyzed: a vidyamānaḥ ntaḥ paricchedaḥ deśataḥ kālataḥ svarūpataḥ ca yasyāḥ cittaḥ saṃvidaḥ tat eva rūpam yasya iti
translated: That whose inner delimitation is non-existent in terms of space, time, and own form, and whose form is that -

original: ata eva bahirmukhaprakāśātmakavijñānasvabhāvasya pramāṇavargasya yo 'ntaḥ pratyābhāsam idam idam iti ananta kalpaḥ vikalpamayo vimarśātmā 🔽pramāsamūhaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva bahirmukha prakāśa ātmaka vijñāna svabhāvasya pramāṇa vargasya yaḥ ntar pratyābhāsam idam idam iti ananta kalpaḥ vikalpa mayaḥ vimarśa ātmā  pramā samūhaḥ
translated: Therefore, the multitude of means of valid knowledge, which have the nature of external light and consciousness, the multitude of valid cognitions, which have the nature of internal deliberation, the thought this is this, the endless imagination consisting of conceptualization, having the nature of reflective awareness,

analyzed: tatra saṃyojana viyojana viśrama ādi rūpa aneka prakāra svātantrya paripūrṇaḥ śuddha ahaṃpratyavamarśa mayaḥ pramātā sa bhaṇyate
translated: There, the knower, who is complete with the many kinds of independence, such as connection, disconnection, and rest, and who consists of the pure self-awareness, is described.

original: ataśca bahirghaṭaprakāśaḥ ayaṃ ghaṭaḥ iti antarvikalpaḥ svīkṛtapūrvarūpaḥ aham iti tadubhayaviśrāntisthānam /
analyzed: atas ca bahis ghaṭa prakāśaḥ ayam ghaṭaḥ iti antar vikalpaḥ svīkṛta pūrva rūpaḥ aham iti tad ubhaya viśrānti sthānam
translated: And therefore, the external light of the pot, this is a pot, the internal thought I, which has as its object the previously cognized form, and the resting place of both of them,

analyzed: iti iyat pūrṇam prakāśasya svarūpam
translated: Thus, this much is the complete nature of light.

analyzed: atra eva upapattim pradarśayitum anvayam tāvat āha
translated: In order to demonstrate the proof right here, he first states the logical argument.

analyzed: tad tad vibhinna saṃvitti mukhaiḥ eka pramātari
translated: When all these different cognitions rest in the one cognizer through their respective doors,

analyzed: pratitiṣṭhatsu bhāveṣu jñāteyam upapadyate
translated: the knowability of objects becomes logically possible.

original: saṃvinniṣṭhā hi viṣayavyavasthitayaḥ iti yat ucyate tat na bhinnarūpaprakātmakasaṃvinmātraviśrāntyā
analyzed: saṃvid niṣṭhāḥ hi viṣaya vyavasthitayaḥ iti yat ucyate tat na bhinna rūpa prakā ātmaka saṃvid mātra viśrāntyā
translated: It is said that the determinations of objects depend on consciousness. That is not accomplished by resting in mere consciousness that manifests different forms,

original: siddhyati api tu tāstā vibhinnāḥ saṃvido niścayarūpāḥ pramātmāno yāḥ tāni eva mukhāni
analyzed: siddhyati api tu tāḥ tāḥ vibhinnāḥ saṃvidaḥ niścaya rūpāḥ pramā ātmānaḥ yāḥ tāni eva mukhāni
translated: but rather by those different cognitions in the form of ascertainment, which are the cognizing selves themselves being the doors,

original: dvārāṇi upāyā mārgāḥ taiḥ mukhaiḥ nadīsrotaḥsthānīyaiḥ yadi amī bhāvā nīlasukhādaya
analyzed: dvārāṇi upāyāḥ mārgāḥ taiḥ mukhaiḥ nadī srotaḥ sthānīyaiḥ yadi amī bhāvāḥ nīla sukha ādaya
translated: the means, the paths, by those doors which are like the currents of rivers, if these objects such as blue and pleasure

original: uhyamānā ekasmin aham iti pramātṛrūpe mahāsaṃvitsamudre pratitiṣṭhanti ābhimukhyena🔽viśrāntiṃ bhajante /🔽tata eṣu parasparaṃ samanvayarūpaṃ tat jñāteyaṃ tat upapattyā ghaṭate /
analyzed: uhyamānāḥ ekasmin aham iti pramātṛ rūpe mahā saṃvid samudre pratitiṣṭhanti ābhimukhyena  viśrāntim bhajante  tatas eṣu parasparam samanvaya rūpam tat jñāteyam tat upapattyā ghaṭate
translated: are being carried, they rest in the one in the form of the cognizer, in the great ocean of consciousness, they enjoy resting in front.🔽Therefore, the knowability of objects, which is the form of mutual connection in them, becomes logically possible.

original: jñātīnāṃ bhāvaḥ tacchabdapravṛttinimittaṃ parasparaṃ jānīyuḥ iti /
analyzed: jñātīnām bhāvaḥ tad śabda pravṛtti nimittam parasparam jānīyuḥ iti
translated: The state of being known is the reason for the application of the word known - they should mutually know each other.

analyzed: karma ca anyonya yogakṣema udvahana ātmakam jñāteyam
translated: And action, which consists of mutual cooperation and support, is knowability.

analyzed: tat ca samanvaya abhiprāyeṇa iha darśitam
translated: And that is shown here with the intention of mutual connection.

original: na jaḍānāṃ svataḥ samanvayaḥ kadācidapi iti pratipādayitum ////
analyzed: na jaḍānām svatas samanvayaḥ kadācid api iti pratipādayitum
translated: In order to demonstrate that there is never any inherent connection among the inert objects.

analyzed: tathā ca vyatireka mukhena etat eva āha
translated: And in the same way, he states this very thing by way of the negative example:

analyzed: deśa kāla krama juṣām arthānām sva samāpinām
translated: The objects, which have their own nature and which are subject to the order of space and time,

analyzed: sakṛt ābhāsa sādhyaḥ asau anyathā kaḥ samanvayaḥ
translated: That connection is accomplished by the appearance of all at once; otherwise, what connection could there be?

analyzed: arthānām jaḍānām
translated: The objects are inert.

original: tajjñānāṃ tadvikalpānāṃ tanniścayānāṃ ca deśakramaṃ kālakramaṃ cātyajatām /
analyzed: tad jñānām tad vikalpānām tad niścayānām ca deśa kramam kāla kramam ca atyajatām
translated: Those cognitions, those conceptualizations of them, and those determinations of them, which do not abandon the order of space and time,

analyzed: sva samāpinām sva rūpa mātra pratiṣṭhānām
translated: Which have their own nature, which are established in mere form.

analyzed: kaḥ samanvayaḥ
translated: What is the connection?

analyzed: na kaścid iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no connection at all.

original: yato hi asau samanvayaḥ sakṛdābhāsena deśakālākāramiśrīkaraṇātmanā yojanābhāsena sādhayituṃ śakyaḥ nānyathā /
analyzed: yatas hi asau samanvayaḥ sakṛt ābhāsena deśa kāla ākāra miśrīkaraṇa ātmanā yojana ābhāsena sādhayitum śakyaḥ na anyathā
translated: Because that connection can be accomplished by the appearance of all at once, by the appearance of arrangement in the form of a mixture of space, time, and form, and not otherwise.

original: na hi pṛthakpṛthak parikṣīṇeṣu srotaḥsu taduhyamānāḥ tṛṇolapādayaḥ samanvayaṃ kaṃcit yānti iti /
analyzed: na hi pṛthak pṛthak parikṣīṇeṣu srotaḥsu tad uhyamānāḥ tṛṇa ulapa ādayaḥ samanvayam kaṃcid yānti iti
translated: For the bundles of grass, twigs, etc., which are being carried along in the streams that are separately exhausted, do not go anywhere in a connection.

original: anekatvena deśakālādibheda ityāśayena sakṛcchabdaḥ tanniṣedhatātparyeṇa prayuktaḥ ////
analyzed: aneka tvena deśa kāla ādi bhedaḥ iti āśayena sakṛt śabdaḥ tad niṣedha tātparyeṇa prayuktaḥ
translated: The word all at once is used with the intention of negating that, with the idea that there is a difference of space, time, etc., due to multiplicity.

original: tatra ko 'sau samanvaya ityāśaṅkya bahutaravyāpakaṃ kāryakāraṇabhāvaṃ tāvat darśayati 🔽pratyakṣānupalambhānāṃ tattadbhinnāṃśapātinām /
analyzed: tatra kaḥ sau samanvayaḥ iti āśaṅkya bahutara vyāpakam kārya kāraṇa bhāvam tāvat darśayati  pratyakṣa anupalambhānām tad tad bhinna aṃśa pātinām
translated: There, what is that agreement? Suspecting this, he first shows the relation of cause and effect, which is more extensive and pervasive,
The causal relation is established by the single cognizer who is the cause of the perception and non-perception that are limited to each part.

analyzed: iha anubhūtaḥ viṣayaḥ prakāśate smṛtau
translated: Here, the experienced object appears in memory.

original: tatra viṣayasyāsau smṛtiḥ na nūtanaḥ prakāśaḥ api tu asya sa prakāśaḥ prācyo 'nubhava eva /
analyzed: tatra viṣayasya asau smṛtiḥ na nūtanaḥ prakāśaḥ api tu asya sa prakāśaḥ prācyaḥ nubhavaḥ eva
translated: There, that memory of the object is not a new appearance, but rather that appearance is the previous experience itself.

original: sa cānubhavo jñānarūpatvena jñeyarūpatvābhāvāt na jñānāntarasaṃvedyaḥ api tu svaprakāśaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca anubhavaḥ jñāna rūpa tvena jñeya rūpa tva abhāvāt na jñāna antara saṃvedyaḥ api tu sva prakāśaḥ
translated: And that experience, being of the nature of knowledge, is not to be known by another knowledge, but is self-luminous, because it does not have the nature of the knowable.

original: sa ca smṛtikāle yadi asan tat kathaṃ prakāśatām /
analyzed: sa ca smṛti kāle yadi asān tat katham prakāśatām
translated: And if that [experience] were non-existent at the time of memory, how could it appear?

original: bhavatu vā asau tathāpi smṛtiḥ syāt /
analyzed: bhavatu vai asau tathā api smṛtiḥ syāt
translated: Or let it be so, still it would be memory.

analyzed: tasmāt etat evam upapadyate
translated: Therefore, this is reasonable:

analyzed: yat eva smṛti sva saṃvedanam
translated: That which is the self-awareness of memory,

analyzed: tat eva anubhavasya sva saṃvedanam
translated: That itself is the self-awareness of experience.

original: na tu aparaṃ svasaṃvedanavyatiriktaṃ pratyakṣam anumānādikaṃ vā tatra kramate /
analyzed: na tu aparam sva saṃvedana vyatiriktam pratyakṣam anumāna ādikam vā tatra kramate
translated: But no other perception or inference, etc., apart from self-awareness, operates there.

original: tataśca tāvatkālāpi avichinnamekaṃ yat svasaṃvedanaṃ tadeva pramātṛttvam iti siddham /
analyzed: tatas ca tāvatkālā api avichinnam ekam yat sva saṃvedanam tat eva pramātṛ ttvam iti siddham
translated: And therefore, the very same self-awareness which is uninterrupted for that period of time is established to be the state of being a knower.

original: anyatra anubhavitari smartā anyo na upapadyate /
analyzed: anyatra anubhavitari smartā anyaḥ na upapadyate
translated: When there is another experiencer, a different one cannot be the recollector.

original: ityanayā chāyayā smṛtyā pramātṛsiddhiḥ pūrvamuktā /🔽idānīṃ tu svasaṃvedanaikībhāvena bhaṅgyantareṇa iti viśeṣaḥ ////
analyzed: iti anayā chāyayā smṛtyā pramātṛ siddhiḥ pūrvam uktā  idānīm tu sva saṃvedana ekībhāvena bhaṅgī antareṇa iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: Thus, the establishment of the knower has been stated earlier by this shadow, by memory.🔽But now, by the oneness of self-awareness, it is in a different way - this is the difference.

analyzed: nanu anubhava atirikte pi arthe santu vikalpāḥ pramāṇam
translated: But even if the object is different from experience, let the conceptual thoughts be valid cognition.

analyzed: aprāmāṇyam hi bādha balāt bhavati
translated: For invalidity occurs due to the force of contradiction.

original: bādhābhāve tat kathaṃ syād ityāśaṅkya so 'pi ayaṃ bādhyabādhakabhāvaḥ satyāsatyapravibhājanayā
analyzed: bādhā abhāve tat katham syāt iti āśaṅkya saḥ u pi ayam bādhya bādhaka bhāvaḥ satya asatya pravibhājanayā
translated: If there is no contradiction, how can it be? Thinking this, he says that this relation of contradiction and the contradicted also, by distinguishing the true from the false,

original: viśveṣāṃ vyavahārāṇāṃ jīvitabhūto na ekena pramātṛtattvena vinā ghaṭata iti vitatya darśayati
analyzed: viśveṣām vyavahārāṇām jīvita bhūtaḥ naḥ ekena pramātṛ tattvena vinā ghaṭate iti vitatya darśayati
translated: is the life of all worldly conventions and does not occur without a single true knower. He shows this in detail.

analyzed: bādhya bādhaka bhāvaḥ api sva ātma niṣṭhā virodhinām
translated: The relation of contradiction and the contradicted can arise for cognitions that are opposed to being established in their own nature,

analyzed: jñānānām udiyāt eka pramātṛ pariniṣṭhiteḥ
translated: because they are established in a single true knower.

original: bādhābhāve prāmāṇyam ityetadartham avaśyasamarthyo yo bādhavyavahāraḥ so 'pi katham iti api śabdasyārthaḥ /
analyzed: bādhā abhāve prāmāṇyam iti etad artham avaśya samarthyaḥ yaḥ bādha vyavahāraḥ saḥ u pi katham iti api śabdasya arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the phrase 'how can' is this: the usage of contradiction, which must necessarily be established, for the sake of the statement 'validity is in the absence of contradiction'.

original: iha śuktyā tāvat rajatasya na kācit bādhā nāma kriyamāṇā dṛśyate /
analyzed: iha śuktyā tāvat rajatasya na kācid bādhā nāma kriyamāṇā dṛśyate
translated: In this case, with regard to the mother-of-pearl, no contradiction of silver is seen to be produced at all.

original: śuktijñānena rajatajñānaṃ bādhyate ityapi na yuktam /
analyzed: śukti jñānena rajata jñānam bādhyate iti api na yuktam
translated: It is also not correct to say that the cognition of silver is contradicted by the cognition of mother-of-pearl.

original: svasmin viṣaye ātmani ca svarūpe dvayoḥ jñānayoḥ pariniṣṭhitayoḥ viśr/
analyzed: svasmin viṣaye ātmani ca svarūpe dvayoḥ jñānayoḥ pariniṣṭhitayoḥ viśrānti
translated: In its own object, in the self, and in its own form, the two cognitions are established and rest.

original: antayoḥ anyonyaṃ virodhasya abhāvāt /🔽atha ayaṃ parasparaparihāra eva virodhaḥ tarhi sarveṣāṃ jñānānāṃ virodhāt bādhyabādhakabhāvasya svātmani pariniṣṭhaiva na labhyeti sutarāṃ
analyzed: antayoḥ anyonyam virodhasya abhāvāt  atha ayam paraspara parihāraḥ eva virodhaḥ tarhi sarveṣām jñānānām virodhāt bādhya bādhaka bhāvasya svātmani pariniṣṭhā eva na labhyā iti sutarām
translated: Because there is no mutual contradiction between them.🔽If mutual exclusion itself is contradiction, then due to the contradiction of all cognitions, the relation of the contradicted and the contradictor cannot be established in their own nature at all, so the distinction between the real and the other would be

analyzed: vighaṭeta satya itara pravibhāgaḥ
translated: destroyed even more.

analyzed: nañ api atra tantreṇa vyākhyeyaḥ
translated: The negative particle should also be explained by implication here.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati yadi jñānaṃ svayaṃ naśyati tadā kiṃ jñānāntareṇa asya kṛtam /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati yadi jñānam svayam naśyati tadā kim jñāna antareṇa asya kṛtam
translated: This is what is meant: if a cognition is destroyed by itself, then what has been done to it by another cognition?

original: na hi tena tatkāle 'saṃbhavatā tasya viṣayāpahāraḥ kartuṃ śakyaḥ /
analyzed: na hi tena tad kāle saṃbhavatā tasya viṣaya apahāraḥ kartum śakyaḥ
translated: For at that time, when it is not possible, it cannot be made to take away its object by that [other cognition].

original: na rājatam ityapi jñānaṃ svaṃ rajatābhāvaṃ viṣayīkurvat na viṣayam apaharet rajatajñānasya /
analyzed: na rājatam iti api jñānam svam rajata abhāvam viṣayīkurvat na viṣayam apaharet rajata jñānasya
translated: Nor does the cognition 'this is not silver' which makes its own content the absence of silver, remove the content of the cognition of silver.

analyzed: atha api jñāna antareṇa nāśyate iti api pakṣaḥ
translated: Even if it is accepted that it is destroyed by another cognition,

original: tatrāpi sarveṣāṃ jñānām iyameva saraṇiriti kiṃcideva bādhyam iti kathaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tatra api sarveṣām jñānām iyam eva saraṇiḥ iti kiṃcid eva bādhyam iti katham syāt
translated: in that case also this is the only way for all cognitions. So how could anything be contradicted?

original: yadā tu rajatajñānaṃ śuktijñānaṃ ca ekatra svasaṃvedane viśrānyataḥ tadā etat upapadyate /
analyzed: yadā tu rajata jñānam śukti jñānam ca ekatra sva saṃvedane viśrānyataḥ tadā etat upapadyate
translated: But when the cognition of silver and the cognition of the mother-of-pearl rest together in the self-awareness, then this is possible.

original: tathā hi ekatrāpi pramātṛtattve viśrāmyatāṃ jñānānāṃ naikaprakāraiva viśrāntiḥ api tu vicitratayaiva sā saṃvedyate /
analyzed: tathā hi ekatra api pramātṛ tattve viśrāmyatām jñānānām nā eka prakārā eva viśrāntiḥ api tu vicitra tayā eva sā saṃvedyate
translated: For even in one cognizer, the resting of cognitions is not of one kind only, but is experienced as diverse.

original: tathā hi nīlam iti utpalam iti jñāne pramātari viśrāmyantī parasparoparāgābhāsena viśrāmyataḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi nīlam iti utpalam iti jñāne pramātari viśrāmyantī paraspara uparāga ābhāsena viśrāmyataḥ
translated: For instance, in the cognitions 'blue' and 'lotus', resting in the cognizer, they rest by the appearance of mutual infusion.

analyzed: ghaṭaḥ iti paṭaḥ iti paraspara an āśkeṣeṇa
translated: In 'jar' and 'cloth', by mutual non-exclusion.

original: śuktikā iti na rajatam iti vā jñānaṃ rajatam iti jñānasya unmūlanaṃ tadīyavimarśātmakapramārūpavyāpārānuvartanavidhvaṃsaṃ kurvat pramātari
analyzed: śuktikā iti na rajatam iti vā jñānam rajatam iti jñānasya unmūlanam tadīya vimarśa ātmaka pramā rūpa vyāpāra anuvartana vidhvaṃsam kurvat pramātari
translated: The cognition 'this is mother-of-pearl' or 'this is not silver' destroys the cognition 'this is silver' by removing the operation in the form of the ascertainment belonging to it.

analyzed: pratiṣṭhām bhajate
translated: attains stability.

original: evaṃ kāryakāraṇabhāvādau viśrāntivaicitryaṃ prameyāsaṃbhavi pramātrā svātantryeṇa nirmitaṃ tata eva asya pramāsvatantratādāyi vācyam /
analyzed: evam kārya kāraṇa bhāva ādau viśrānti vaicitryam prameya asaṃbhavi pramātrā svātantryeṇa nirmitam tatas eva asya pramā svatantra tā dāyi vācyam
translated: Thus, the variety of resting in the relation of cause and effect, etc., which is impossible in the object of knowledge, is created by the knower independently.
